<question from>



Meow M
Member since: 10 October 2008
Total points: 62 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Opinions bad/good please?



Notice how she doesn't send you her thoughts in sound anymore?
Yes I do...
Notice how she does not send you written feelings anymore?
Yes I do...
What can you do about this?
A lot of things but the results will mean nothing.
What do you think?
I believe that this is how love is, it comes to you inevitably and without warning, it strikes the heart, conquers it, makes itself comfortable inside, sleeps well and when the morning light bothers its eyes leaves without a saying,  a note on the table or a good-bye kiss on the forehead while you sleep. Nothing sweet to leave behind just the dull loneliness and the silence of the room that you both used to sleep in, reminiscing on every single moment that at that time did not seem so special but now that you cannot experience them again you feel like screaming at the sky in hopes that it will scream an answer back or at least make the clouds mad and receive a lighting so that this pain and agony will perish.
What do you feel?
I cannot truly describe all of my feelings as they are deep inside and unreachable, the pure sight of my face can describe everything, the pose of my body, my staring at the floor and if you look deep into my eyes you would find yourself falling into a bottomless abysm where the dark is pitch black and the coldness hurts the bones, you will feel my torment and mourn with me as well, but I do not wish for you to feel what I feel.
So why do you love?
I do not love anymore, and for that I am about to perish, we have to love someone or at least something in order to keep living and keep going forward, love took us to where we are at the moment, if you did not love asking questions so much you would not be here at this moment asking them to me, and the answer to all of your questions should be "love", love or be loved, it does not matter, as long as love is present in your life your blood will be warm, your heart will keep pumping and your lungs will still drink the air outside, love, be loved or perish like me... 



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



Moving words indeed, your text is great but I suggest breaking it up some as its hard on the eyes to read (perhaps its for the benefit of Yahoo Answers that you've typed it this way ?)



</answer>

What do you think of this plot?



Title: "The Rich & Poor"
This story is basically about a teenage girl just out of high school who had to take care of her little brother since her parents died. Now there is the guy across the street who secretly has feelings for her and helps take care of her. He is in his mid 20's. He has helped her out since her parents died. Anyways rich guy comes in the picture and finds her interesting and soon ends up falling for her. Now his parents are all like some poor street rat, where too high powered for that so he makes up an excuse and says that her little brother is his son and they have been together secretly for a long time which causes trouble and drama for the mid 20's guy and himself. Soon she tells the truth because she's not that type of girl to lie and things have to end.



But I'm thinking of a sequel about she had a kid w/ him but the she says that it's the mid 20 year old guys kid.



So I need help too maybe change it up a bit if it doesn't sound good or interesting, things you might think that she be added in? Names and suggestions? Plz I need help with this one. XI

<question>



What should I title my book? ?



Haha....I've asked this question about 300 times but I'll ask it again....
I need some help coming up with a name for my book. It is temporarily called The Violet Eyes but I would like something a little better. Okay, I'll post a link for the first five chapters of it . I want the name to be a little gloomy but beautiful in a strange way.



http://www.fictionpress.com/s/2581604/1/...



Here is a summary, though I would so much rather you jsut read the book becasue I suck at summaries and reading the book will help you get a better gist of the kind of mood I want to set:
The book is about a girl named Lily who has just escaped from a school that trains witches from birth to be cold-blooded killers. She meets a young man and begins to fall in love with him but then realizes that he is a vampire and that she has been trained to kill him her whole life. The young man sees her eyes (they are violet, the sign of a witch) and begins to attack her. Lily doesn't fight back becasue she feels that she deserves it and she lets him bite her (she becomes sort of a half-vampire, she is only a vampire at night and she bites herself rather than hurt anymore innocent people) So then a Master at the school that she jsut escaped from tries to kill the vmapire and Lily throws herself in front of him and gets injured really badly. She collapses and William pulls her into her arms and kisses her becasue she just saved his life. Um...when she wakes up he is gone but she still has feeling for him...and a bunch of other stuff happens.
Thank you, and sorry for that horrible summary



Oh, I almost forgot, I recently discovered that there is already a book called Violet Eyes, so, yeah......That one is out



</question>



<additional details>



Before someone says something, let me clear one thing up...THIS IS NOT A TWILIGHT RIPOFF! Just becasue a story includes a freakin vampire doens't mean that that person stole the idea from Stephenie Meyer. There were plenty of stories invloving vampires before Twilight and there will be many after. Now if William (the vampire) sparkled, had no fangs, attacked animals, was pale nad beautiful then that would be a Twilight ripoff. If Lily was clumsy, blushed alot, and hted parties then yes that would be a Twilgiht ripoff! Sorry I blew up liek that but it jsut really ticks me off that people judge you before they even have read the whole story. And another thing, I started writing this ages before I'd even heard of Twilight.....



Oh! I'm sorry, I totally did not mean you. I know that you weren't callign it a Twilight ripoff, I jsut wanted to make sure that no one did. Thank you for your honesty and sorry for the misunderstanding. Also thanks for calling it an accomplishment. To be quite honest, I'm a little tired of the vmapires myself, but I promised myself that I would finish this one and I am sticking to it



</additional details>



<answer from>



gracie11...
Member since: 05 November 2008
Total points: 124 (Level 1)



</answer from>

No, it's okay. I liked the idea of your story, it sounds really interesting.



Okay...titles, um, I have a few in mind just off the top of my head:



Heart, Soul and Mind
Price of Love
For You
Blood Red Hearts
Betrayel
Mistake
Bite of Death, Kiss of Life



Yeah..I think that's all I've got. Hope this helps! Or if it doesn't, inspires some other ideas. :D



</answer>

<question from>



Marion G
Member since: 26 August 2008
Total points: 91 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Where Can I Find A New Moon(Whole Book) PDF In The Internet?



</question>



<answer from>



redunico...
Member since: 26 January 2006
Total points: 241150 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



History



Books & Authors



</answer from>



<answer>



That would be stealing from Stephenie Meyer because she is not giving the book away for free.



Yes pirates have stolen Stehenie's books before. But if you read her book on a pirate website, you are a pirate too.



" In a civil suit, an infringer may be liable for a copyright owner's actual damages plus any profits made from the infringement. Alternatively, the copyright owner may avoid proving actual damage by electing a statutory damage recovery of up to $30,000 or, where the court determines that the infringement occurred willfully, up to $150,000. The actual amount will be based upon what the court in its discretion considers just. (17 U.S.C. 504)



Violation of copyright law is also considered a federal crime when done willfully with an intent to profit. Criminal penalties include up to ten years imprisonment depending on the nature of the violation. (No Electronic Theft Act, 18 U.S.C. 2319)"



Source(s):



http://www.chillingeffects.org/piracy/fa...



</answer>



<answer from>

Member since: 10 July 2007
Total points: 22226 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



You can't, it's called stealing. Go buy one or get one from the library.

<question>



Help about INVICTUS of William Ernest Henley?



Invictus
-William Ernest Henley



Out of the night that covers me,



Black as the pit from pole to pole,
I thank whatever gods may be



For my unconquerable soul.



In the fell clutch of circumstance



I have not winced nor cried aloud.
Beneath the bludgeoning of chance



My head is bloody, but unbowed.



Beyond this space of wrath and tears



Looms but the Horror of the shade,
And yet the menace of the years



Finds and shall find me unafraid.



It matters not how strait the gate,



How charged with punishments the scroll,
I am the master of my fate:



I am the captain of my soul.



Help me explain each stanza pleeeaaaaaaasssseeeeeeeeeeee...
(sob)



</question>

<original file>12371.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk102054.txt</current file name>




<category>



Arts & Humanities



Books & Authors



</category>



<question from>



Melissa H
Member since: 05 November 2008
Total points: 95 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



In "The Rime of the Ancient Mariner"?



Why might Coleridge have spent so little time describing the killing of the albatross when it is such a crucial aspect of the overall plot?



</question>



<answer from>



Eoredd
Member since: 20 November 2006
Total points: 28800 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



Maybe the "plot" of a poem is not extremely important, compared to other aspects (vers, images, rhythms...) The plot doesn't play in a poem the same role as in a novel.



</answer>



<answer from>



BeautyBl...
Member since: 19 July 2008
Total points: 4965 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



The killing of the Albatross is at the very end of Part 1.  There was no need to drag it out and make it a long drawn out part of the peice.  He killed the Albatross and moved onto part 2 where the fall-out from killing the albatross starts.  There just wasn't a need to write a long passage about it.  The killing of the albatross is not as crucial as the effect it has.



</answer>

<question from>



kikkiday

</question from>

<category>



Arts & Humanities



Books & Authors



</category>



<question from>



luvs2wri...
Member since: 05 November 2008
Total points: 100 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What do you think of the character names listed below...  ?



I'm making a new story and I was wondering what you think about the names I might use in the story call "The Rich & Poor..."
Age/Looks/Personality/Flaws/Good Traits... etc.



Aveline Elizabeth
Keilana Beth
Jadalyn Kristine



Conan Wolfe
Gage



Tristan Elliot
Vincent Ryan



</question>



<answer from>



sndtrks@...
Member since: 04 November 2008
Total points: 120 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Conan Wolfe is good.  The rest sound made up.  I'd shoot for real names and use unique names (like Conan Wolfe) sparingly.  Google a baby name finder, that may help.  There's a program where you can set some parameters on names you like or are interested in and they will suggest more options.  Traditional or time tested names are great.  Also, it helps to connect the name of the person to the characters personality/disposition.  For example, the sort of nerdy, lonely, not in shape character from "Lady in the Water" was named, appropriately, Cleveland Heap (sp?).  Jane Austin's Elizabeth Bennet was a name of the time, Victorian and English.  And finally, mono-names like Gage are only for superheros.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks for the opinion, so now I should change the names lol.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Fern
Member since: 15 October 2008
Total points: 208 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Aveline Elizabeth:



Sounds unique, and slightly olden-dayish.  I'm thinking a responsible, traditional person with a solid set of values.  Make her either really old or and quite young.



Keilana Beth:



I think that this one sounds like a teen.  And a rebellious one at that.



Jadalyn Kristine:



Another teen ... maybe a little bit mature for her age.



Conan Wolfe:



Either really popular or really mysterious and dark.  A young adult or late teen.



Gage:



This guy sounds like a drug addict lol.  Mid thirties.  Sneaky, sly, likes to bend the rules.



Tristan Elliot:



Sounds like some rich guy.  Some 'daddy will buy it for me' rich guy.



Vincent Ryan:



He sounds like the not-so-rich rich guys best friends xD



</answer>

Based on your knowledge of Franklin’s work and your understanding of Gatsby’s character, argue whether or not Jay Gatsby has lived up to his boyhood vision of a well-rounded man. <original file>15080.html</original file>

<category>



Arts & Humanities



Books & Authors



</category>



<question from>



Rachel G
Member since: 16 April 2008
Total points: 16 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What comparisons do both of these poems have? can someone help?



"To My Dear and Loving Husband"



By: Anne Bradstreet



_If ever two were one, then surely we.



If ever man were loved by wife, then thee:



If ever wife was happy in a man,



Compare with me, ye woman, if you can.



I prize thy love more than whole mines of gold



Or all the riches that the East doth hold.



My love is such that rivers cannot quench,



Nor ought but love from thee, give recompense.



Thy love is such I can no way repay,



The heavens reward thee manifold, I pray.



Then while we live, in love let’s so persevere



That when we live no more, we may live ever.



"Upon the Burning of Our House"
By: Anne Bradstreet



_In silent night when rest I took,
For sorrow near I did not look,
I waken'd was with thund'ring noise
And piteous shrieks of dreadful voice.
That fearful sound of "fire" and "fire,"
Let no man know is my Desire.
I starting up, the light did spy,
And to my God my heart did cry
To straighten me in my Distress
And not to leave me succourless.
Then coming out, behold a space
The flame consume my dwelling place.
And when I could no longer look,
I blest his grace that gave and took,
That laid my goods now in the dust.
Yea, so it was, and so 'twas just.
It was his own; it was not mine.
Far be it that I should repine,
He might of all justly bereft
But yet sufficient for us left.
When by the Ruins oft I past
My sorrowing eyes aside did cast
And here and there the places spy
Where oft I sate and long did lie.
Here stood that Trunk, and there that chest,
There lay that store I counted best,
My pleasant things in ashes lie
And them behold no more shall I.
Under the roof no guest shall sit,
Nor at thy Table eat a bit.
No pleasant talk shall 'ere be told
Nor things recounted done of old.
No Candle 'ere shall shine in Thee,
Nor bridegroom's voice ere heard shall bee.
In silence ever shalt thou lie.
Adieu, Adieu, All's Vanity.
Then straight I 'gin my heart to chide:
And did thy wealth on earth abide,
Didst fix thy hope on mouldring dust,
The arm of flesh didst make thy trust?
Raise up thy thoughts above the sky
That dunghill mists away may fly.
Thou hast a house on high erect
Fram'd by that mighty Architect,
With glory richly furnished
Stands permanent, though this be fled.
It's purchased and paid for too
By him who hath enough to do.
A price so vast as is unknown,
Yet by his gift is made thine own.
There's wealth enough; I need no more.
Farewell, my pelf; farewell, my store.
The world no longer let me love;
My hope and Treasure lies above.



</question>

<answer>

<answer from>



someone
Member since: 05 November 2008
Total points: 103 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I'm not familiar with Gregor the Overlander, but Brisger and Twilight are in the Young Adult section of my library.  If you're ready to graduate to the adult side, check out anything by Terry Brooks.  Don't worry about his books being inappropriate or too adult--they're all very clean.  His series include Word and Void (3 books), Genesis of Shannara (3 books so far), Shannara (14 books: 4 independent, the rest sets of 4, 3, and 3, in that order), and Landover (5 so far i think, with a new one on the way).  If you love series, you'll love the fact that Genesis of Shannara is in the process of connecting the Word and Void world to the world of Shannara.  Start anywhere you like though.



If you don't want to dive in there, you could always try the Pellinor books: The Naming, The Riddle, and The Crow, with a fourth coming out eventually.  Those are Young Adult books.



Sci-fi... basically anything Star Wars, found all over the place by different authors.  A good sci-fi/fantasy mix would be the Dragonriders of Pern series by Anne McCaffrey.  Most of hers are on the adult side, but there may be a few in Young Adult depending on your library.



</answer>



<answer from>



Bookworm...
Member since: 05 November 2008
Total points: 102 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Terry Pratchett for sci-fi



Other seriously good books:



The Secret History
The Time Traveller's Wife
Tokyo, Birman, The Treatment and Ritual

The Beach
The Shadow of the Wind

Valley of the Dolls

Set this House in Order
The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night Time
Catch-22
The Great Gatsby
The Complete Tales and Poems of Edgar Allen Poe
The Poisonwood Bible



</answer>




<original file>16014.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk106102.txt</current file name>




<category>



Arts & Humanities



Books & Authors



</category>



<question from>



Ajinkya C
Member since: 05 November 2008
Total points: 95 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What is the book pride & prejudice all about



explain fast?



</question>



<answer from>



daisy30u...
Member since: 14 January 2008
Total points: 608 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I hate to state the obvious, but it is about Pride and Prejudice!



Elizabeth Bennett and Mr Darcy are both too proud and prejudiced without any real foundation. Elizabeth is prejudiced against Darcy and for Wickham - a mistake that costs the family dearly. Darcy is also prejudiced against Jane because of her social position. It is not until they see the truth about each other and the other characters that they can change and fall in love.



</answer>



<answer from>



Clemon
Member since: 07 August 2007
Total points: 116 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



The book has 3 main themes:
Pride, Prejudice & Marriage.



So basically the idea of the book is how these different people with varying amounts of Pride and Prejudice about other people must overcome that to have...uh.. Marriage.



This can be shown by the three marriages of



Charlotte & Mr. Collins



(neither has a great deal of pride and no prejudice)



Jane & Mr. Bingley



(the prejudgment of the Bingley family made the Bennets look forward to Mr. Bingley from the beginning, and neither parts have a great pride to stop them from marrying)



Elizabeth & Mr. Darcy



(Both have negative prejudgments about the other, and consider their pride more important--this pride is what make Elizabeth turn down Mr. Darcy's first proposal)



I hope this helps. ^ ^



</answer>

<original file>16017.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk106105.txt</current file name>




<category>



Arts & Humanities



Books & Authors



</category>



<question from>



Future Marine
Member since: 03 December 2007
Total points: 740 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



I need an idea for this story?



So I have to write this story for class, but here's the catch



The story has to be about a big secret that nobody else knows about the  Character , and in diary entries, and at the end the secret is supposed to be revealed in the last diary entry



So I need some ideas, and I want to try to make comical if at all possible....so can you give me some ideas?



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



The writer comes from another planet and has assumed human form. It/he/she finds it difficult to maintain this form since it takes so much of its energy. Each day it experiments with the form it should take but meets people from the previous day who comment that they feel that they have seen it somewhere before. You can imagine the trouble it gets into in bars, when it appears as an attractive female but does not comprehend what the dudes are after. Or when it appears as a helpless old male/female and some muggers attempt to rob it only to encounter a superhuman strength and agility.



There you are! Have a go at that and remember that the diary or report will have a style all its own.



</answer>

It's been a very looong time since I've read this strange book...



1) She got scared of what she had to experience, and so she requested (and was) "released" (killed).
2) No Idea...continue to train them?
3) The older Giver who trains the new Giver
4) When he saw the colour of the apple (cause everyone esle sees in greytone) (and has "Capacity to See-Beyond")
5) I guess they must be young and be different?
6) Having to experience really bad things (i.e. coldness, despair)
7) No Idea...



Ok so not really helpful. It helps best to read the novel or asked someone more intelligent about it...

<original file>18838.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk109238.txt</current file name>




<category>



Arts & Humanities



Books & Authors



</category>



<question from>



waiting on the world to change..
Member since: 06 June 2008
Total points: 2599 (Level 4)



</question from>



<question>



What do you think: should i finish this story?



Well, i've asked this question once before (long time ago) only i added a little more to it this time. (14 yrs old, if needed)



~~~~
Waiting across the street for Demetris to arrive, Aniela sat in the shadows of the dark alley, unseen by any passers-by. She crouched low as a large delivery truck drove past,  splashing mud on her light jacket. She, being now frustrated by the lateness of  Demetris, brushed off the mud, eyes narrowing.



The man with the brief case strolled down the alley, looking not afraid, but very aware of his surroundings. Aniela stole out of her crouch and slowly tip-toed towards the man, her eyes on nothing but the case he now held against his chest.



“Is that the file?” Her cold voice rung throughout the street, echoing off of the empty trash bins nearby.



“Y-Yes,” the man stuttered. His eyes now shined with fear, greatly exempting their dark brown color.
Aniela held out her pale, long-fingered hand. “Give it here.”
“I-” The man swallowed, making strange gulping noise. “I want to be sure of our deal. I-I need to know nothing happened to my son.”
“Trust me,” Aniela said, snatching the solid case from his enclosed hands. “You will know soon enough.”
She turned and stalked down the dark alley, seeming to disappear into its depths.
*
Aniela arrived in Switzerland at exactly 12:01. Late, she thought. Again. She marched through the busy streets of a small town, covered in a light snow, glaring in a straight haze. Many tourists, laden with shopping bags and fudge, were pushed lazily aside.



Demetris was perched against a telephone pole, his back towards the bustling crowd, talking fluently in what sounded like French on a tiny cell phone. Aniela, feeling her anger returning, launched herself at the unaware man’s back, knocking him upside the head.



“You idiot! You imbecile! You didn’t show!” Aniela pounded her fists furiously into the tall man’s back, struggling to keep her voice low.
“I know. I had to take care of some personal business.”
Aniela glared. What sort of ravage fool would leave his partner?



“Doing what?” She asked, her voice smitten with rage.
“Never you mind. Now, please follow me. Master is waiting, and might I add he is not pleased with you.” Demetris kept his face expressionless, though clear joy was etched into his deep blue eyes.
The pair quickly rounded the corner, still miles from their destination. Miles they could make up easily, of course,  once the grubbiness of this low-class town was left behind. Demetris led the way, only glancing over his shoulder when a pretty girl passed. “Oh, please!” Aniela whispered, still following the mysterious man that was her partner.



The last building on the road was nestled near the silent woods. The building was shabby, obviously not used in a few years, and in need of some major repair. Few people lingered here, nor were many on this particular block. Demetris pulled a tiny key from his breast pocket, and slid it into the door.



The inside of the deserted building was exactly how Aniela pictured it. Small, dusty, and cramped, with covered antique furniture hidden in the shadows. The only item that appeared to be left untouched was a small wood desk in the middle of the room.



The chair behind the desk slowly turned, showing the face of their Master. Aniela and Demetris both cringed, seeing the mangled face.
“Enter.” The harsh voice called. “Both of you. Quickly.”



Aniela pushed Demetris further into the room, slamming the old door behind her.



She glanced at Demetris, whose smug expression was entirely gone from his topaz eyes. Aniela stood slightly behind him, keeping herself slightly distanced from the chair.



“Aniela, you’re late. Again. Is this becoming too hard for you?” The chair swiveled again, to the right this time. It moved forward, towards to two standing motionless near the door. “Because, if it is, I can easily fix that.” The man in the chair pulled out a long stick, seemingly flicking it through his fingers.



“No. No I can handle it. But, sir, I need more time, the nuisance of a boy knows we’re after him. He’s running, and he is quick. He’s got the two others with him, both experienced and ready. Its unlikely I’ll be able to capture him while he is being guarded by them.” Aniela’s fear made her voice quiver.



“We.” Demetris glared forward. “We will catch him.”
Aniela disregarded this comment, not letting his stupidity cost both of their lives.



The man in the chair flicked his wand at the creaky door, making it fly open. Taking it as her cue to leave, she pulled Demetris by the back of his long cloak. “Yes, Master. It will be done.”



~~~~
Alright, so do you think i should finish it?



Got any ideas for what happens next, also? I have a terrible writers' blcok. :)
thanks, and be nice, please! :)



</question>



<answer from>



BeautyBl...
Member since: 19 July 2008
Total points: 4995 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



The cure for writers block is the following:



sit down and keep writing, no matter how bad you think it is because eventually something worthwhile will jump onto the page.



The only way to get better is to practice, the only way to practice is to keep writing.  I think you should finish it.  It may not be your finest work you will ever do but it is a beginning, and every writer needs a beginning.



</answer>

Rawley M

<answer>



Because at the time of  his writing, single-sex education was in the majority in England.



</answer>



<answer from>



radiojoy...
Member since: 14 September 2008
Total points: 260 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Several reasons:
Firstly, it would have introduced more overt sexual tensions in the book (if you read it, they do exist a la the pig-rape scene; however he mains them subtly) which would have been detracting from the overall message.



Secondly, he was raised in British single-sex education, so the amount of explaining needed to include girls would have been greater than any need to have them in there.



Thirdly, LotF is in part a dissection of war and the abstract societies that grow out of conflict and founding. Typically, war and exploration have been carried out by men.



</answer>



<answer from>



augie6_1
Member since: 30 October 2008
Total points: 647 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



From Shmoop Literature on Lord of the Flies



http://www.shmoop.com/intro/literature/w...



In A Nutshell



The whole boys-being-stuck-on-an-island thing is nothing new, and it seems Golding used this scenario to respond to another novel, The Coral Island, written by R.M. Ballantyne in 1857. The Coral Island depicts some white, European boys who end up on an island and use Christianity to “conquer” the “heathen ways” of the Polynesian natives. Naturally, this was a huge success in Victorian England. Golding read it and got all fired up, and wrote Lord of the Flies using many of the same names for his characters that Ballantyne did. Unlike The Coral Island, Lord of the Flies shows the British boys as savage and, to use a technical term, rather “sketch.”



From Character Clues



http://www.shmoop.com/character-clues/li...



Names
At the beginning of the novel, before the reader is told the boys’ names, Golding uses labels as a characterization tool, such as “the fair boy,” and “the fat boy.” At first, we’re bothered by these labels; it doesn’t seem right for the boys to be without names. But then we realize that “the fat boy” is not very different from “Piggy,” and that even names like “Ralph” and “Jack” are just descriptions (Ralph means “counsel,” by the way – nifty, isn’t it?). In other words, what seems “primitive” to us is really just a slightly skewed version of what we do in “civilized society.” Oh, also, Simon is a name from the Bible to reflect his spirituality.



Source(s):



www.shmoop.com



</answer>

<question from>



B'klyn
Member since: 19 December 2007
Total points: 25 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What is the comparison and contrast of the 2 poems "To His Coy Mistress" and To the Virgins, to make a Time?



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



In the Andrew Marvell poem, the speaker is urging a woman to have sex with him personally.  The Robert Herrick poem is addressed to young women in general, advising them to embrace their sexuality.  In doing your comparison and contrast, some of the things you might look at are the arguments that the two poems make in favor of sexual activity, and the language they use (including metaphors and other figures of speech) to discuss such topics as sex, love, youth, old age, and death.



</answer>

<question from>



Recheli
Member since: 09 October 2007
Total points: 323 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Do you know this childrens book?



it's about an African girl who gets kidnapped by the sea on her way to get a conch shell and is stolen by someone/thing and put into a drum. They take the drum to villages and get rich because they hit the drum and make her sing, and the people think the drum is magic.
In the end, the little girl inside the drum knows she is in her own village and sings a song about herself while her captors are away so the listeners know that she is within the drum, kidnapped.
The villagers take the little girl away and fill the drum with sand so it is heavy and the bad guys don't know she's gone.



</question>



<answer from>



Tequila
Member since: 18 June 2007
Total points: 11267 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Books & Authors



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



"When the Drum Sang: An African Folktale" by Anne Rockwell,  New York: Parent's Magazine Press, 1970.
http://ils.unc.edu/~sturm/storytelling/c...
The drum is filled with bees toward the end. The same story and related tales are discussed here:  http://www.loganberrybooks.com/solved-w....
(Scroll down to ""When the Drum Sang".)



The one you described originates in a Bantu, southern-central African tale.



There are several versions.



Another version stemming from Bantu origins: Arnott, Kathleen. "The Singing Drum and the Mysterious Pumpkin." African Myths and Legends. Oxford: Oxford University Press,1962. 179-185.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thank you so much. I have been searching forever for this book!



</asker's comment>

<question from>



Writingg
Member since: 30 July 2008
Total points: 1528 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



I lost my passion for writing!?



I used to write (and read) almost non-stop. Then a bunch of drama happened in my life over the course of 10 years. I'm now 21, and I can't get back to that passion. When I sit down to write, it's literally like I can't even go to that place any more, there's a concrete wall. Absolutely no ideas. Have I lost it forever? What can I do to get it back? When I did write, I'd write for hours, endless and beautiful things... I know if I could just get past this permanent block I'd do good things with my writing. HELP!



</question>



<answer from>



BeautyBl...
Member since: 19 July 2008
Total points: 5011 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



The only cure for writers block is to write.  write ANYTHING.  write in a journal, write what the kids are doing in the street outside your house.  Just write.  Who cares if it's garbage, just write.  It will get you back in the swing of things in no time.  To begin with it's not going to be spectacular and beautiful, it's going to be ugly most likely, but no one has to see it and at least you will be writing.  Eventually your muse will come back.



Write first; leave the judging 'til later~unknown~



He who dares not grasp the thorn should never crave the rose.~Anne Bronte~



We must do the things we think we cannot.~Eleanor Roosevelt~



</answer>



<answer from>



multitas...
Member since: 13 October 2008
Total points: 1851 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



This book is for unblocking creative flow from all types of artists.  I'm a poet and it brought me back, it worked for my music, too.  It's helped a few friends of mine that read the book as well:



"The Artist's Way" by Julia Cameron



Miracle Book, I swear.  Has tasks and things you can do to rid your mind of things that are blocking your creative flow.



Source(s):



A poet.



</answer>



<answer from>



pj m
Member since: 05 March 2007
Total points: 11443 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Books & Authors



</answer from>



<answer>



Writingg,



Sometimes things happen in our lives that are very weighty. It seems the world has settled on our shoulders and no one is around to help bear the burden. The first thing you need to do is get over whatever it is that brought on your 'writers block' caused by a mild case of depression over your predicament. This is more important right now than writing. This is your mind. It needs a rest right now and a way to get over whatever it is that's bothering you.



You're young at 21. You have a long way to go in life and you should look forward instead of backward. Everyone can offer their help here on YA, but you can only really get that help from someone you can reach out and touch. If your problems become that bad, then you need to reach out to one of these people.



Take your time in getting back to writing. It will come.



I wish you well.



PJ M



Source(s):



I've been there and know well how you feel.



</answer>



<answer from>



Wonderco...
Member since: 21 January 2008
Total points: 818 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Remember when you first discovered the magic of writing?  It was when you finished a book that you'd remember forever, wasn't it?  And you said to yourself...I want to be like that one day.



To find that flair again...it's easy.  First, don't think that it's hard to get back or it will be.  It's like jumping from a big rock to the next big rock...if you tell yourself that you might not make it (and you believe that you might not make it) you're going to fall.  You have to know that you're going to make that leap and you're going to be okay.



What happens when we mature is that we become better and better at reading.  We begin to realize that if we read faster...we get to enjoy more stories during our spare time.  This is great, because we get to ride along on another person's adventure...but it sucks, too, because we're conditioning ourselves to go through books as if they're passing by us on an assembly line.



Slow down.  Savor the words of whatever you're reading.  If something tickles your mind in a story that you're reading, go back...read it again.  Taste the words.  Feel them.  Find out why you like the passage so much.



It takes time to write.  Lord, do I know that!  And it's a great injustice when someone comes up to me and tells me - "I read your story in one night!  It was good!"



What?!  It took me six months to write that, and you gobbled it up in a single night?  :(



Think of books like the turkey on Thanksgiving.  It takes hours to cook.  Put all the trimmings with it, and gather your loved ones around.  Nobody wants to see a family tear through a Thanksgiving dinner in record time.  Savor each bite as a rare treat.  That's how you should be reading when you're a writer.  You should pause often and think...that was good, I'm going to turn back a few pages and have seconds and find out why that was so yummy! :b



When you slow down and learn to enjoy the language, you'll start to realize that the same flavors go into your own writing.  It won't be long before you're no longer writing...and literally watching the story unfold for you in your imagination.  Those are the best times! :)



</answer>



<answer from>



kelby_la...
Member since: 13 August 2007
Total points: 9586 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Books & Authors



</answer from>



<answer>



Write about the drama



</answer>

<question from>



Wolf Fang
Member since: 26 April 2008
Total points: 169 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



In the Charlain Harris Sookie Stackhouse series, Who does Sookie end up with at the end?



</question>



<answer from>



Oat
Member since: 19 November 2007
Total points: 4330 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



The series isn't over. The last I heard Charlaine hadn't made and commitments to who Sookie would end up with. In the last book, she broke up with her boyfriend, who was an interesting guy, and Bill and Eric are both still panting after her. Of course, there is also ever loyal Sam. Charlaine once indicated that she didn't really know who Sookie would end up with but that was before the last book came out, maybe she know now, but hasn't shared it with us yet. She likes to let the story evolve. It could be someone we know or haven't even met yet. :P



Personally, I'm rooting for Eric.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



XD! I hope to god she chooses Eric! He's by far my favorite character, lol.



</asker's comment>









<original file>20785.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk111402.txt</current file name>




<category>



Arts & Humanities



Books & Authors



</category>



<question from>



hell raiser9392
Member since: 13 August 2007
Total points: 393 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



From the novel: Pigman; Are John and Lorraine dynamic or Static characters? and why? ?



I need to answer this in a paragraph, but don't know enough information, and don't understand this! Please help!!!!



I need the answer by 8:15 am. thats when we go to class.



</question>



<answer from>



Oat
Member since: 19 November 2007
Total points: 4330 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



You need to ask yourself if they show more than 1 side of their character. Did they learn anything? Did they change at all? Static characters don't change at all, they remain constant. Dymanic characters are like most people, there is more than 1 side to them and they are constantly learning and changing.



As far as John & Lorraine goes, I think they learned a very important lesson in the book. Do you?



</answer>



<asker's comment>



thanks!



</asker's comment>

<original file>21734.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk112457.txt</current file name>




<category>



Arts & Humanities



Books & Authors



</category>



<question from>



ROYA R
Member since: 17 January 2007
Total points: 33 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Please tell me what do these words and sentences mean?



1- what does "convention of genre" mean? "Joyce Carol Oates' prodigious output(Gravedigger's Daughter) has become, these days, almost a convention of the genre." I guess convention and genre has same meaning, is that so?



2- what does "liminal child" mean?"Rebecca is born on the boat in New York harbour; a liminal child, distinguished from her family by the accident of her birth and from her homeland by the outlandishness of her family."
3-Does Hazel Jones have a special meaning?: "Hazel Jones, the name she chooses for her new incarnation, is a distillation of American apple-pie womanhood."
4-what does brought on in no small part mean? does it meant that it appears in so many ways, or appears alot?: "His mental dissolution, brought on in no small part by his loss of status when he reaches the US, is profound and harrowing."
4- what does"unravelling" mean?: "that's much better than being alcoholic, angry and unravelling."
I've translated this interview with Joyce Carol Oates, but I'm not sure about the above words or sentences, so your help will be much appreciated.



http://www.guardian.co.uk/books/2007/sep...



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



1. Convention of genre, standard in the genre.  Meaning that within her genre, this amount of output has become the normal  to expect.



2. liminal, you probably recognize the word  subliminal.  liminal would be overt, noticeable.



3. Jones is a common name and so is Hazel, this is basically saying her new name was like John Smith, a common name for someone of English descent in america.



4. Pull a thread out of your sweater or shirt, keep pulling, that is unravelling.  Here it is used for someone who has a mental state that is frayed, becoming more scattered.



</answer>




<original file>21735.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk112458.txt</current file name>




<category>



Arts & Humanities



Books & Authors



</category>



<question from>



Roper007
Member since: 23 July 2008
Total points: 237 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Has J.R.R Tolkien published a book of poems?



Has he written poems that are well known or published. I am doing a project and i need to pick a author that has written both novels and poems. I know He has written poems but my teacher said he might be hard to do because he doesn't think Tolkien has a published poem book or something along that line.



</question>



<additional details>



And if there are books of peoms that he has written and published or poems that were published, please list them



</additional details>



<answer from>



Sophie B
Member since: 31 January 2007
Total points: 36187 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes.. there are a couple.....



Bilbos last song



The road goes ever on



Lays of Beleriand



</answer>



<answer from>



Samwise
Member since: 01 November 2007
Total points: 10048 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Mathematics



</answer from>



<answer>



There's "The Adventures of Tom Bombadil," which is 16 very short poems. I don't think it's in print, but it has been included in "The Tolkien Reader" for well over three decades, and that appears to be in print.



That volume also includes a play in Anglo-Saxon-style alliterative verse, called "The Homecoming of Beortnoth Beorthelm's Son."



Tolkien also translated some medieval poetry into modern English verse, in print as "Sir Gawain and the Green Knight, Pearl, Sir Orfeo."



Of course, there's considerable poetry mixed in with the various works on Middle-Earth, too.



</answer>

<question from>



iamme
Member since: 22 February 2008
Total points: 51 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



A short story, i need some help?



im writting a short story for school and i needed some help with this project



"What would america be like if they continued udner british rule?"
can anyoen give me some ideas for this question?



</question>



<answer from>



Boomer
Member since: 14 January 2007
Total points: 532 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Well we would have remained governed colonies by the King of England. We would have remained their whipping boy, paying unnecessary taxes on all goods. England would have sent leaders over to govern certain areas of newly colonized land. A lot less freedom basically. Also would have had to sign up for the army to fight for problems not concerning us.A revolution was inevitable.



</answer>



<answer from>



EarthKid...
Member since: 08 May 2007
Total points: 1870 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Would america still have the vast amount of land that it has? Or would other countries such as Spain and France own half of it? Would the mistreatment of native american's continued in the same way? What kind of government would we have? Would we have abolished slavery sooner?



</answer>



<answer from>



Madrock Machina
Member since: 29 October 2008
Total points: 474 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Freedom of Religion.
Your first right under the American constitution. This entitled everyone the freedom to choose WHAT to believe in.
England was forcing everyone, at that time in history, to believe in their religion. The people that became the colonists objected to this religion, and they wanted to believe in their own beliefs (Hence, the Freemasons). This is WHY the constitution is written with "Freedom of Religion" being the very first amendment. So to answer your question: If "the colonies" (by the way, they weren't called America yet) hadn't broken away from England as they did, chances are there would have been an English civil war over religion. Or: everyone who is an English descendant residing in what is now America, would have been Church of England in faith. Also, everyone who has come to America, raised children in America, taken up employment in America, would all have had nowhere to go to because there would be no America.



</answer>

June 2008 Update: In response to the outrageous number of emails that I have received with questions concerning Midnight Sun, I talked to Stephenie this weekend and she asked me to let everyone know that Midnight Sun is her next project. <question>



I need help identifying the title of this short story...?



We read a short story, or an excerpt of a novel or something in middle school, with some really powerful imagery of socialism. In the story there is a beautiful ballerina who is forced to wear a mask, so that she is more equal to the other's whose beauty isn't as great. I think she was also forced to wear weights,because she was an exceptional dancer. Can anyone tell me the name of the story?

Tammish
Member since: 20 October 2008

<question from>



Isabella M.
Member since: 05 November 2008
Total points: 100 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Has anyone read my book "Injustices of a Poetic Soul"? If so, can you please let me know whether you liked it?



I have written a very interesting book based on the trials and tribulations of my life. I have endured many forms of abuse growing up, and I wanted to educate others on the signs of abuse, and ways to acknowledge this. The book is full of poetry and stories explaining the poetry and giving detailed descriptions of all that was endured. I also offer sound advice on self love, self worth, self realization, and empowerment.



I often had hoped to help others who have the same or a similar situation to get through what they have encountered, and to help infuse their innerbeings with courage and love.
I have had little success getting people to buy my book or even give me a chance to make the change that I so hoped I could make.
I take my time out to talk to teenagers and motivate them to do something with their lives. So far I have changed some of their lives for the better, but I need to know what I am doing wrong as far as getting the word out there about my book.
I bust my behind sending copies to various talk show host, posting ads on the internet, handing out flyers and book marks, calling around, giving out free copies, and I even have a book signing event on Nov. 16 at borders.
I am not having any success, but I have spent a lot of money investing into promoting my book, and still I am not having any luck.
I even have a website that I pay for every month with very little visitors (www.injusticesofapoeticsoul.com ). Can someone please offer me some advice if they have any experience in this field. I would greatly appreciate this.



</question>



<answer from>



cathrl69
Member since: 10 July 2007
Total points: 22302 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Uh, does anyone except you think it is remotely interesting, let alone "very interesting"? "Injustices of a Poetic Soul"? How "oh poor abused little me" can you get? Deeply pretentious. What are you doing wrong? You wrote a book nobody wants to read.



We all have lives with trials and tribulations. Not much interested in reading your version, or your platitudes on how I should live, thanks very much. If you want your book to be read, get it published by an actual publisher, not vanity press. If all you want is for it to be available, post it online. Fictionpress.com takes original fiction. But from your description I for one have no interest in even reading it for free, let alone paying to do so.



</answer>

The Love Ninja

<question>



Southern Vampire Series (True Blood)?



I love vampire stories and ive been watching the show on HBO i know they are way more graphic then most but what do u guys think about the books if u read them i was thinking about reading them give me ur thoughts



</question>



<answer from>



Oat
Member since: 19 November 2007
Total points: 4364 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I love the books. They are some of my favorite vampire books. Charlaine Harris has such an interesting voice that comes through in all her works. I simply love her. She has such a nice down, home Southern voice and her Sookie is a lot stronger person than the HBO's Sookie. O, and "down home Southern" doesn't mean absolutely redneck idiots either. Gosh, the way HBO has Jason sound ignorant drives me up the wall.



The books are far superior to the show. Most people who I know that have read the books are pretty annoyed with the show. They have added and changed so much to make 1 book last a full season. Truly, they should have just done 2 books in a season or something.



They have taken some parts of the book that are only a couple sentences and dedicated large parts of several episodes to them, then major parts of the book get glossed over.



Jason's and Sam's characters are also very different. Jason is a male ho in the book, but he wasn't a blood addict or someone who would consider participating in a kidnapping. Sam in the book is pretty much a perfect sweetheart. He isn't at all creepy like they portray him in the show.



I was so thrilled when the series was coming out, but now I'm a bit sick over it.



Plus, in the books you get Bubba. Bubba is totally worth reading them if  you can't find any other reason. :D But I won't spoil him for you.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



thx alot



</asker's comment>

NA7
Member since: 29 September 2008
Total points: 1480 (Level 3)



Contributing In:

</answer from>



<answer>



I read the first three books. They're at least better than the crappy HBO adaption. True Blood is so painful to watch. Disgusting sex scenes and  and strange pacing, along with lame changes... Bill's way of speaking is awkward, Sookie is annoying, and Sam is even MORE annoying than he was in the novels. Ugh, I hate everything about him. The vampire thing seems to be taking a major backseat to a sort of soap plot, with all these characters and their love (sex) lives. It's been a long time since I read any of the books, but I don't remember a lot of what I've seen in the first 5 episodes.



ANYWAYS, I don't see why you wouldn't enjoy the books more than the TV show. They aren't my favorite books by any means, but they're decent enough if you're looking for something in the vampire romance/supernatural genre. (well, not enough to keep me reading, but enough not to regret reading the first few books)



</answer>

<question>



What's the 'YES MAN' 'S story ? ?



tell me about it shortly  ^ ^

</answer from>



<answer>



well, according to Wikipedia, a yes man is . . .



The term "yes man" is typically used for an employee who agrees with every statement of his or her employer.[1] Some synonyms of yes man are flunky, stooge, butt-boy, suck-up, kiss-***, and sycophant; all of which have pejorative connotations.[2] Such a person may also be referred to as a lapdog.[3]



presumably, a "yes man" story refers to a story about a yes man . . .

I always check out SM's website and even planned to buy the bracelet Jacob made for Bella. I was THAT obsessed.

Even back when I loved the book to death, I started to notice how the book keeps going in circles. The fourth book creeped me out when I found out that Jacob fell for a freaking new born!



I waited and waited for a fight when the Volturi showed up, but every thing they worked hard for became useless when someone like Renesmee showed up and said that people like him aren't dangerous.

Bella was so desperate to have sex with Edward!! It's like she's trying to rape the poor guy. For her age and for our generation it's totally okay, but that I think is just a bad influence!



Marriage at 18? Pregnancy at 18? I don't think that's a good thing... Bella is the worst heroine I have ever known.



Edward? Too over protective. Enough said.



I really don't get why SM had to make her vampires sparkly!



She overuses words like velvety and murmurred. It's getting annoying.



Very mary-sueish. Not realistic at all. I know it's in a fantasy genre, but to have a human character- you must at least make some of it believable!



And answer me this... HOW IN THE WORLD COULD BELLA ATTRACT SO MANY GUYS?!?



If she's plain and charmless as what SM initiated in the book, then WHY!? Remember the part when Edward said that he felt as if he needed to fight to date Bella and how she would be surprised at the number of guys she wanted to date?!



Please! SM is trying very hard to get girls hoping when in fact, none of that actually happens.



Dreaming is ok, but too much is very unhealthy!



How could you dream of something so passionately and not do anything about it! This does not comply with desperately praying that the twilight characters would be real!



I honestly don't care what you twilight lovers think. Go love the book for all we Twilight haters care. But we have the same right as to make a site for Twilight haters.

<question>



Is there a book that only talks about death rates and death facts?



if so wats it called



</question>



<answer from>



Kevin k
Member since: 10 October 2006
Total points: 15572 (Level 6)

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



There are several government publications on the mortality rates in any given country.  Contact your state's department of Vital Statistics or the U.S. Census Bureau.  For other countries, try writing the countries' conciliates.



</answer>

<question from>



plethora de sarcasm
Member since: 01 May 2008
Total points: 7816 (Level 5)



</question from>



<question>



Deathly Hallows-Harry/Hermione question?!?



In the new book about the Harry Potter fandom called "Harry: A History" that was released yesterday, J.K. Rowling discussed the relationship between Harry and Hermione - as well as how the Harry Potter films' screenwriter Steve Kloves interpreted it in Deathly Hallows...Here's what she said:



Quote:
"I tried very hard to soften it, I suppose," Jo said. "Just because someone had a view on Harry/Hermione didn't mean they weren't genuine, or that they were necessarily misguided. In fact, I will say this, Steve Kloves who has been the script writer [on the Potter films], who is enormously insightful on the series and a very good friend, after he read book seven he said to me, 'You, know, I thought something was going to happen between Harry and Hermione, and I didn't know whether I wanted it or not.'



"I had always planned that Harry's true soul mate, which I stand by, is Ginny, and that Ron and Hermione have this combative but mutual attraction. They will always bicker, there will always be rough edges there, but they are pulled together, each has something the other needs."



I stared at her, sensing she wasn't finished, and a sense of foreboding crept in around the edges.



"[Kloves] felt a certain pulll between them at that point. And I think he's right. There are moments when [Harry and Hermione] touch, which are charged moments. One when she touches his hair as he sits on the hiltop reading about Dumbledore and Grindelwald, and [two] the moment when they walk out of the graveyard with their arms around each other."



I was holding my breath at this point. She wasn't done.



"Now the fact is that Hermione shares moments with Harry that Ron will never be able to participate in. He walked out. She shared something very instense with Harry.



"So I think it could have gone that way."



DID ANY HARRY POTTER FANS PICK UP ON THIS? I did notice something, but I still just saw as the brother/sister relationship. I can't believe JK Rowling said that something actually could've happened...maybe all the Harry/Hermione shippers weren't so off the mark after all.



: P



</question>



<answer from>



hpotterf...
Member since: 20 April 2006
Total points: 411 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I am doing a reread/listening to the audio book right now, and I'm just at the part where Ron is about to come back so this is all fresh in my mind.  Yes, I see it.  When they are alone together for so long, there are moments where they touch or hold hands or they seem almost like a couple.  If Ron and Ginny weren't in the back of their minds for that whole time I think it could easily have gone another way.  The stupidest thing Ron could have done was leave them alone together like that.  But he wouldn't be Ron if he did the smart thing very often.  I'm glad it turned out the way it did.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



I completely agree with you. I think that's exactly what JK Rowling meant...that if Hermione and Harry weren't so invested in other people then something could have happened. And you don't even have to tell me how dumb Ron can be. lol. thank goodness he finally came to his senses at the end.



</asker's comment>

genev!ev...
Member since: 07 July 2007
Total points: 605 (Level 2)

I was always a Harry/Ginny shipper, but of course there'll be Harry/Hermione moments, because, like Jo said, Ron walked out. So they still are hormonal (though on a different scale) teens with needs. So... something could've happened...



</answer>

<question from>



Jessica O
Member since: 05 November 2008
Total points: 99 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Should books be banned?



</question>



<answer from>



Merci, Tourterelle
Member since: 11 July 2008
Total points: 9043 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Books & Authors



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Absolutely not.



I think individuals have the right to choose what books they want to read, and to limit those choices because of content is completely wrong.  Besides, the First Amendment states "no law shall be made abridging the freedom of speech."  Banning books does not fit in with the First Amendment! Really, people who think books should be banned because of language content should just avoid the book; they can't ban others from reading it, though!



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thankyou for answering my question.It helped me greatly!:]



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Huntress...
Member since: 13 February 2008
Total points: 1330 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I don't think books should ever be banned.  People as a whole have the right to CHOOSE to read or Not to read a book. If its banned then that choice is taken from them. Even school right now allow students to substitute books from the required reading list if parents have a problem with them..
No one forces you to read anything, its a choice and in my opinion that choice is a right!.



</answer>

<question from>



Isabella
Member since: 03 November 2008
Total points: 215 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What is the theme of Jane Austen's Pride and Prejudice?



I have to write an essay tomorrow and I need to know the theme and plot detail. Any help would be greatly appreciated.
Thank you!



</question>



<additional details>



yes thank you i know the themes are pride and prejudice. (duh!) but i mean a sentence! like for Lord of the Flies it would be "when people are in a situation where there is no civilization they feel the need to establish structure and organization." I need a general non specific thematic statement :) thanks!



</additional details>



<answer from>



Bells*
Member since: 21 March 2008
Total points: 3550 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Well, lets see, what would be the theme of Pride & Prejudice...thats a tough one.  Maybe freaking PRIDE & PREJUDICE.  you dolt.



Lizzy is very proud, and her first impression of Darcy is her only one, and it gets worse, until he proposes to her the first time, then it gets better when she goes to his Pemberly estate.



Darcy is the prejudiced one, he doesnt like Lizzy because he thinks her family laughs too much, and her family (other than Jane) is rude and uncouth.  He loves Liz against his better judgement, and he thinks hes doing her a favour by proposing.  He saves Lydia and Jane with Bingly after, and he does it for Liz.  He loves her enough to save her family, after shes denied him, and he he says he will still love her if she denies him again, but he will keep quiet.



Both characters are so alike, although their reasonings are opposite, but that is only because both of them got their stories wrong, Darcy got Jane and Bingly all screwed up, and Liz thought Darcy was terrible to Wickham, when that wasnt what happened.  They are both very passionate people.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Even though you were kind of rude, thank you for giving me a long, well written, accurate answer. (and thanks for answering my question!) :)



</asker's comment>

Then I found out his whole family were space aliens. I got over him.Then Obsert came back and we got married, did it, and had our baby, Rambemo. <question>



Books To Read In A Life Time?



list any books you think should be read before you die!



</question>



<answer from>



Glitter-...
Member since: 14 December 2006

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>

Charlotte Brontë, To Kill a Mockingbird... Harper Lee, Great Expectations... Charles Dickens, Charlie And The Chocolate Factory... Roald Dahl, The Great Gatsby... F Scott Fitzgerald, Alice's Adventures In Wonderland... Lewis Carroll, Of Mice And Men... John Steinbeck, Memoirs Of A Geisha... Arthur Golden, Midnight's Children... Salman Rushdie, Londonstani... <asker's comment>



very informative



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Mike
Member since: 23 April 2008
Total points: 1049 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Books to read in a life time?  Now there's a thought!  It depends of course, on you, your tastes, your course of study, your career, etc.



What is right for one person, would be different for another!  What is true universally, however, is that any list today, would be different tomorrow!  Knowledge is added to hour by hour, day by day, and thus your list will expand accordingly.



Any well-written book, read and understood, will contribute to the sum of learning that you will carry around in your head, and your interpretation of what is important in life.



So I would say this: read, enjoy and travel the river of knowledge wherever it takes you!  Bon voyage!



</answer>



<answer from>



shockey_...
Member since: 17 April 2006
Total points: 384 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



The Day of the Jackal by Frederick Forsyth
Eyes of The Dragon by Steven King (not his usual horror stuff)
The Art of Zen and Motorcycle Repair (forgot the author, sorry)



Also try to read somethings outside your normal realm of experience.  Pick up a true crime book written by a cop, or a mafia member. Read about the darker side of real life.  Read about places that you will never get to go yourself and broaden your life on the experiences of others.  Read a fiction/fantasy novel and discover places that exist only in the movie of the mind.  I do hope the "before you die" in the question is not urgent, best of luck.  The important thing to do is just to read something... and enjoy it.  Just because it is on a best seller list doesn't make it good.



</answer>

<answer from>



MMM
Member since: 30 March 2006
Total points: 2424 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I am very widely read in not only regular classic literature, but also in a lot of popular contemporary authors.  I am sort of a sci-fi, fantasy, horror buff.  Here's my list from that point of view because I think you'll get a lot of Shakespeare, Dickens, and Tolstoy from everyone else.  These are just plain fun to read and hang the snobbish fascination with the classics:



"Ender's Game" by Orson Scott Card
Sci Fi/Fantasy Hugo/Nebula Awards, I recommend this book to everyone.  My sons love it.  (Anyone who has ever been a "gamer" will appreciate this book.)



Any book by Anne McCaffrey (but especially "Crystal Singer".) Sci Fi/Fantasy Hugo/Nebula Awards, This is probably my favorite and the most prolific author on this list--she's written at least 25-30 books, every single one has made the bestseller's lists.  Great message and great characters.



"The Earth's Children" Series by Jean Auel (Historical Fiction)  Those legions of us who are die-hard fans of this series are keeping our fingers crossed that she completes the final book in this series before she dies--she's been writing them for several decades now--very slow (usually 6-7 years between books) but unbelievably intricate and detailed author.  These are pretty thick though--you'd better really like to read to take these on!



"The Darwath Trilogy" by Barbara Hambly (all NYTimes bestsellers--sort of Horror/SciFi.)  She has also written several other very very good books.



All Tolkien--this really is a must:  The original Fantasy Classic.



"Mists of Avalon" by Marion Zimmer Bradley (exceptional re-telling of the King Arthur story from a woman's perspective.)



Enjoy!



Source(s):



My book filled life.



</answer>



<answer from>



Bill C
Member since: 24 August 2006
Total points: 4742 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Books by Piers Anthony, Douglas Adams, Roger Zelasney, J.K. Rowling, J.R.R. Tolkien, Garth Nix, read Little Women, Tom Sawyer, Romeo & Juliet, Taming of the Shrew, Ten Little Indians, read everything pertaining to Mythology and the Greek and Roman Gods.  Read biographys of anyone you feel is important, like Einstein, Lenin, Chruchill, Ronald Regan, Marilyn Monroe, Ted Williams, and definitely read about Mr. Kellogg, the founder of the known cereal, or Henry Ford, the founder of the auto construction line.



Whatever you do, read.  Whether it's a book or on the internet.  I've found it so disappointing when I see a 2nd or 3rd grade child who doesn't yet know how to read.



</answer>

<answer>



Everyone should read, but what should they read depends on what they believe. If you're religious, the Bible is a must read. <answer>



Obviously these are my favourites, but I also think that people should read them for fun, information, and just to experience great british literature



for fun:
any of the terry pratchett discworld series.. I would recommend "Guards, Guards"  - the first one in the ankh morpork city guard series



for Information:
'Why People believe weird things' by Michael Shermer... pretty much does what it says on the tin



For beautiful literature:



'Under milk wood' by Dylan Thomas -  a wonderful look at a day in the life of a small town in Wales



also, 'The canterbury tales' just for the sheer joie de vivre and insight into the common man, in medieval britain.
at one time I used to pick up a copy and have a look every springtime.... "when april with her showers sweet, hath pierced the drought of march to the root"



</answer>

Jackie Brown
Member since: 13 March 2007
Total points: 3239 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



1. The Complete Works of Edgar Allan Poe
2. The Complete Works of Jane Austen
3. All (7) Harry Potter books by J. K. Rowling
4. "The Lord of the Rings Trilogy" by J.R.R. Tolkien
5. "Atlas Shrugged" by Ayn Rand
6. "To Kill A Mockingbird" by Harper Lee
7. Anything and everything by Gabriel Garcia Marquez (One Hundred Years of Solitude, Love in the Time of Cholera, his short stories, etc...)
8. The poetry of Robert Frost - any of it.



9. The Bible
10. "His Dark Materials" Trilogy by Phillip Pullman
11. "Alice's Adventures in Wonderland" and "Through the Looking Glass" by Lewis Carroll
12. "Atonement" by Ian McEwan
13. "Harold and the Purple Crayon" by Crockett Johnson
14. "The Bell Jar" by Sylvia Plath
15. "How I Became Stupid" by Martin Page
16. "The Catcher in the Rye" by J.D. Salinger
17. "The Metamorphosis" by Franz Kafka
18. "The Chronicles of Narnia" Series by C.S. Lewis
19. "More Than A Carpenter" by Josh McDowell
20. "Romeo and Juliet" and "As You Like It" by William Shakespeare
21. "The Shawshank Redemption" (and many others) by Stephen King
22. "On the Road" by Jack Kerouac
23. "Tender is the Night" by F. Scott Fitzgerald
24. "The Little Prince" by Antoine de Saint-Exupéry
25. "East of Eden" by John Steinbeck
26. "Breakfast of Champions" by Kurt Vonnegut
27. "The Alchemist" by Paulo Coelho
28. "The Giver" by Lois Lowry



Sorry - can you tell I LOVE to read! All of these I chose for a reason. Some are well-known classics, some are not. But I love all of them, and they have all taught me something, or just plain entertained the hell out of me.



Enjoy!



</answer>

<answer>



Yes, War and Peace--I know someone said it, but I'm refuting it. And it is Tolstoy's best book.
now, Irving Stone has a lot of good books but his two best(that I have read) are
The Agony and the Ecstasy~about Michaelangelo
Love is Eternal~about Mary Todd Lincoln
The Hobbit and Lord of the Rings--the books are amazing!!
Any Redwall book, little talking mice and badgers:)
and maybe Hacking Harvard. ok, it's not a classic. ok, you're going to find it in the young adult section, if you find it at all. But I loved it; it's about love and college and pushy parents, but it's funny too, and you can always pick it up.

<answer from>



Brownsug...
Member since: 17 June 2007
Total points: 141 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



You should read Coldest Winter Ever
The Coldest Winter Ever by Sister Souljah is a thoroughly engrossing, simply riveting book that I am very happy to have read. It is like a tell-all story from an urban teenaged girl's point-of-view. From the drug life to the privileged life, the story takes you on a journey that you will never forget. There's so much that can be said about this book, but I'll start with the main character Winter. This girl is sooo real, so authentic that I wondered "Who is Winter? Where is she?" SHE EXISTS out there somewhere. Sister Souljah did an excellent job characterizing Winter as well as the others (Midnight, Lauren, Santiaga, etc.). The way the story was written you were allowed to know Winter's every thought, whether you agreed with those thoughts or not. Winter was defined by what happened to her and how she reacted to the things that she experienced (mother's accident, father's jailing, being forced to live among strangers, lack of money, love for money...). And the plot had many twists and turns, shockers and laughs. My favorite line is "Bounce, *****," which is what Winter said to a 'white man'. It was hilarious. Overall, I loved the story, the writing, the character, and some of the messages conveyed in this piece of work. It is highly recommended..



</answer>



<answer from>



Annie
Member since: 24 May 2008
Total points: 1721 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>

The Lusiads by Luiz de Camões it's a great book, too. Camões tells the History of Portugal mixed with some mythology. It's poetry. It's divine.

<question>

I heard that he would staple or somehow make all these pages on big long massive page, put it in his typewriter and just write for hours in stream of conscious style, probably heavily drinking at the same time.
I wanted to know his name and book, I'm really interested in the idea.
Can anyone help?
Thanks.



</question>



<additional details>



I already knew about the Naked Lunch and look forward to reading it, but it's James Joyce. Thanks, I guess I was right about the drinking heavily thing..



</additional details>

<question>



I am reading the Catcher in the Rye and I need to indentify three places in the book where Holden acts mature.?



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



In the bar, where he pretends to be a grown up so he can get a drink.. he always gets a drink there since he's so tall and he doesn't look like a minor.



Also, i think it was almost in the last part, when he was talking to his baby sister.. when he said he wants to be the catcher in the rye.. that was pretty mature..



i can't remember any other place, though.. maybe his conversation with his old professor in the professor's house, maybe that's mature already..



</answer>
