<question>



The sun watches...poem...any good?



the sun shines in the sky
looking down upon the earth
watching the people
who inhabit this land
the people who fight
the wars that they start
the death that they cause



how can the sun bear to watch us kill each other?
how can the sun bear to watch the misery?
how can the sun bear to watch the disease?
the plague which has spread across the earth?



The moon comes,



here to relieve the sun,
to give old yellow a rest
the moon watches too,
with a half eye or a full,
the moon sees, the stars see



Will the people of the earth
ever lay to rest
all the conflicts,
all the fighting,



all the bloodshed,
the unkindness committed upon one another?



The day the sun watches,
the night the moon comes,
and the stars shine,
they are bright, brighter than before
bright the time the people stop,
bright with joy,
bright with peace.



i made that up as i went along...
unedited, i just felt like writing another poem...
i think i have poem fever =)
anyway, constructive criticism would be appreciated =D



</question>



<additional details>



star please?



</additional details>



<answer from>



Nico
Member since: 05 November 2008
Total points: 138 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yer man your really good i think you should keeep going with your poetry you will go far good luck



hope i helped



Nico=]



</answer>

Josh C

<answer>



In literary terms, it sucks. Horribly written, poorly executed, and doesn't hold a candle to Tolkien or Lewis. Not even to J.K. Rowling.



But if you like vampires, teen drama, and sparkly things, go for it.



</answer>



<answer from>



savanah smiles
Member since: 02 November 2008
Total points: 227 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



It seems to be the national craze. I, on the other hand, hated it. The writing is simplistic and - for lack of better word - just plain bad. Stephenie Meyer isn't as developed as she should be. She has a decent imagination, but in my opinion the story line is too likely.



Who knows. That may be your thing.



</answer>

<answer from>



astra.ma...
Member since: 07 August 2008
Total points: 523 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I think it depends on what you read.



I mean if you loved Meg Cabot's Princess Diaries and Boy meets Girl, seriously, GO FOR TWILIGHT.



But if you're more literary, Jodi Picoult, Margaret Mitchell, Salinger etc, Twilight is SO not the book for you.



Basically, I think its a book for regular, hormonal teen girls so they can fall head over heels for Edward Cullen.



</answer>



<answer from>



ella
Member since: 09 December 2007
Total points: 935 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



It is an enjoyable read. That is, if you like teen romance, where the heroine is in love with two guys who are enemies with each other. And then there's the hot vampire as a hero. Really, I think it's him that is the main attraction of the book. Without the hero Edward, the book wouldn't be that good.



But I wouldn't call it great and I wouldn't say that it's "the best book ever" like a lot of people say. Why? The plot is not exactly something so different. It's not really a great love story either. The narration is ok. The characters are also ok, except for the hero. The love relationship between the hero and heroine... well, I've read books with better romance.



If you're into romance, then you could try it and see for yourself. Overall, I think it's the 1st and 3rd book are enjoyable. But I wouldn't call the whole series great. But it's all a matter of opinion.



Edit: Hey, I agree with Kady (person below me), except about New Moon. New Moon  sucks! The mood of the book is overall depressing. I get depressed reading it. And there's not much going on in it either.



</answer>



<answer from>



Kady
Member since: 05 November 2008
Total points: 100 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Twilight (the first novel) is brilliant. It takes you into an great fantasy of vampires in human life and gives you a good perspective of a forbidden love between mortal and immortal. The characters are well written, their thoughts are original and the quirky banter between Edward and Bella is great to read. I love it heaps. 10/10
New Moon (the second novel) - Not quite as spectacular. If you read a few times, you can appreciate what Stephenie Meyer is trying to do with her characters, though at times it seems out of place the way she is throwing them around. Though it gives you a new perspective on Edward and Bella's romantic relationship and sheds light on the vampire world. Bella starts becoming annoying. 7.5/10
Eclipse (the third novel) - Worse than New Moon. Stephenie Meyer is once again trying to be creative with her vampire world and stretching a few boundaries.  Bella is edging over irritating. 6.5/10
Breaking Dawn - An absolute catastrophe. Stephenie Meyer has run out of ideas and stretches the limits of her vampire world to beyond breaking point. Characters and not recognisable and Bella becomes extremely hatable. It wasn't well thought out or written. Stephenie seemed to be in a rush to brush off the final novel. She wrapped up the series rashly and ended up losing the plot. 2/10



I think you should get Twilight and New Moon for starters. If you're brave, get the rest. :)



Source(s):



Personal Opinion



</answer>



<answer from>



Proud Twilighter!!
Member since: 26 October 2008
Total points: 123 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



the best novel that EVER came on the face of this earth



</answer>

<question from>



Lexie =]
Member since: 29 October 2007

</question from>



<question>



If you read 1984...help meeee!?



Can you answer these question?
Did Winston receive a better or worse treatment in the Ministry of Love? Describe the relationship between Smith and O'Brien. Why was Smith allowed to go in his heresy for so many years? Why did they let him go in the end?



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



oh i read this 2 terms ago for an assignment....must have been one of the worst and confusing books ive read, sorry. Winston was brainwashed in the minisrtry of love so in a way he recieved a better treatment. But he was going to die anyway, at the end of the book...Oh dam this second question I had to respond to in an exam....ok... well put simply the relatioship was a father-son relationship...This is because we are seen to believe that O'Brien can see how Smith's mind works and he is seen to be a fatherly image by cradling Smith in his arms after torturing him...As for the final answer I guess the party watched so many of these people and studied them so that they can improve on the welfare of the party...sorta like lab mice really.... Hope that answers your question/s..if not good luck in trying to find a solution



Source(s):



1984



</answer>

<question>



What specially stands out for you in Agatha Christie novels?



Why do you like Christie?



</question>



<answer from>



deepred
Member since: 22 July 2008
Total points: 3096 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



the racism, the bourgeois attitudes, the inane writing, the anachronistic values. Avoid Agatha.



</answer>



<answer from>



mirzhila
Member since: 17 April 2008
Total points: 1317 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Madam marpel.



</answer>



<answer from>



Digirb
Member since: 24 April 2007
Total points: 4172 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



The characters are amazing!  I also love the twists and turns in the plots.  It's interesting to read the books in order and see the progression of 20th century society in her lifetime.  I understand the problems with classism, sexism, etc, but each book is a reflection of what was really going on at the time it was written.  It's better than a history book!



</answer>



<answer from>



Poe Bird
Member since: 15 November 2007
Total points: 2079 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I think she was a stand alone when she first started writing. I know they seem a bit cheesy compared to today's standard, but today's standard will become yesterdays and so forth. They were simple, well written, and the better ones did leave you guessing. For some reason they're just a good read, something to take with you anywhere.



</answer>

<answer from>



what do dogs do to wolves?
Member since: 13 June 2007
Total points: 1852 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Bella's body, streaming with red, started to twitch, jerking around in Rosalie's arms like she was being electrocuted. All the while, her face was blank – unconscious.
It was the wild thrashing from inside the center of her body that moved
her. As she convulsed, sharp snaps and cracks kept time with the spasms.

...

Another shattering crack inside her body, the loudest yet, so loud that we both froze in shock waiting for her answering shriek. Nothing. Her legs, which had been curled up in agony, now went limp, sprawling out in an unnatural way.

"Her spine," he choked in horror.



Source(s):



Breaking Dawn, book 2, chapter 18



</answer>



<answer from>



Cassie M
Member since: 04 August 2008
Total points: 134 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



There is a big controversy over Breaking Dawn and the Twilight series. The Media Center at my school does not have these books because the relationship between Edward and Bella is so intense. They don't want kids to feel that their relationships need to be like that. In New Moon, the sequel to Twilight, Edward leaves and Bella's life is turned upside down. She gets depressed and won't eat. She has screaming nightmares. They don't want kids to feel that way. Also, the book is a bit racey in the beginning when Edward and Bella go on a honeymoon.



</answer>



<answer from>



I LUV HARRY POTTER MORE THAN U!!
Member since: 30 December 2006
Total points: 573 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



for me there was nothing bad about it. I loved it entirely. everything. Sometimes it seemed a bit out of character but you have to realize Bella changed and so did Edward. they are married now and some of the boundaries and safeties were going to be crossed. I thought it was amazing. I liked everything about it and I used to hate Jacob. But now I have a new found respect for him and even liking. Most people didn't seem to like it because they have narrow closed minds and if something doesn't happen like THEY expect it to, the book automatically sucks. I found the book very interesting and intriguing. I loved it.



</answer>

<question from>



metallic...
Member since: 03 July 2008
Total points: 481 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Can somebody suggest me some horror books please.?



Thanks!



</question>



<answer from>



Artemis
Member since: 21 September 2006
Total points: 12039 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Drama



Other - Television



Movies



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Try some of James Herbert's books.  He is the best horror writer around at the moment in my opinion.  His books can be quite dark and twisted but they are genuinely good & creepy horror novels.

He wrote a trilogy of books about Rats & they are probably some of his most chilling novels.  They are called 'Rats', 'Lair' & 'Domain'.
I found 'Domain' to be the most creepy of the three novels because it is set in London in the aftermath of a nuclear attack & while the idea of bloodthirsty mutant rats might not sound very plausible - the events following the nuclear attack are very scary because they really are quite plausible.

'The Ghosts of Sleath' is very good and very chilling - at one point when I was reading this book I actually shivered with fear.

'The Fog' is also very good but one of the more twisted of James Herbert's novels.



'Once' is a bit off the wall - it's about evil fairies, goblins & sprites.  It's like the antithesis of a fairytale.

'Haunted' is the first novel I read by James Herbert and one of my favourites.  It's almost like an old fashioned ghost story in a huge haunted house.  It's excellent.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks i am going to go and check his books out.

are they hard to read?



</asker's comment>

<question>



What does a story outline looks line?



Can someone give me a detailed example/sample of what a Story Outline should look like?



</question>



<answer from>



Elektris...
Member since: 21 March 2008
Total points: 6722 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



http://www.readwritethink.org/lesson_ima...



Source(s):



7th grade English



</answer>



<answer from>



BrittUhN...
Member since: 23 February 2008
Total points: 1399 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



It could be anything, there are many outlines. You could have a web where you have a circle in the middle, and then bubbles coming out. Or you could do this:

Chapter 1- (Title)
a. Detail
b. Detail
c. Detail

You could also just write down your ideas, brainstorm, that's all a story outline.



Source(s):



The Web Outline
http://www.do2learn.com/libraryimages/pa...

The Chapter 1, detail detail detail
https://www.msu.edu/course/cep/886/Readi...

Another Web
http://www.sccs.swarthmore.edu/users/99/...

You can also use websites to store your ideas, one I know of is wridea.com. Some other writing sites that I have heard of let you share stories with other people, write down notes, ideas, etc.
http://wridea.com/



</answer>

<question>



Best villain of any book/movie/tv series?



Who and why, best argument wins.



</question>



<answer from>



anon25
Member since: 21 March 2008
Total points: 780 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Argh - really hard choice. My top three in no particular order are:

Gul Dukat from Star Trek Deep Space Nine:
I don't think of him as being completely evil through and through ... He can be charming. He can be generous. He can do the right thing. All of that somehow makes his 'evil' actions all the more despicable, because we know that there was the potential in there for him to be a better person. He's so versatile, you see the best of him, the worst of him.

Steerpike from Gormenghast:
He's chilling and cunning and downright manipulative. He manages to almost take over an entire kingdom, all through the powers of persuasion. He would have gotten away with it completely if he had been quicker off the mark killing flay.

Patrick Bateman from American Psycho (book not pile of sh1te movie):
He gets away with it all, he knows why he does it, because he is completely unhinged, but at the same time, he just wants to fit in. The guy is a master.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



So many great answers from everyone but your Gul Dukat answer sold it for me.  He's not only my favourite villain of all time, but you summed him up perfectly.  I might check out Gormenghast based on your recommendation.

<answer>



Okay, I just watched War with Jet Li in it. He's like the hero slash villian so he's more anti hero.



What did I love about him? What did I love about him? Oh my gosh, I was rooting for him even though I was supposed to be rooting for the good guy! He was the most awesome, greatest villian ever!! He killed ruthlessly. Okay, what I hate is when they say "any last words" and take such a long time to kill the hero because, let's face it, reality doesn't work like that. If someone wants to get rid of you they don't wait it out until you have a chance to escape.



That is so friggin' stupid when they do that. Jet Li didn't do that. Nope. Not at all. He didn't really talk throughout the movie but he beat EVERYONE'S butt even the good guy. He was the silent killer. The quick and clean killer. He was the best villian EVER!! If I were to ever write a book with a villian that great, I sure hope my readers enjoy it the way I enjoyed the movie.



He just went in there with a clean cut suit and three seconds later he came out and behind him were a bunch of bodies. No screaming. No stupid "any last words" and definitely no struggles. And not a drop of blood on his suit. It was AWESOME!!

It sounds completely evil, but we're talking about villians here.



</answer>

<answer>



first prize goes to gollum from lord of the rings. i just love this guy! you can find yourself pitying him because of all that he's gone through, (just like frodo) but then he does something awful (i.e. betraying frodo to be eaten by a giant spider) because the lure of the Ring is too strong and he has no will left. He's just such a shaded character...he's a great literary creation. he's my PRECIOUS!!!

second prize goes to the joker from the dark knight. he's just insane and hilarious in a sadistic sort of way...and he's just so much fun to watch. you're always guessing what kind of weird stunt he's going to pull next. why so serious?



third prize goes to darth vader. he's just iconic. every time i see empire strikes back, all i'm waiting for is the 'luke, i am your father!' scene. and he has the awesome voice and the breathing...but in the prequel you see that he really was a nice guy, and actually went bad with good intentions, and so he does have a redeeming quality, which makes him even cooler than he was as a dark lord who was just evil because he was. the dark side conquers all!

actually, these are all so great, i like them all equally. they all get golds!!!

*celebrindal*

<answer from>



Fortunat...
Member since: 18 July 2008
Total points: 349 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Mrs. Coulter from 'His Dark Materials'!! She is undoubtedly the best "villain" in children's literature anyway.

Two (main) reasons why:

It's incredibly important not to depict a character as purely evil (as the majority of the "villains" offered here are) because life isn't black and white and "evil" is subjective. Mrs. Coulter, while being power-hungry, selfishly cruel, and insensitive, is genuinely a loving mother and ultimately sacrifices herself for her daughter. Her character is so rich and layered and nuanced that our reception of her changes with every page. She is totally unpredictable, and we feel she may turn upon and viciously murder Lyra at any moment.

Mrs. Coulter is unspeakably beautiful. She exudes charm, glamour, and luxury, yet beneath this we detect something cold, powerful, dangerous and extremely unnerving. This is yet another important portrayal: beauty does not correspond with goodness, and ugliness does not correspond with evil. Too many villains, and a glance at the comments here speaks volumes, are ugly and repulsive while the central and "good" characters are healthily attractive. Again, life is not like this, and it is misleading and dangerous to depict it as such.

Mrs. Coulter! Woop woop.



</answer>



<answer from>

Member since: 11 August 2008
Total points: 221 (Level 1)

dalia a

<answer>



Ok, the numbers are for words
10,000-40,000 - Novella
Over 40,000 constitutes a "novel." However, 40,000-60,000 - Novelette or "Novel Lite"
60,000 and up - Novel

I think the last thing in your mind should be what to call it (novel, novella, etc.) but to produce something you love.



</answer>



<answer from>



harlequi...
Member since: 02 August 2008
Total points: 148 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



The edges between short story, novella, and novel can get blurry. But generally, a short story runs up to 60 pages; a novella, between 60-120; and a novel, 120 or more. Those numbers are completely subjective, but they're good ballpark figures.



</answer>



<answer from>

<answer from>



goldie

<answer>



This ? shows up on here as frequently as Twilight questions!  If you're going to be a "real" writer you need to go to a library & skim their section on writing.  Trust me, there won't be many.  While there look @ Writer's Market that lists all the current publishers.  Ignore those sections--you're not ready for them,  Do read their articles & learn about novellas,novels, etc.  Then go to a good bookstore & start buying for your personal library.  There will be books that have answers for the beginning writer & books by authors who give good advice & encouragement (Stephen King & Natalie Goldberg are 2 examples).



Get books on punctuation, spelling, grammar.  Don't forget a good thesarus & dictionary.  Sound expensive?  Ask yourself if writing is a hobby that you can post on here for anyone to claim, or is it a career?  I'm betting you want a career.Best of luck.



</answer>



<answer from>



natalie nkay
Member since: 17 July 2008
Total points: 126 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



It really doesn’t matter how many pages. A 700 pages Harry Potter is as enjoyable as a 150 pages Marquez. The length of your novel depends on how you want to tell your story. True that some people don’t like novels that look underfed but there are others who avoid books that look obese. It doesn’t matter- don’t go by length. As long as you have a story that connects with your reader, as long as your narrative can enthrall him and keep him wanting to turn the pages, you know you have written a successful novel. All the best!



</answer>



<answer from>



Sela C
Member since: 22 June 2008
Total points: 2928 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Books & Authors



</answer from>



<answer>



It's actually a good question. Especially if you aim to be published. There are rules, people. A select few get to break them, but not many. If your publisher states they want novels of 85-100K, then that's what they want. 5K one way or the other is no big deal. 20K? Big deal.

As lovely as it is to say, write until it's done, that only gets you to the rough draft. If you want to sell it, then you need to step up to the line and do the hard work, which means expanding or cutting.

I say this as someone who writes novellas. Believe me, word count is an issue.

Chapters should all be roughly the same length. In shorter works, 10-15 pages. In a novel, if you aim for around 20, you'll be fine. Again, a few pages here or there isn't going to make a huge difference, but balance is good. In other words, no 3 page chapters followed by 50 page chapters.

Typical, mainstream, genre fiction novels run between 80K-120K, depending on genre and publisher requirements.

We do count in words, rather than pages. That means that you have to have your work formatted so that we're all on the same page (Look! A pun!)

Courier New 12
Double spaced
1" margins all around

That'll show you how many pages you have. Figure 250 words per page and you'll know how many words you have. A 100K novel is about 400 ms (manuscript) pages.



Source(s):



Published author



</answer>

<answer>



The first of the series is "The Wizard of Oz" and the characters are Dorohty, the Tin Man, the Cowardly Lion and the Scarecrow.

The author is L. Frank Baum.

He wrote a whole bunch of Oz books.  here they are:

[edit] Oz works
Main: List of Oz books

The Wonderful Wizard of Oz (1900) 
The Marvelous Land of Oz (1904) 
Ozma of Oz (1907) 
Dorothy and the Wizard in Oz (1908) 
The Road to Oz (1909) 
The Emerald City of Oz (1910) 
The Patchwork Girl of Oz (1913) 
Tik-Tok of Oz (1914) 
The Scarecrow of Oz (1915) 
Rinkitink in Oz (1916) 
The Lost Princess of Oz (1917) 
The Tin Woodman of Oz (1918) 
The Magic of Oz (1919, posthumously published) 
Glinda of Oz (1920, posthumously published) 
Queer Visitors from the Marvelous Land of Oz (1905) 
The Woggle-Bug Book (1905) 
Little Wizard Stories of Oz (1913)



</answer>

<answer>

CALDWOOD
Member since: 06 June 2008
Total points: 695 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



"All the Pretty Horses" is a great book but they made a very weak movie from it. There are a lot of reasons, but here are some of the major ones. In the book, John Grady Cole is 16 and leaves home in with his 17 year old friend in 1949 on horseback headed into Mexico. There they get jobs on big ranch and John Grady falls in love with Alejandra (17) and they make love. John Grady is taken to prison where, in defending himself he kills a man. He then gets out of prison, is shot, but nonetheless rides back to Texas by himself. That's a heck of a lot and very heroic for a 16 year old. But in the movie, they made him 27 and the girl too and what's all that great about people that age having sex etc. Plus, in the book, the courtship between the guy and girl goes on for a lot of pages, so you can see their love and desire build until they are overcome by it, but in the movie they just jump in bed with little build up or explanation for what they see in each other.



Source(s):



I've read the book three times and seen the movie twice.



</answer>



<answer from>

Member since: 05 July 2006

<answer>



"The Bone Collector" by Jeffrey Deaver

Before I start, let me say that I like all of the actors involved, just not the casting of the roles!

Denzel Washington is not an older, white man (Lincoln Rhyme).  Queen Latifah is not a gay man (Lincoln's assistant).



Angelina Jolie is/was not a red head (Amelia Sachs).  They followed plot devices, but not the characters.  These characters are part of a series of books.  They aren't just throw-aways.  You read the books for the characters, not just the plot twists.



</answer>

<question>



Need help with a title for my story



The legend of the Golden Light of LOTGA, many years ago in between the golden ages. There lived a huge city know as Braveture where people’s lives were in peace with the animals, nature and even their fellow people who live apart of the great city. Until the day of Summoning Lord- it’s a special time when all of the people, are thankful to their lord LOTGA in the sun-dawn temple. It was also known as a time of sharing, playing and even the joyfulness in life it’s self, but when there’s light, darkness will follow. 
A young man whom always hated the city and was set to destroy life, as we know today.

And then the day of Sorrow Cry was upon them; it was the huge down fall of the beautiful city and gaining unlimited power and life. The greed of ruling the whole world itself, then out of the blue a young child facing the deepest of fears, to come front him. Through out the horrible battle the child summoned LOTGA to seal the dark soul away forever, as faith would known it, the child give their life as a prise of sealing him forever and scattering five pieces of the Golden Light’s power around the lands called Cloridmay.

A Tale of their future from LOTGA say: “Darkness will rise from JTA seal and will try again to gain even more power, along with Thee marked child…”
“Thee who has the mark of LOTGA will rise to call, when time is needless and followers bond, Thee who will be our saver of Braveture…”

And so peace was back in place like it was before and the story of one’s true fate begins…



</question>



<answer from>



chocolat...
Member since: 09 September 2007
Total points: 248 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



It sounds to me like the Sorrow Cry era is going to come back, so...
The Return of Sorrow Cry?
The Second Sorrow Cry?



I'm out on a limb here. I have issues with naming my own stories, but I had a need to feel at least somewhat helpful.



</answer>



<answer from>



Vive
Member since: 18 July 2008
Total points: 671 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



It sounds like an interesting story idea. If you haven't finished writing it, I suggest you finish the whole thing first before you name your story. However, here are some ideas:

- Legends of the Golden Light
- Savior
- Savior of the Light
- Marked Child
- Fate of Light
- Scattered Light
- Pieces of the Light
- Shattered Light
- LOTGA
- The Broken Shards of Light

etc.

Good Luck.

V.



</answer>

<question>



How do you enjoy books?



I read books but become bored. Can someone help?
And can someone name some places you can go to, where you can enjoy a book more?



</question>



<answer from>



sparkle
Member since: 02 April 2008
Total points: 3762 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



I have been enjoying books since the age of 8. Its my preferred choice of entertainment. I gave up about 7 years ago. I guess you should try reading about something that you are interested in.



</answer>



<answer from>



Tanya B
Member since: 29 June 2008
Total points: 2219 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Singles & Dating



</answer from>



<answer>



You have to use your imagination. Don't just read it, you have to paint a picture in your head and imagine it just like you're watching a movie. (Except that you can picture your character or setting however you want). That's why I think books are more exciting that movies. There's no limits. As the person above me said, you have to find a book that's interesting too. Don't expect to find a boring old dictionary, start reading it, and actually enjoy it. :] Find something you're interested in.



</answer>



<answer from>



Graceful Little Alice
Member since: 16 June 2008
Total points: 2194 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Books & Authors



</answer from>



<answer>



I tend to read things that i'm passionate about. Vampires, witches, you know, fantasy stuff. But i also read 'realistic fiction', which s almost like real life, only not a real story. No magic involved, just telling about someone else's imaginary life. Find our passion. Maybe you like reading about rebellious students (if you do, try out Isamu Fukui's novel, "Truancy" about a bunch of kids who fight the school system). Maybe you're into fantasy (try Harry Potter, Twilight, The Host, etc.). Maybe you like Greek/Roman/Norse/Egyptian mythology (try Percy Jackson and the Olympians, anything about Thor or Odin, The Mummy, etc.). You may even like spin offs of things (Try 'the looking glass wars' by Frank Beddor [its and alice in wonderland spin-off], or 'Beastly' by Alex Flinn [ a spin off of Beauty and the Beast. Not as girly as it sounds, don't worry])

Just find your ideal fantasy and go with it.

♥Graceful Little Alice♥



</answer>



<answer from>



LapanCoo...
Member since: 21 April 2008
Total points: 233 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



It's just because you haven't found your type of books.



Just rent some books from your local library, at least 10. Start with the first one, and force yourself to read it up to page 36, if you are bored, grab another one, until you find an interesting one.

It's a bit like movies... you never know if you're going to like it... just give it a chance. :)

I hope it will work for you coz books rules!!!



</answer>



<answer from>



rottento...
Member since: 25 July 2008
Total points: 160 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Well, personally I enjoy books because they're a form of entertainment for me. I like to think of it as a TVshow and play it out in my mind. Books also provide new ideas and views. They cause enlightenment and new interests. 
Reading is something no one can ever take away from you. After you've read a book for the rest of your life you can always say "I've read the book ______!"



There are many, many places where you can go to enjoy a good book. Some of the places I go and recommend would be..

- Near a body of water such as an ocean, lake, river, pond, etc. The presense of water is calming and relaxing. Just make sure you protect the book your reading and don't drop it in or near the water! =)

- On the roof of your house/apartment. When I want to just be alone in a house of chaos I simply climb out my window with a good book and read. It is especially wonderful at night because you can stop inbetween chapters and take a look at the stars. But, you have to be careful not to fall because that could lead to possible injury/death or cause someone else injury/death. =)

- In a tree. Find a good (and stable) tree, climb up it, find a comfortable branch and read your book! I don't recommend it for long periods of time but it's quite peaceful if your looking to read a couple of chapters.

I hope I've helped you! =D



</answer>

<answer from>



Holly M
Member since: 24 April 2008
Total points: 2668 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Books & Authors



</answer from>



<answer>



What kind of books do you enjoy reading?  Erotica has a large following and the books do have some kind of romantic storyline, but it isn't the focus of the book.
Have you thought about putting real life issues in your stories, perhaps a love story between an aids patient and a soldier in Afghanistan.
or a story about an illegal alien who marries a guy for citizenship, but then falls in love with him, but he doesn't believe her, blah blah blah.
Take any situation from the paper and make it your plot and just use the romance part as a subplot.
Good luck and keep writing.



</answer>



<answer from>



misslave...
Member since: 11 October 2007
Total points: 887 (Level 2)



Contributing In:



Books & Authors



</answer from>



<answer>



I think maybe the only way to do that is to have experienced love, and have gained enough perspective to address it honestly and objectively. I don't think anyone really knows what love is until they have lived through it. To say it's hard would be an understatement! Love can be beautiful and ugly, fulfilling and painful, all at the same time. It's never, EVER perfect. I think once you can tap into that kind of real experience and write about love with honesty rather  than idealism (and I mean all writers, not you personally), you'll wind up with a book that many people identify with. Good luck!



</answer>



<answer from>



jenkin19...
Member since: 01 December 2006
Total points: 7960 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



I worked in an international bookshop for over 6 years, and the steadiest bestsellers were Mills and Boon.  I daresay there is a 'formula' but it must be easy enough to learn.  Buy a couple and identify what the main themes are, and just write the same.  You will always sell.  The author's name is not important - the fact that it's Mills and Boon is the real selling point.



</answer>






<original file>index;_ylt=Ahl_6A7Vav0029cwTSWirFbsBwx15c0.html</original file>

<category>



Arts & Humanities



Books & Authors



</category>



<question from>



jack_ran...
Member since: 01 August 2008
Total points: 96 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Any tips on creating a fictional world?



I'm trying to create a fictitious world for use in my art. It's going to have a lot of detail - histories, geographies, beliefs, governments etc. - but I'm not sure where to start. Are there any resources or tips on how to successfully create a complex, detailed imaginary world?



</question>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



Try sneezing with some vegetables in your mouth.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



I look for books that have the detail data that matches my ideas best. I bought a home design book to get ideas for room decor, plant books to include plants, rock books for geology, books on sea life for ocean animals, fossils books for historical creatures, field guides for animals, etc.



A good way to use a history or geography book is to use the style of speech and replace it with your own details. I added history by finding news stories and then changing the details to match my own novel.

Since its always best to show instead of tell for religion, political and economic behavior, think of how you could show the behavior in a scene i.e. have people praying rather than saying people pray. Often movies can show areas that are hard to visit -- I like many of the BBC series.

I create a document that contains a list of all I've decided. See the references below for books with detail lists.



Source(s):



Worlds of Wonder by David Gerrold, How to Write Science Fiction & Fantasy by Orson Scott Card



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



obscure colours that arent natural like pinks and purples in buildings and hints of blues in animal fur.... you get what i mean.  ive got some lovely fairy kingdom pics that embrace that type of thing



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



yes. depend it on ur real world, only the imaginary things should be the parts of your world u wish u cood change



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



Here's a site that has lots of tips on creating imaginative worlds: http://www.elfwood.com/farp/writing.html It's mostly geared toward fantasy writers & has some tips for writers of any genre. And if you have any specific questions about fantasy writing that isn't covered there, you can join Elfwood and ask here: http://forum.elfwood.com/



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



You have a very good start. Now add the day to day details. How do people eat? What do they eat? Where do they work? What is transportation? Currency? Communication? Problems? Climate? It goes on and on.  Anne Mc Caffrey has done a wonderful job of creating the fictional world of Pern. Every single detail has been explored. Have you read them? Pax-C



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



One pretty standard and often used way is to start with this world and start changing things. Some obvious kinds of things that can be changed would be to have people live a lot longer, or to be able to read minds. You could also make garbage valuable and gold trash. Just start with the real, change it, and see what you want to do next.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



I ALWAYS start with characters. looks, personality, ect.

As far as political systems and philosophy go, come up with something that reflects YOUR idea of great, and also something that makes people think. Make people wonder and come up with ideas.  Seriously, I am sucker for these kinds of things.

Geography- be creative! But have it reflect your society.



History- Again, it should reflect your made-up society... Perhaps have something to do with our generation, if the story takes place in the future. This is the best way about making comments about our current society.



After this, go into details. Once you have come up with the whole, create the individual. 
good luck! :)



</answer>

its called first look. go to harperteen.com then go to contests and scroll all the way down till you find the first look thing. you decide which book/books you want to read and they will send you it to read and review and then you send in your review and you get to keep the book. PLUS these are books that havent even been published so your one of the first to review it. :D



</answer>

<answer from>

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



this sounds obvious but have you typed the ISBN into amazon or ebay? the isbn is unique to the particular book and you'll be able to find all the publishing info and date from this.



</answer>

<answer>

<answer from>



no answerer details

<answer>



I personally liked it too but I can see why some people wouldn't.
Twilight attracted so many people partly because it had an equal amount of fighting/enemies/death/tragedy and the lovey/dovey part. In the last book Meyer focussed a lot more on the lovey/dovey part to wrap the saga up on a good note.
But she ended up turning Bella Swan into some perfect mary-sue-type (Which put people off). Also, I was a bit disappointed with they way Alice was depicted she was different in BD, she just didn't quite seem like Alice.

But this sort of thing is to be expected with books - you can't please them all especially when so many people obsess over it and get a certain storyline set in their mind as they wait for it to be released.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



She's an author.
She's going to be criticized sometimes. Of COURSE there will be "negative comments" and "slagging" sometimes. If you release a product to the public, you have opened the door to let yourself be criticized, judged, and critiqued. If she can't handle criticism (and she can't, judging by her silly interviews of late), she's in the wrong business. If you can't handle that she's sometimes going to be criticized, and you can't handle the "fans' outrage"-- welcome to America! Freedom of speech. People who disliked the book have just as much a right to their opinion as you do yours.

If half of her fans hated the book, it should tell you something about the book. If a good 90% of the *professional* reviews about the book are negative, it should tell you something about the book (personally, I put more stock into what a professional reviewer says than the typically 14 year old Twilight fans).

Who the hell cares if they "worshiped" her the day before but now don't like her? I'm loyal to BOOKS, not authors. I love JKR (one of my favorite authors), but if she ever releases a crappy book, I'll have no problem saying it's crappy. Sometimes even good authors can release something that is awful. I've never liked Smeyer, but even if she someday releases something that's just amazing, I'll still think Breaking Dawn is crappy. Like I said-- I'm loyal to books. Not authors.



Source(s):



Topaz--
For most anti-BDawners, the ending had nothing to do with our dislike. We didn't dislike it because it "didn't go how we wanted it to". We disliked it because it had no plot, there were dozens of plot holes, there was no point, there was no conflict, the end was anti-climatic, and the characters acted out of character.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



Sorry, there are very few fans of it. At least, not that i've talked to. All of my friends that have read it (and so far, that's about...20 people) hated it. A few of them even returned their copies or donated them to our local library. Personally, i hated it.

♥Graceful Little Alice♥



</answer>

<question>



I wanna write a fiction book but don't know what to write about- any ideas?



i wanna write one thats similar to Harry Potter (with wizards in it) but i don' t know what to write about



</question>



<answer from>



Sasha
Member since: 12 March 2008
Total points: 596 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Just free write. Something will come to you eventually.
If it's someone else's idea, it will never work well for you - as a short story, /maybe/, but as a book, it's basically guaranteed not to. Beyond that, if someone had an idea for an entire book, why wouldn't they write it?



</answer>



<answer from>



Venus Y
Member since: 12 August 2008
Total points: 120 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



start with your own experiences.



if you are already thinking Harry Potter style then maybe you relate to that - explore that in your own life and elaborate and go from there.



think about your childhood stuff.
good luck



</answer>



<answer from>



darth-yo...
Member since: 11 August 2008
Total points: 139 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



write from your heart (it sounds cheesy i know :P)



</answer>



<answer from>



Bookworm-Totally Obsessed
Member since: 27 March 2008
Total points: 252 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Well, you just said it yourself, you want a story on wizards. So why don't you start defining the settings? If it's going to be in Camelot, or the modern world (Do you want to be a wizard? is a great series on wizards in the present day who are intent on slowing the death of the universe) or a make believe world of sorcerors and witches (The Darkangel Trilogy by Meredith Ann Pierce) or even one of mages or chanters (Tamora Pierce's books, any one; the Chanters of Tremaris Trilogy).



Shape up the setting and the main character with a character sketch, and the plot will come out in no time.



</answer>



<answer from>



Ginerva
Member since: 27 July 2008
Total points: 641 (Level 2)



Contributing In:



Books & Authors



</answer from>

Katen

<answer>



If you are going to write about wizards I would first think about how you are going to make it completely different to Harry Potter. Maybe have a girl as the main character, of from the point of view of someone completely different to Harry - like Voldemort.
Why not think about the time it is set, it could be set in the medievil times or in the future.

Maybe something along the lines of

The year is 3945, the wizard count is low, single figures. Tomorrow is the execution of the last Witch, my wife. Only me and my best friend are left. We are the last wizards on Earth.

I know it sounds kinda cheesy and sci fi but I did my best



</answer>

<question>



Favourite piers anthony book?



what is you favourite piers anthony book?
what series is it in?
what is the most recent book you have read by him?

are his UK versions of the Split Infinity available in the US?

i love split infinity
in split infinity series (originally set to be trilogy, but was expanded)
currently reading blue adept



</question>



<answer from>



The Technical Analyst
Member since: 30 September 2007
Total points: 12657 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Macroscope.



</answer>



<answer from>



swdarkli...
Member since: 07 January 2008
Total points: 7449 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Books & Authors



</answer from>



<answer>



My favorite books by Piers Anthony would have to be Bio of a Space Tyrant (6 books) followed by the Apprentice Adept series (7 books).



I have read many of his books, but the above 13 books are by far my favorites - can't really single out a specific book, as these work more as a series than a single story.

Other books that I have enjoyed are the Geodyssey books (Isle of Woman, Shame of Man, Hope of Earth, Muse of Art), Shade of the Tree and Firefly, although he has written many wonderful books. I have read a few of the Xanth books and enjoyed those as well.

I don't know if you can find the UK versions, in the US, but US versions are definitely available. You can probably order the UK versions, but shipping would probably be pretty high.

If you check the link below and click through on the title of the book, you can see which versions have been published (near the bottom of the page) as well as their availablility. You can also try the second site listed below, but I don't know if shows if it is the UK or US version. Their prices on used books are quite reasonable and they offer free shipping in the US.



Source(s):



http://www.fantasticfiction.co.uk/a/pier...
http://www.betterworld.com/list.aspx?Sea...



</answer>

<question from>



kiwispud...
Member since: 16 May 2008
Total points: 187 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Who are Tom Becker and Roddy Doyle's agents? You can answer with just one if you like. ?



The above



</question>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



I don't know these authors, but I'll tell you that if you look in their books at the dedication page, sometimes they'll mention who their agent is. Just another research tip.

Also, agents don't charge up front fees. If they try it, run away. They take their percentage off the top of the check you get from your publisher and you get the rest. Don't begrudge them their fee, though. They work really hard to get your work in front of the right people and help negotiate your contracts. A good agent is worth their weight in gold. A bad agent is worse than none at all.



Source(s):



Author



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>

No person who is famous or is an agent of a famous person will tell you.
1. because they get asked to be THERE agent
2. the nagging
and three its to expensive anywayss

xx



</answer>

5. “Ellen!” It was a cry of instant recognition. “Ellen - it’s been so long. What are you doing here? How did…

<answer>



Theres an obscure book called "Some Talk of Private Armies" which covers all the small Allied armed groups in WW2, from Pops Private Army (a Polish distillary worker in North Africa who formed a gueriila force with his Arab workers and caused mayhem to the Germans) through to the weird British fighter unit in the Far East that had Swastikas on their wings (seriously)

This book has to be pregnanat with novel ideas.

The other weird idea is that of the Melungeons, mentioned in Bill Brysons "The Lost Continenet" and in this link http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Melungeon

There is a theory that they are the descendants of the lost colony of Roanoke Island, who left their settlement with only the word "Croatoan" carved on a tree.

Hope this helps

<answer from>



Rob K
Member since: 20 May 2006
Total points: 11357 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



I could make any number of suggestions but ultimately they may not fit your idea of a good story. It's always suggested that you 'write what you know' or certainly about something for which you have a passion.

I know nothing of your age or your interests and that's why it is so tough.

It's not just the initial idea either, there have to be plots woven through the story as well to give it a credible length.

Who will you based your protagonist upon - you or someone you look up to? or your anti-hero? What other characters will you include. Will there be a love interest? family secret? national emergency? What twists will you introduce during the story to keep the reader interested. What will be revealed along the way and what will the final outcome reveal?

What genre will it reflect, sci-fi, action, sports, political thriller, murder, etc.?

I hope this has given you something to think about and then it can be a work of your own. If someone gave you an idea and you used it and your novel was successful, they might feel aggrieved and sue you for compensation for their original idea. This question would become paramount in any litigation.



Source(s):



Overactive imagination for far too many years...

I've started too many books and not gone on to finish them.

I wish you good luck in your endeavours!



</answer>



<answer from>



princess...
Member since: 28 June 2007
Total points: 3378 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Books & Authors



</answer from>



<answer>



Come up with your own ideas for a novel-I have to agree fishing on here for ideas is lazy. I'd be surprised if you got anywhere as a writer never coming up with your own ideas. Use your imagination for goodness sake-something I assume you have if you write. If you don't, you're never going to be a proper writer.

You shouldn't write other people's ideas, you should write your own. It is more important to write firstly for yourself.

As someone once said, it is better to write for yourself and have no public, than write for the public and have no self.



</answer>



<answer from>



mike b
Member since: 23 June 2008
Total points: 503 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



What interests you?  You could write a story about Special Forces rescuing a senior Government official who's been kidnapped.  Another idea is to work on developing a character.  It's amazing, actually, how this can work itself into a story.  It's difficult to advise you, not knowing your interests, but perhaps a lonely old man who's befriended by a much younger man/boy.  The old man's retired from, say, the C.I.A., and has kept his secrets all these years.  Gently, the boy pries these secrets from him, and you write your book as a conversation(s) between the two.  Could be quite exciting.  Hope this helps,
Good luck
Mike B



</answer>

<original file>index;_ylt=AilFARRnxtO4pFyTOG8tqjXsBwxc482.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk34806.txt</current file name>



<category>



Arts & Humanities



Books & Authors



</category>



<question from>



Vicious vegan
Member since: 06 August 2007
Total points: 2651 (Level 4)



</question from>



<question>



How many books does Laurell K Hamilton plan on writing?



In the Anita Blake series, that is.



Her latest book "blood noir" just came out and I know a lot of people who're not too happy with her latest books. So I'm just wondering if she's planning on calling the series to an end sometime soon.



Does anyone know?



</question>



<answer from>



kristen2...
Member since: 09 May 2006
Total points: 3249 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Laurell did an interview with Writer's Digest back in March.  They asked her this same question and here was her response:

"YOU'RE ON ANITA BLAKE BOOK NUMBER 16 IN THE SERIES. IS THERE ANY END IN SIGHT FOR THIS SERIES OR DO YOU WANT TO KEEP IT GOING INDEFINITELY?

I have no plans to ever stop Anita. I think of the series as mystery; it's open ended. Unless I change my mind, I'll still be writing Anita when I'm 80. That's a while away. I may have other interests by then. But I'm still having a wonderful time with Anita. I'm still learning new things about Anita and her friends. I'm still learning new things about her world.

I've had other writers ask me how I keep an interest in it. All I can say is my characters are so real to me that they make choices that aren't mine. They surprise me and it helps me to never get bored. John D. MacDonald wrote more than 20 books for the Travis McGee mystery series. And Rex Stout had more than 70 books in the Nero Wolfe series. My goal used to be 20. But when I found out about Rex Stout, 70 became my new goal."



Source(s):



Writer's Digest article:
http://www.writersdigest.com/article/lau...



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thank you.



</asker's comment>

<answer>



If you're looking for stories about an everyday person in a weird world, there are hundreds to choose from!

How's about trying for starters:

The Wizard of Oz - child called Dorothy ends up in Oz after being sucked up by a tornado.

The Lion, The Witch, and The Wardrobe - 4 London children end up in Narnia after finding a tunnel there through an old wardrobe.

Stardust, by Neil Gaiman - A ordinary boy travels across the wall in his English village, thinking to find the fallen star he just witnessed, only to find himself in a magical world.

Bridge to Terabithia, by Katherine Paterson - two kids make-believe a kingdom that ends up becoming real.

Hope these titles help.



Source(s):



All can be purchased from bookshops like Amazon, or borrowed from your public library free of charge.



</answer>

<question>



In order to be considered well-read, I would expect you to have read .........



My teenage children are at last developing a taste for literature and I have said that I would compose a list of books that I consider classics which they may like to have a go at reading.  What would be on your list? And if you had to add a 'heavy going factor' with 5* being heavy going and 1* being light, that would help too.



</question>



<additional details>



By heavy going I mean weighty, intellectual, tough vocabularly eg The Unbearable Likeness of Being, A Brief History of Time.  By easy going I easy to follow in terms of plot, vocabulary and general readabilty. It doesn't necessarily it is a better or worse piece of literature.



</additional details>



<answer from>



Joop
Member since: 11 July 2007
Total points: 199 (Level 1)



</answer from>

<answer from>



Sprinkles
Member since: 14 October 2007
Total points: 3286 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Fashion & Accessories



</answer from>



<answer>



Gone With the Wind 4 (uses a handful of harder words but this has got to be one of the best vocab-improving books out there :D)
Animal Farm (politically based but great book!) 2
To Kill a Mockingbird 2
The Great Gatsby 3
Pride and Prejudice 3
Tom Saywer 2
1984 by George Orwell 2
Romeo and Juliet 3
The Pearl 1
Of Mice and Men 1
A Tale of Two Cities 4
Breakfast at Tiffanys (the novella) 2
The Lord of the Flies 2

I'd say my favorites are Gone With the Wind (I LOVED THAT BOOK AS A 7th GRADER!!!!), The Pearl, A Tale of Two Cities, and To Kill a Mockingbird. I'm 13 right now and have more of an adventurous but romantic taste in literature. :) The Lord of the Flies is a great adventure story for boys especially...But with all classics, the reader has to try and analyze it after reading - that way he/she can get the most out of the book and recognize the themes. I would recommend having your teens write a short response after each book they read, or at least going to Wikipedia and looking up the book and finding out more about the plot, themes, motifs, etc. :)

Other books my teachers assigned during middle school are:
The Outsiders 2
The Princess Bride 2
The Third Eye (this is not a classic though)
Night 4
Maus (this is a graphic novel) 1-2
All of these are very good selections; I would highly recommend reading Night and The Outsiders though. Princess Bride is a good, relaxing read and it might be considered a classic...

If I had to pick only one book to be on the list it would definitely be Gone With the Wind. It has so many good themes and life lessons and I think that even as a seventh grader reading it for a classic novel project, I was able to take a lot from that book. Now, whenever anyone asks me what the most life-changing thing I have done is, I tell them that it was reading Gone With the Wind! -laughs-  The themes of determination, never giving up, and not being able to get everything you want are all very important and I think it'll be useful for the next school year - I'm going into high school! Yikes, lol.

The higher the number on my list, the harder the language will be. If I were to relist these books in terms of how meaningful and deep they are (though this would depend on the individual's interpretation):

Gone With the Wind 5
Animal Farm 3
To Kill a Mockingbird 4
Pride and Prejudice 2
Tom Saywer 3
1984 by George Orwell 4
Romeo and Juliet 2
The Pearl 3
The Great Gatsby 4
Of Mice and Men 2
A Tale of Two Cities 5 - lots of symbols/themes in this one
Breakfast at Tiffanys (the novella) 3
The Lord of the Flies 4



</answer>

<answer>



If I were you, I'd go to a local high school that has Honors or A.P English courses. The teachers would be more than happy to give you the lists of books that their students read, and help you pick out which ones would be good for your children's level.

Many of the "classics" are not that hard to understand, and it's always good to use the internet and such to dig deeper into the book, about the parts they didn't understand and etc.

In any case, those lists are pretty extensive and contain most of the literature our culture considers to be classic.



</answer>

<question from>



Lost A
Member since: 15 August 2008
Total points: 73 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



If you want to become a good writer...?



how many hours should you read for and how many hours to write?
and while reading should you type down the sentences you like on a typewriter to remember them etc?
I'm 13 and I really want to become an author.



</question>



<answer from>



thatpira...
Member since: 09 August 2006
Total points: 1335 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



It doesn't really matter how long you read/write, as long as you make sure to do it for a little while every day, even if it's just 15 minutes. It's a good idea to keep a notebook where you can collect things that inspire you, and you can write down your favorite passages in there. If you read and write every day, you're sure to improve a lot. Ray Bradbury writes a short story every day when he wakes up. That's a lot, but it's something I like to keep in mind to inspire me.



</answer>



<answer from>



Obsessiv...
Member since: 09 August 2008
Total points: 262 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



You can read and write for however many hours you choose. 
I think it's best to set yourself a certain amount of time for each and stick by that daily. I currently read for around four hours and write for about an hour. 
I make a note of the page number and the name of the book. It helps me to decide on how to write a certain part of a story or bring across a certain aspect. 
I also would like to become an author and, from what I have learnt - by reading different peoples tips - is that any story ideas you get, jot them down. Maybe carry a notebook with you and if you find a good plot out of something you see or have any ideas during the day you can work on them during your specified time.
Hope this helps :)



</answer>



<answer from>



Sequin
Member since: 22 August 2007
Total points: 256 (Level 2)



</answer from>

</answer>



<answer from>



somebody
Member since: 10 February 2008
Total points: 292 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Well, your probably not going to get an answer from anyone here who has written or published a book. However, I will try to give you some pointers because I am in college, and working towards a degree in English, with hopes of writing and publishing literature someday.

-You want reading and writing to be a thing of habit, it would be great if you could implement this hobby with the free time you have. Excessive television, video games, and texting have become a thing of habit for today's disenfranchised youth. I'm not saying that these things are inherently evil, but they're never going to help you with regards to writing or anything productive along those lines. 
-Learn how to write coherently, and use proper grammar. It's a thing of rarity on Yahoo Answers to find someone capable of posting a question or answer that follows these simple and basic guidelines. If you want to become an author, you have to write like one. Try to use capitalization and punctuation whenever you write. I'll give you some slack because you are only 13 years old, but you should learn to write as though it were going to be edited or graded, even if it isn't. Most people today don't take the time to do any of these things, but it should be a focal-point for anyone considering a career in writing.

Understand that writing is not an easy field, and very few ever make it big as a writer (same odds as professional athletics or acting). Writing careers are also dwindling, considering how reading is on a steady decline as other forms of media have taken heed in recent decades. But if you want to do it, go for it, and make it part of your daily routine like an athlete's training. As for typing down sentences you like while reading, I personally don't see any real purpose to that end. You should focus more on building a better understanding of the language overall, not looking for small phrases or sentences that seem appealing or cool.



</answer>



<answer from>



pfskribb...
Member since: 07 July 2008
Total points: 239 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Stephen King suggests 4 hours a day of each.  Which is ridiculous if you already have a job.  I'd say, and mind you I'm no great mind, if you read a book a week and write 500 words a day you'll be doing better than most.  When writing a novel, don't skip a day, or the story will grow dank in your mind and you'll spend most of your time trying to remember who that was or what just happened in the story rather than adding to it.



</answer>



<answer from>



ffgirl
Member since: 11 August 2008
Total points: 129 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I wouldn't say there is a set number of hours that you should read for. Every one is different, so reads at different speeds etc. I would recommend reading lots of different genres and styles. 
As for writing, I would say an hour or two a night for now. 
If you are interested there are some really good websites that you can post things on.

http://www.fictionpress.com/
This website is really good as you can post your orignal fiction or poetry. Readers will review and tell you what you can do to improve

http://www.fanfiction.net/
Fanfiction are basically stories about tv shows, movies, books etc. Writing fan fiction is really good practice for a young writer, because it allows you to create your own plots, but you don't have to create a whole set of characters etc. Plus it's really good fun. I'm 15 and also want to be an author, my writings really improved since I began to write fan fiction, but it's not for everyone.

Hope this has helped, and good luck.



</answer>



<answer from>



mike b
Member since: 23 June 2008
Total points: 897 (Level 2)



Contributing In:



Books & Authors



</answer from>



<answer>



If you like reading, read.  If you like writing, write.  If you dislike doing either one, look for something else to do.  But obviously you want to write, or you wouldn't have asked the question.  Don't set time limits on yourself, either for reading or writing, whatever you do.  Writing is art, and you can't time it.  If you want to write down sentences from books, do it.  I do recommend you grab a notebook and write down ideas as they come to you.  Also characters.  If you see someone who seems a little off-beat, try weaving a story around him/her.  What do they do?  What secrets do they have?  Perhaps they tell you a secret.  What is it?



I hope this helps,
Good luck
Mike B



</answer>

<answer>



I don't think there is a set standard to be honest, it is up to the individual and what works for them. I read when I feel like it, I carry a notebook with me everywhere I go (for ideas etc) and I write when I am in the correct mental frame for it - but that is just me! I know others who write each day no matter what is going on or how they feel. I know people who read ALL the time and then dont write that much at all.... what works for you?

<answer>



Try "Don't Tell Mom I Work on the Rigs: She Thinks I'm a Piano Player in a Whorehouse" By Paul Carter. It's Pauls bio here's a synopsis from amazon.com

Since age 18, Paul Carter has worked on oil rigs in locations as far flung as the Middle East, Columbia, the North Sea, Borneo, Tunisia, Sumatra, Vietnam, Nigeria, Russia, and many others — and he's survived (so far!) to tell stories from the edge of civilization (places, as it happens, upon which most of our lives rely). Carter has been shot at, hijacked and held hostage, almost died of dysentery in Asia and toothache in Russia, watched a Texan lose his mind in the jungles of Asia, lost a lot of money backing a scorpion against a mouse in a fight to the death, and served cocktails by an orangutan on an ocean freighter. Taking postings in some of the world's wildest and most remote regions — not to mention some of the roughest rigs on the planet — Carter has worked and gotten into trouble with some of the maddest, baddest and strangest people you could ever hope not to meet.

I use to work in a bookstore and the guys loved it and thought it was hilarious.

Steve J

</answer from>



<answer>



Hi JT.
My, you do seem to have been recommended some awful books! You give no clues as to your taste, but "funny" and "gripping" is a tricky one. I will suggest "Kim" by Rudyard Kipling, a cracking adventure yarn with a good dash of humour. Then I will suggest "The 39 Steps" by John Buchan, a ripping yarn if ever there was one. For modern books it is harder, humour being difficult to come by. Try the "Flashman" books by George MacDonald Fraser, starting with "Flashman" and "Flashman at the Charge". If you like the lying, womanising, cowardly chancer (like I do) there are plenty more!

As a wild card, try Jerome K Jerome's "Three Men in a Boat" and "Three Men on the Bummel". Not gripping in the accepted sense, but funny and quite riveting reads.

Enjoy, Steve.



</answer>



<answer from>

<answer from>



2tuforu
Member since: 29 June 2007
Total points: 1052 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I'm a girl, but am not afraid to read guy books and horror stories, and am not all interested in chick lit, so I think you can consider my suggestions with a peace of mind. I've also read all the ones I'm about to list, and I loved them!! They all have a good amount of adventure, action, and humor (especially the Alfred Kropp series) . . .



Here are a couple of books that are guy-certified (meaning I've seen them being read by guys):
the Pendragon series by D. J. MacHale 
the Everworld series by K. A. Applegate (I'm not so wild about this one as I am with the others)

Here are some more books that I haven't seen guys reading but are still awesome:
the Cirque du Freak series by Darren Shan
the Demonata series by Darren Shan
the Alfred Kropp series by Rick Yancy
the Alex Rider Adventures series by Anthony Horowitz

Note: I don't know if you would consider these books to be too juvenile (considering your age), but please don't be turned off but what I'm about to say: The first two I listed can usually be found in the Children's section of the bookstore, and the others in the Young Adult section. But they're all still REALLY good. Overall, on average, they are rated on Amazon a 4.5 - 5 out of 5 stars. I believe they can be read by anyone at any age . . . well, maybe excluding the Everworld series due to all the cussing.

Anyways, go check them out on Amazon to get a feel of their awesomeness!! :D

Also, if none of the books I listed suit you, try "American Shaolin: Flying Kicks, Buddhist Monks, and the Legend of Iron Crotch: an Odyssey in the New China" by Matthew Polly. I haven't read it yet but it looks interesting and it seems to have the stuff you want, as you can probably tell by the title.
---

Another note: I don't think the Warriors series will interest you; I don't think it's what you're looking for . . . Don't get me wrong, I really like the series, but I don't think it has the type of humor and grippingness (I know that's not a word) you want . . . Just warning you. ;)

Good luck!



</answer>

<question>



How do you become a good writer?



How do you become a good writer? how? How do you remember all the words. How do you make up good sentences?



</question>



<answer from>



sn0zb0z
Member since: 20 April 2008
Total points: 503 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Read as much as possible and write as much as possible. Get feedback on your work and just keep writing



</answer>



<answer from>



RobKin
Member since: 10 June 2008
Total points: 250 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



There are long distance courses you can do. The Writers Bureau (google it) is one to look at. They will assess your work as you complete projects and help you along the way.



</answer>



<answer from>



italian-...
Member since: 03 October 2007
Total points: 2735 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Attend an evening class in Creative Writing. Get some books (from the library if you are short of funds). Join a Writers Group where you can hear other people's work and try out your own and get constructive criticism. Read a lot of books in the genre that you wish to write in.



</answer>



<answer from>



princess...
Member since: 28 June 2007
Total points: 3384 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Books & Authors



</answer from>



<answer>



Read as much as possible.

Have talent.

Keep practising.



</answer>



<answer from>



Selentic
Member since: 13 September 2007
Total points: 3160 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Start by running away from B&A as fast as you can.

Then pick up a classic, and it's pretty much downhill from there.



</answer>



<answer from>



mike b
Member since: 23 June 2008
Total points: 506 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



You have to want to write above all else.  Having said that, read, read, read.  Learn from the masters.  (And I don't mean 'Breaking Dawn' type stuff, either.)  Dickens, Hemingway, Orwell, etc.  And write!  Buy a notebook and write out any ideas you may have.  Or pick a character, develop him/her and weave a story around them.
Good luck
Mike B



</answer>



<answer from>



Sephen B
Member since: 03 August 2008
Total points: 130 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



If you don't have a creative side then there isn't much you can do which is the truth. If you do and you feel lost try to read some books which is the advice from most people! Read some good books though, some of the classics and not that Harry Potter rubbish. Dickens, Shakespeare, Orwell ( 1984-pretty depressing book though ) and the others. Try and look at some of the sentences in articles by Borris Johnston as well. There is some good writing there!



</answer>

<answer>

"I Capture The Castle" by Dodi Smith

You can buy a nice copy at The Folio Society (and you don't have to become a member to buy one book) or you can find it on amazon.

<answer>



'Once' by James Herbert

I was never really interested in Fairies and Demons, but this guy knows how to write.

He gives a description so that you feel that you are living it and describes characters as if they have been your friends all your life.  Believable, unputdownable and an amazing read.

I think you would love it.

<answer>



The Gemma Doyle trilogy by Libba Bray are great books.
1st book- A Great and Terrible Beauty 
2nd book- Rebel Angels
3rd book- The Sweet Far Thing
These books have a variety of different themes intertwined-fantasy,romance, and action.

<answer from>



Leah M
Member since: 13 December 2006
Total points: 2594 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



I hate to sound like one of the grammar freaks, but what's with all the capitals, that must have been really annoying having to put in all those.
Anyway, enough of that.  Have you read Dune by Frank Herbert?  It's the most amazing sci-fi/fantasy adventure ever.  It's quite dark too, it's about a royal family that get moved to another planet where the natives are hostile and another family are looking to usurp them.  The planet is all sand dunes and these big worms live in them that eat people.  Really, if you haven't read it then you should, it's awesome.
You should also give Stephen King's The Dark Tower series a go too, that's pretty amazing, all 7 books of it.  It's got plenty of adventure and some horror too.
There's a book called Jonathan Strange and Mr Norrell by a woman called Susanne (or Susanna) Clarke and that's really nice and magical, it's a tiny bit slow but it is good.



</answer>



<answer from>



Sagda
Member since: 23 August 2007
