<answer>



Try some of these:

Neil Gaiman is an amazing author! Any of his books are good. Try Neverwhere, Stardust, or Coraline.

Edgar Allen Poe is a really good author. Check out his poems and short stories.



William Shakespeare is good too.

Any books by Scott Westernfeld or Neal Shusterman are really good too.

Any books by Amelia Atwater-Rhodes are amazing! There is In The Forest of The Night, Demon In My View, Shattered Mirror, Midnight Predator. And then there is the The Kiesha'ra series: Hawksong, Snakecharm, Falcondance, Wolfcry and Wyverhail.



A Northern Light by Jennifer Donnelly

Blood and Chocolate by Annette Curtis Klause

The Princess Bride by William Goldman

Abarat by Clive Barker, Make sue you get the hardcover version though!!! If you liked the first one be sure to check out the next book in the series Abarat: Days of Magic, Nights of War.

Daughters of Destiny series: Keeper of the Winds,Keeper of the Waters, Keeper of the Flames and Keeper of the Earth by Jenna Solitaire.



The Abhorsen Trilogy (Sabriel, Lirael, Abhorsen) by Garth Nix



The Maximum Ride series (The Angel Experiment, Schools Out Forever, Saving the World and Other Extreme Sports, The Final Warning) by James Patterson

His Dark Materials trilogy (The Golden Compass, The Subtle Knife and The Amber Spyglass) by Philip Pullman

A Great and Terrible Beauty, Rebel Angels and The Far Sweet Thing by Libba Bray

The Riddles of Epsilon by Christine Morton-Shaw

The Cry of the Icemark by Stuart Hill

The Haunting of Alaizabel Cray by Chris Wooding

Inkheart and Inkspell and Inkdeath (coming soon!) by Cornelia Funke

The Inheritance Trilogy by Christopher Paolini

The Chronicles of Narnia (7 books) by C.S. Lewis

The Hobbit and The Lord of the Rings trilogy by J.R.R. Tolkien

Uglies series by Scott Westernfeld

The Wind Singer, Slaves of the Mastery and Firesong by William Nicholson

The Sight and Fell by David Clement-Davies

The Prophecy of the Stones by Flavia Bujor



Wake by Lisa McMann

Old Magic by Marianne Curley

Jurassic Park by Michael Crichton

The Earthsea series (starting with A Wizard of Earthsea) by Ursula K. Le Guin

Shadow Spinner by Susan Fletcher



Source(s):



Enjoy!



</answer>

<answer from>



logicals...

<answer>



Because bookworms (the lit. worms) eat their way through a book, from cover to cover, and someone who likes to read consumes a book as voraciously as a worm.



</answer>

eldie

</answer from>



<answer>



Han Nolan is a really good writer, try reading some of her books

It's better for girls than for boys, and it's not all about "I-love-him-but-he-doesn't-love-me" blahblahblah; they're more serious, more moving stories than that. Nolan doesn't consider the reader some pubescent little kid.



Also, Francesca Lia Block, she's really good too, a little like Han Nolan

Also, if you're into science fiction, try the Ender's Series (Ender's Game, etc.) by Orson Scott Card. It's a little like Harry Potter, only in space. It's about this really intelligent kid.

Good luck, happy reading!



</answer>

<answer>

<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I forget the title but a hen wanted to bake bread but none of the other animals in the barnyard wanted to help.  So eventually she gathered the ingredients and she and her chicks baked the bread.  Then all the animals wanted some of it but since they didn't help they got nothing.  Nice morality tale for a toddler.  :o)

<question from>



especial
Member since: 14 January 2008
Total points: 95 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



How can I find a (probably out of print) book that my mum remembers from her childhood, without title/author?



My mum was telling me about a book that she was given when she was a little girl (over 40 years ago), and she said the book looked old then! but she said she really loved it. However, she doesn't have it any more.



As a surprise for her birthday, I'd like to find it for her - but I don't know the title or author.

It's about a young girl from Liverpool who gets invited to stay with wealthy relatives in Cornwall. She has to go on the train alone, and before she goes, her mother takes her shopping for some nice dresses to wear.



That's all my mum can remember about the plot... She said it was a small green book and it was so old and non-famous then that it's probably out of print.

Would love it if someone could help out with a method to finding this book, as i doubt anyone will remember the book from the scant story details!

Thanks
x



</question>



<answer from>



madi n katie
Member since: 10 February 2008
Total points: 0 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



CHILDHUD MORE LIKE ADULTHOOD BRAPPPP



</answer>



<answer from>



shelly lamb
Member since: 17 March 2008
Total points: 666 (Level 2)

Sprinkles

Contributing In:

<answer>

</answer>



<answer from>



AlienSun...
Member since: 16 February 2007
Total points: 3002 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



This is a fantastic and very thoughtful idea but a tough one. Maybe try some Antique book dealers and describe as much as you can to them and they may be able to help you. Maybe your local library can advise where you could find some. See if anyone else in the family remembers the book (aunts, uncles, your grandparents if they are still with us) they may be able to remember the title.  Good luck with your mission, also id love it if you let us all know if you find it.



</answer>



<answer from>



Miss blue dog
Member since: 03 April 2006
Total points: 5297 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



you could go into a second hand bookshop and ask their advice-they'll probably know how to go about it.



</answer>



<answer from>



chocahol...
Member since: 06 April 2008
Total points: 1199 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Wow thats a lovely idea, I think its great you put so much thought into your Mums gift. (Have a word with my daughter will you ha ha ).
I used to love reading when I was a kid but that doesn't ring a bell. All I can think of is that you visit your local library or even write to a few libraries in your area with as many details as you can about the book. You never know, even if you don't get the book you might get more details if anyone remembers it.
Also try writing to your nearest university as anyone who is doing an english or english literature degree may have read the book.
You could also traipse round as many charity shops as you can find, they always have old books. You might actually find a copy of it.
I hope this helps and I hope you find the book. Your Mum will be touched you went to so much trouble.



</answer>

</category>



<question from>



Catherine Rose
Member since: 27 November 2007
Total points: 334 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



How do I protect the copyright of my articles?



I am trying to get my articles published in a newspaper or magazine. How do I protect my work?



</question>



<answer from>



Poison
Member since: 06 May 2007
Total points: 2646 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Anything you write is automatically your copyright. Keep all your back up work, research and early drafts of your writing. This should be enough to suffice if you come to a dispute about ownership.



You may be advised to post yourself a copy of the work and keep the envelope unopened - but this has no legal standing. I believe you can get a solicitor to verify that the work is your own creation, but this will cost you. Another way is to lodge a copy with your bank if they offer you this service. With Barclays it costs around £20 per year to do this and you have proof of the date when your material was put into storage.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks for the great advice.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



country jenny
Member since: 01 September 2006
Total points: 2860 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



ask Citizens advice, they will be able to tell you who to get in contact with.



</answer>



<answer from>



artdavin...
Member since: 29 January 2008
Total points: 4137 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



here ia an article that might help
http://www.sparkplugging.com/craft-boom/...



</answer>



<answer from>



LauraLor...
Member since: 01 July 2008
Total points: 2463 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



You don't need to. It's copyrighted as soon as you write it.



</answer>

<answer from>



obidane
Member since: 23 June 2008
Total points: 4040 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Books & Authors



</answer from>



<answer>



Twilight is a teen romance series about Bella Swan, who moves to a rainy town in Washington state and meets a handsome-beyond-all-belief vampire named Edward Cullen.  They fall in love, but of course nothing is simple (otherwise there wouldn't be one book, much less four).  You'll see Edward's rival for Bella's love starting more in the second book.  His name is Jacob Black, and he's by far my favorite. ^^

The books in order are:
Twilight
New Moon
Eclipse
Breaking Dawn

The books are poorly written, but they can still be interesting.  It really differs from person-to-person on whether or not they like it.



</answer>



<answer from>



Emo-Ange...
Member since: 17 February 2007
Total points: 4750 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



First, because there's no such thing. Anyone who called it a saga to you was lying THROUGH THEIR TEETH.
It is a series.
Calling a romance between a self-absorbed doormat and an emotionally abusive stalker a saga is a disgrace to all the real sagas out there.

There's no plot to it. Bella loves Edward. Edward loves Bella. Bella cooks dinner. Bella drown in depression. Bella hurts everyone around her. Everyone around her, regardless of that, worships the ground she walks on. New vampires come out of nowhere and want to kill her.
I've read better fan fictions.
You're so lucky to never have heard of them.
And no, you don't need to get out more if it's just to find out about this terrible series. Consider yourself lucky.



</answer>



<answer from>



edward cullen = ♥
Member since: 03 May 2008
Total points: 431 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>

lol jk
twilight is amazing deffenatly worth time reading
its about a vampire(edward) and a human(bella) falling in love, not saying anything else :)

The Schwa

</answer from>



<answer>



I agree with the first person, but here is a summary of the first book:
Okay, ready? So it's about this girl whose irresponsible and child-like mother abandons her for a minor-league baseball player who is ten years younger then her. Said girl then goes to live with her cop father in a town in the middle of nowhere in Washington. She basically takes care of him because apparently even though he was alone for sixteen years he is unable to take care of himself. Then, she goes to school, and even though she was considered ugly in her old school, she is apparently gorgeous in Washington. She continues to be mildly self-sufficient until she meets this boy who appears to hate her. Naturally, she falls deeply "in love" with him because (and only because) he is gorgeous (because who doesn't want a guy who hates you, right?). SURPRISE! The aforementioned boy just happens to be a vampire who wants to suck her blood! She becomes totally dependent on him and ceases to be able to think, act, or take care of herself, and she ceases to exist as an individual, rather she is "Edward's girlfriend" from that point on. He is very stalkerish and creepily controlling and overbearing, going as far as to slash her tires to make sure she doesn't go anywhere, but she doesn't seem to mind, because she still "loves" him. Somehow, he ends up "in love" with her too (presumably because she smells good), and they go all gushy love scene. Then some random other vampires decide they would like to kill her (because she smells good), so they try, and of course fail, because if they succeeded that would be several million dollars down the drain now wouldn't it- no opportunity for a sequel, which she decided to make three of. 
The author then makes statements about vampires and goes back on them later in the books, teaches girls that, while it is not okay to get married in high school, it is perfectly acceptable to get married the day after, get pregnant a few days later, have an overbearing and abusive boyfriend, be a nymphomaniac/satyrist or a pedophile, and that it is perfectly okay to attempt suicide should that abusive satyrist boyfriend ever attempt to leave you.
They're badly written, have plot holes as big as oceans, and are all about how "hot" the vampire is.  My advice?  Don't waste your time or money.



</answer>



<answer from>



ZC
Member since: 13 December 2007
Total points: 125 (Level 1)

beachesn...

</answer from>



<answer>



the Twilight saga is a 4-book series following the adventures of an ordinary 17-year-old girl named Bella Swan. It's largely a romance series, with exciting endings and lots of plot twists. Twilight starts out with Bella moving from Phoenix to Fork, WA and meeting the sexy vampire Edward, after which she learns that some myths are more than fantasy.

I read all 4 (Twilight, New Moon, Eclipse, Breaking Dawn), and really enjoyed them. Stephenie Meyer (the author) does an exceptional job pulling you into the story. The target audience is teenage girls, but i know quite a few adults and some boys who enjoy the series.



Source(s):



I read the books.



</answer>



<answer from>



Mizutoki is SPECIAL!
Member since: 09 June 2008
Total points: 576 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Bella, a human, is in love with this guy named Edward. In the latter part of the first book she finds out that he is a vampire. And that she, his true love and vice versa, has the sweetest smelling blood any vampire would want to take a gulp of. It's like a siren singing directly to your heart. But their love for each other is so profound that not even the want for her blood is gonna keep them apart.



That's pretty much the main plot, but a lot of other things are happening around them. A love triangle is quickly formed.

I'll be honest, the series didn't suck. But the last book of the series did. It's one of the shittiest endings, in my opinion. You might feel like your anticipation to finish the series will be worth nothing, but you'll definitely be happy that you finished it anyway. I hope you enjoy the book, I know I wanted to. :]

♥Mizu.



</answer>

<answer>



Consider yourself lucky.

It is the story of a whiny girl who moves to a new town, and everyone at her new school worships her despite the fact that she despises them all in spite of their attempts to be hospitable, and every guy there falls all over her, but she chooses the most attractive guy who is also a vampire, but not really because he only eats animals, and he sparkles for some reason. They fall in love after one word together, and are devoid of any kind of chemistry or personality (although the personality thing kind of goes for all the other characters too). The plot sticks to the last 30 pages of the book, and the entire thing is written like a 12 year old girl fanfiction. This is made even more obvious by the fact that almost every character is a Mary Sue.

I only read the first book in the series, and I barely made it through that one because the writing was so awful and the story so cheesy. From what I have heard they only get worse. All of them really send bad messages as well, considering that the books are mainly read by 13 year old girls, but I can't tell you what that is because you said you didn't want spoilers.



</answer>

Books & Authors



</answer from>



<answer>



About a month and a half ago I was in the same boat.  I kept seeing people on here posting stuff about Twilight, so I finally broke down and read the books.  And quickly became a Twilight addict.

The book Twilight is part of series, aptly named the Twilight Saga.  The books are Twilight, New Moon, Eclipse, and Breaking Dawn.

Twilight is about a high school girl named Bella who moves to the small, rainy town of Forks, Washington to live with her dad after her mom gets remarried.  There, she meets a guy named Edward Cullen.  She finds herself drawn to him and soon discovers he is a vampire.  As she begins to fall in love with him she realizes the dangers of being so closely involved with the vampire world.

Forgive my conjecture, but I know it sounds a little corny and not thoroughly thought out, and in some ways it is.  But for some reason there is something about the books that draws people in and keeps them reading the books over and over again.  They're not great pieces of literature, but I like them.



</answer>

<answer>



Definition of saga:

1 : a prose narrative recorded in Iceland in the 12th and 13th centuries of historic or legendary figures and events of the heroic age of Norway and Iceland 
2 : a modern heroic narrative resembling the Icelandic saga 
3 : a long detailed account &lt;a saga of the Old South&gt;



Sounds like a saga to me..... Especially with the LONG account part.

Anyway, with that said, they aren't that great. They're good, but nothing special. While the first book is really good and the third is okay, the second and fourth aren't. They're not written very well, and the characters aren't great, and the story is very unbelievable. (Yes, I know it's about vampires and werewolves, but there still must be an element of believability and consistency to it).

So, basically, I wouldn't suggest them to you. Well, I might suggest TWILIGHT, but not the other three.



Source(s):



http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionar...



</answer>

<answer from>



Charles S
Member since: 05 June 2008
Total points: 2102 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Being blind needn't stop you writing. You have two options:

1) You can buy a software package with voice recognition and screen reading;

2) You can dictate your thoughts to a dictaphone and have someone type it for you.

You may feel depressed because you're losing your sight and I do understand. My father was effectively blind for the last year or two of his life and he started going blind ten years earlier. While you still have your sight, try to learn Braille and techniques for coping with blindness.

And that your daughter is a lesbian is irrelevant. She may not have a husband or sex with men but she might still have children through a sperm donor. Be happy that she's OK with who she is. Embrace her. She's still your daughter and there for you!

Maine is a lovely state. I holidayed there in '77 and '81. I adore the seafood, especially the lobsters. However, maybe your wife just wants a change. If you've got lots of money, why not take her on a round the world cruise? It might give you ideas to write about.



</answer>



<answer from>



mfg
Member since: 27 August 2006
Total points: 5585 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



You might try counseling and if necessary meds for the depression. Also, you might have SADD, so you might either move to a sunnier place or get a lamp that has light that's more like sunlight.



</answer>

<answer>



"The Historian" by Elizabeth Kostova = amazing!!! I really recommend this to EVERYONE! Probably my favourite at the moment, very... erm, historical :D

"I Am Legend" by Richard Mathieson = it's nothing like the film (everything is different - they just copied the title), I read it long before the film came out and it's one of my favourites :D Lots of scary vampire moments... (and they are vampires in the book).



"Dracula" by Brahm Stoker = just started reading this one and it's fabby. It was written long before all of the cheesy horror cliches which makes them all seem new and exciting when you come across them.



Also try the Anne Rice series. I love my vampire themed novels and these are some of the best I have ever read. What have you read so far? :D

<answer>



-The "House of Night" series by P.C and Kristen Cast is pretty good, and an interesting take on vampirism in general. The first book is called "Marked". 
-Someone else mentioned " 'Salem's Lot" by Stephen King. I love Stephen King, and this is one of his best (in my opinion).
-As far as movies go, "The Lost Boys" will always be a favorite (no, it has nothing to do with Peter Pan).
-I would only recommend "Twilight" if you're partial to romance novels.

I think that's it, sadly.
I can't think of anymore.

<question from>



ecoman19...
Member since: 11 August 2008

</question from>



<question>



Has anybody read Arther C Clarks The last theorem, and what did they think? ?



It was his final novel before his death.



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



It was respectable science fiction, but not the great Clarke at his best.

It re-worked themes and idea he'd dealt with before, but to no telling  effect.  The 2001 and Rama books were fresher, but his earlier short stories were the freshest of  the lot.
Tales from the White Hart, Report on Planet  Three...



</answer>

<question>



Does anybody have any questions for Eileen O'Hely, author of the Penny the Pencil books?www.bestbooks4ever.com



We're interviewing her and we're looking for questions from fans.



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



Like the stories of the famous five of Enid Blyton, Eileen O'Hely has found a heroine in a girl of Penny the Pencil. 
Do You thinkd that you have been influenced by Enid Blyton while writing the stories of Penny the Pencil ?



Penny goes Undercover
Having overthrown Black Texta and his evil sidekick Rubber, Penny and her friends can get on with helping Ralph with his schoolwork.



But someone is writing graffiti on Ralph's school books, vandalising Sarah's entry in the school colouring competition and turning Ralph's coloured pencils against Gloop.



With help from Sarah's pencil Polly, Penny goes undercover to find out who is committing these dastardly deeds.

Arts & Humanities



Books & Authors

<question from>



College Dropout
Member since: 04 May 2006
Total points: 167 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



When do you think the climax in Dr. Jekyll and Mr Hyde is?



I'm not sure if it's when we find out that Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde is the same person or at another point in the book.



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



It's definitely what you say: when we discover that they are the same character. There is no doubt in my mind that Robert Louis Stevenson intended it that way. When we read the story today, everyone knows that Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde are the same person, but the original readers would have had no idea, and had probably never come across anything similar before. If today's readers feel that the climax is at a different point in the book, it's because they already know the story's brilliant and world-famous climactic twist.



</answer>

Books & Authors



</answer from>



<answer>



I suggest you research more effectively by studying Writers Market or Agent Query or any of half a dozen publications and guides designed to help you find an appropriate agent. Make sure you also check Absolute Write and Preditors & Editors for scam artists.



</answer>



<answer from>



Lakely
Member since: 01 December 2006
Total points: 19208 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



You know your work better than anybody. Use "Writer's Market.:" That is the list of the legitimate ones. Pick out a few and follow the instructions they give for query or proposal. Many of them ask for particular things... and some only accept email proposals.

So dig in and find the ones that look right for you and submit to them according to their instructions. Many of them allow multiple submissions... I would recommend that to save yourself some time, since these agent can be slow to respond... even up to months!!



</answer>



<answer from>



annaleya...
Member since: 17 January 2008
Total points: 2998 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



buy a copy of the writers and artists year book,  that lists pretty much everyone



</answer>

<answer>

<answer>



You might be thinking of Honore de Balzac - famous for his novel cycle, "The Human Comedy".

I would also recommend Guy de Maupassant - not a playwright but a brilliant short story writer - I recommend "The Necklace".



Source(s):



Balzac
en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Honoré_de_Balzac

The Necklace
www.eastoftheweb.com/short-stories/UBo...



</answer>

<answer>

<category>



Arts & Humanities



Books & Authors



</category>



<question from>



hafwen
Member since: 01 May 2008
Total points: 2404 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



Writing several novels concurrently...writers: what are your thoughts? Am I being too fickle?



At present, I'm writing a novel for teenagers - I'm about halfway through, and it's humming along pretty well. I'm still "in love" with this book, and feel confident that I'll get to the end.

Thing is, I have ideas for many more novels pulling at me, books that I'm itching to write - both teenage and adult novels. I've even planned three of them to the point where I feel I could start writing them now.



While I'm madly in love with my current project, I can feel these other novels beckoning. I feel a bit like a kid in a candy shop!



Should I give in and work on several books at the same time? They're all vastly different ideas, so there would be no danger of confusing the stories...



Do you think that spreading my creative energy over a number of projects is a good idea? Am I being too fickle?



Put it this way, I always read a number of novels concurrently - always have done. I'm wondering what the merits are of approaching my writing in the same way...

I'd love to hear your thoughts on this...

Hafwen x

PS. I've completed 3 novels already, so at least I know I have the stamina...



</question>



<additional details>



TW K - no, I'm not published yet - apart from a couple of short stories. And as for my 3 completed manuscripts - well, I gave each one my full attention...



</additional details>



<answer from>



Alberich
Member since: 21 September 2007
Total points: 13260 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Classical



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



The only way to resolve this issue, is to experiment, and see: "nothing ventured, nothing gained".



Many creative geniuses of the past have worked concurrently on more than one project.



Wagner had completed the first two of his Ring operas, and was working on the last,(the 3rd Act)of the third of the four, when he began "Tristan; completed it, then turned to "Die Meistersinger" and completed it, while continuing(in his spare time) to work on the Ring: fianlly finishing, after having worked on it for a period extending over 25 years.



So, I don't think you're necessarily being fickle; but I  would be prudent, and proceed with caution, monitoring your creative quality as you go along: if this suffers, then by all means stop, and resume work on only one novel; and at the most, to begin, wouldn't attempt working on more than three at the same time.



Interesting question; would like to be appraised as to how things turn out, sometime in the not too distant future.



Much good luck,



Alberich



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Well, Alberich, I had no idea that Wagner worked this way too...I'm tempted to say, "well, if a great composer can spread his creativity this way, then so can I..." but - well, I'm definitely not a towering genius like Wagner, and had better pace myself!

Hafwen x



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



megsamad...
Member since: 03 August 2008
Total points: 642 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Given your history with concurrent reading and your ability to multi-task, I'd say go for it.  Give each story a priority - make your "in-love" project #1, and make an effort to still give it most of your time, but have a couple projects on the back-burner for those moments you just need a break from "in love." :)



</answer>



<answer from>



TW K (May God Bless Us)
Member since: 22 January 2007
Total points: 28961 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Books & Authors



</answer from>



<answer>



I too get it that way. But I stick to my present work with all devotion. Two legs in two boats- and you go down! I dont want to do that. SO I just do what I am doing right now. You should write down all those thoughts and ideas so that you can use them later on - fill them with character and do the research they warrant. Here lies the problem, you cannot research all the different things at the same time. SO how can you write them? I, by now realise that writing should begin after a you have a good hang of all surrounding things. So working on projects which are much different is a very tough job, undoubtedly. You have 3 novels in your kitty, but were they all written simultaneously.



I guess, there are authors who work on several things at the same time. so you too can. But, personally I would prefer undivided attention to one main project. Just a personal thought.

Are you published, Hafwen x?



PS: This new Yahoo! Spell check shows that I have made 4 mistakes including one for TW, please excuse them!

TW K



</answer>

<answer>



I would go for it, there is nothing to lose. If it doesn't work then you can stop. I am writing 2 novels and about 15 short stories. It seems to be working out fine. As long as i'm organized!

I joined a writing community called http://www.chapteread.com. I think you might find it useful. They have a private writing area where you can organize your writings and its really easy! They have some great writing tools and posting features for getting critiques and reviews. [you don't have to post if you don't want to] The other writers give helpful advice. Worth checking out!



</answer>



<answer from>



RaeMen
Member since: 09 August 2008
Total points: 104 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I am working on lots of projects at the same time. I find that is the only way I can work. I tried fighting it, but that only made me block up ... argh!

So, this is what I do. I have read advice from other writers in lots of books and magazines and have found there are a lot of US out there!

I work extensively on one project to try and finish it. When another idea comes in I write it on a sticky note or in a notebook or something. Sometimes I go to that file and add the scene that has hit me. I can write for hours like that. When I wear myself out I take a break, then go back to The Main Project and progress on that.



Sometimes the main project is the only thing I work on - especially during the editing process. For some reason, it is difficult for me to be in editing mode and then switch to creative mode. Not sure why.



Just work with yourself. Work with your strengths. Lord knows those inspirational moments don't come oftern enough - work with it.



I have files and notebooks everywhere. The best thing I did for myself and my problem of being a Bear of Little Brain is to label EVERYTHING. That way I can have a hope of finding it ... I have three file cabinets ...

If you have three MS done I think that proves you have a little self-discipline! Yes. Keep it up! You are not alone



:o)

My Projects: two plays, three novels (four?), lots of short stories, lots of poems and the MS for my (hopefully) second published book Ghostly Galion and Beyond  ... My day job is writing for the Galion Inquirer Newspaper which has taught me to crank out stories much faster than I used to. But my dream is to get back to my creative writing full time. Some day. When some of the bills are paid!

Stay cool!
God Bless!
rachel



</answer>



<answer from>



Song bird
Member since: 28 September 2007
Total points: 4549 (Level 4)

<answer>



When I'm not working on my main opera, I write. (go figure)
I write emails, answer questions here, or work on other operas.
Even though technically, I'm still writing, I see it as taking a break.
There is nothing wrong with doing what you enjoy.
Besides, does your mind ever really off the other projects when your not working on it? Probably not. 
Writing is about inspiration and life experience, why not jot it down when it comes to you?
Best of luck.



Source(s):



Librettist

<question from>



ÐЯд¥έЙ
Member since: 07 May 2008
Total points: 2827 (Level 4)



</question from>



<question>



Why do some authors write under their own name and also a pen name?



Just wondering..
A recent example i've come across was Anne Rice, who wrote under at least 3 names... I believe that was because of the books themes (s&m erotica)



</question>



<answer from>



Hedge Witch
Member since: 08 August 2006
Total points: 17640 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



It just gives them the freedom to write different genres as different people so as to be able to not disappoint "devotees" who always buy "their" books.



</answer>



<answer from>



cakegirl
Member since: 21 January 2008
Total points: 7307 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Fanbase loyalty fears.

For some reason, a majority of general audience of readers prefer their authors to stay within one genre, one type of writing. They get "upset" when their favorite authors stray and do something different--even if it's children's books a couple times when they're mainly a horror author. This is particularly true of popular authors. So some have taken on other names so they might enjoy the thrill of the write and addition to the bank account without disgusting, demoralizing, annoying or otherwise losing some of the fickle fanbase they earned under the usual name.



</answer>



<answer from>



Tony
Member since: 15 January 2007
Total points: 4887 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



It gives them a chance to write in a variety of genres, and fans usually expect the same sort of book written by one person.  It's not an unusual practice--Agatha Christie did it, as did Dean Koontz and Victoria Holt.



</answer>



<answer from>



Gems =]
Member since: 11 February 2008
Total points: 252 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I guess the whole 'for a chance to write a different genre' thing but on some of Meg Cabot's books it will say Meg Cabot in big letters as the eye-catching name and then underneath inm smaller letters 'writting as Jenny Carroll' or some other pen-name =S



</answer>



<answer from>



XxAmilli...
Member since: 29 December 2006
Total points: 3182 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Books & Authors



</answer from>



<answer>



As some have said, they do it for genre purposes, but in Stephen King's case, he worte under a pen name to get past the "one book a year" rule.



</answer>



<answer from>



Poe Bird
Member since: 15 November 2007
Total points: 2067 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Well writing under a different pen name gives you a clean slate, you can be a new person again with a fresh audience. That can be rewarding in many ways, particularly if you want to see what sells, your novel or your name. A new name offers the old struggle of recognition.



Then again maybe it's for shame or embarrassment. I can imagine there are a lot of people who don't want to admit that this is the stuff they write.



And as always there's the idea that it can change your image. Female authors have been known to give themselves male pseudonyms in a bid to be treated equally by publishers. Maybe they don't like their name and want something that sounds appealing, something that matches their genre perhaps.



These are all bog standard though, I'm sure there are many more reasons for not wanting to give a real name.



I love that about Stephen King dodging the one book a year rule! That's great trivia :)



</answer>

<answer>



Heart of Darkness, by Joseph Conrad.

Literary masterpiece, with lots of intelligent insights into the human psyche and countless incidents of symbolism, metaphors and literary devices. But good God, how boring!

I studied this text for three years in a row, from A-Level to undergraduate, but although I cam to appreciate it as a great work, I would go to great lengths to avoid ever having to read it again!



</answer>



<answer from>



kelby_la...
Member since: 13 August 2007
Total points: 6549 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Moby Dick. there is a chapter on different species of whales, a large one. if you don't like the good old sea or sailing around you will find it as boring as i did.

To Kill A Mockingbird is boring, but people think it's great. Atticus coughs out a load of Chinese proverbs, Scout needs a good slap. The first half of the book is about Scout and Jem playing around in tyres. I'd skip that if I were you, if you actually read the book.

The Great Gatsby is brilliant. It's not very jolly but it's very evocative and poetic. Anyone who can't recognise that is ignorant.
The Metamorphosis is hardly boring. I imagine you didn't understand it.



</answer>

<question from>

<question>



Is this a good idea for a novel?



A mentally disabled man and his friend Tommy are both con men. Tommy dies or has he? the mentally disabled con man kidnaps a millionairs baby and the journey goes on from their. Showing whats inside his mind.



</question>



<answer from>



Ashley
Member since: 29 July 2007
Total points: 475 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



It could be excellent, but it all depends on how you write it, sounds like it'd be a novel where you'd have to get deep into your own character's minds to display the emotions and feel of what's going on, and sometimes that's hard for people to do. 
But all in all, it sounds like it could be a good idea.



</answer>



<answer from>



Charles V
Member since: 15 November 2007
Total points: 2971 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Books & Authors



</answer from>



<answer>



It's such a good story, Stephen King already did it as Richard Bachman.  The book is called Blaze.

I actually have several ideas for novels.

One is about a man who is a caretaker of a haunted hotel (I'll call it the Overlook) and gets snowed in with his family and goes crazy.

I even have a neat idea about a Pet Cemetary where the animals come to life, but I change the "C" in Cemetary to an "S."



I think those are pretty good ideas too!

Edit:

I didn't notice your user name until Kauna did!

Now I'm just in a Rage!  Why don't you go take a Long Walk out where they're doing Roadwork!  That's it, just get Running... Man!  You're walking a thin line... Thinner line in fact!



</answer>

<question from>

<question>



If you self-publish a book is it possible to get an ISBN?



</question>



<answer from>



princess...
Member since: 28 June 2007
Total points: 3380 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Books & Authors



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes, you can buy one.

If you self publish on something like Lulu, they have packages in which you get an ISBN.



</answer>



<answer from>



amandada...
Member since: 14 July 2007
Total points: 157 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes, you should be able to get one by contacting the ISBN organization



Source(s):



http://www.isbn.org/standards/home/isbn/...



</answer>



<answer from>



Henry Hedgehog
Member since: 17 April 2008
Total points: 2188 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes, a friend of mine has done that.

Unfortunately he didn't know that the last digit is a checksum, so the ISBN of his book is invalid.



</answer>

Maureen

Total points: 1369 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Hmm, I've never read these books myself, but after having a look on Amazon, they sound pretty cool (have just ordered them for myself!).

The author, Anne Bishop, also does another series, called the Ephemara series, which might interest you.



You might also try: Dark Desire (Love Spell Paranormal Romance) by Christine Feehan 
Undead and Unwed (Berkley Sensation) by MaryJanice Davidson 
The Three Sisters Island Triology, by Nora Roberts
Kitty and the Midnight Hour by Carrie Vaughn
Bitten by Kelley Armstrong
Touch the Dark by Karen Chance
Succubus Blues: 1 by Richelle Mead
Ill Wind: Book One of the Weather Warden Series by Rachel Caine
Neverwhere by Neil Gaiman

Happy reading!



Source(s):



www.amazon.co.uk
http://www.amazon.co.uk/another-shelf-ur...

<question from>



SCOTT N KYLIE
Member since: 19 June 2008
Total points: 151 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Writing a child's book.



I work in childcare and have done for 8 years.  I have ideas for childrens books that I have been thinking about for years. I want to know if I write the book and get pictures etc done how can I go about sending it to a publisher to read and to tell me if they think its any good?



</question>



<answer from>



Elj
Member since: 23 May 2007
Total points: 577 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



You just send it. You have to type it up a certain way (google how to) and then just look up publishing house addresses, and send it.

Most books don't get published though, so if I were you I'd write the book first, before you start even thinking about publishers.



</answer>



<answer from>



Siobhan
Member since: 18 June 2008
Total points: 213 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



My father is a writer and I know from him that if you just send it in to the publishers they probably wont even read it. What you need to do is go to a good source, maybe try to 'bump into' a writer at a festival or something, and ask them to read your work, they might well reccommend it to a publisher. Thats what happened to my dad.



</answer>



<answer from>



Maureen
Member since: 26 May 2006
Total points: 1369 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Hi there.  I'd recommend getting a copy of the Children Writers' and Artists' Yearbook, as this has loads of great advice in it, as well as the names and contact details for all the publishers and agents of children's books. 
Many publishers don't accept unsolicited manuscripts, so you may want to research which literary agents do, and send it there instead/as well as.



Also, it's a good idea, before you send it anywhere, to road test it on a few children first - if they don't like it, or get bored, etc, they will definitely let you know, and so you'll know whether you have a hit on your hands or not!
Best of luck!



Source(s):



Experience.
http://www.amazon.co.uk/Childrens-Writer...



</answer>



<answer from>



mike b
Member since: 23 June 2008
Total points: 506 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Write the book first.  Forget all about publishing and other machinations.  You must really want to write for writing's sake, not just some idea to make money.  If you've had these ideas for a long time, for goodness sake get them down on paper.  It's a lot of hard work, a lot of re-writes, etc., but get to it.
Good luck
Mike B



</answer>

<answer from>



lostprophets fan
Member since: 24 February 2008
Total points: 1448 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



you really don't want to but it - its only got a page on James and Sirius - no lily, look here it is ( from Mugglenet)



______________________________________...
The Story:
The speeding motorcycle took the sharp corner so fast in the darkness that both policemen in the pursuing car shouted,"Whoa!" Sergeant Fisher slammed his large foot on the brake, thinking that the boy who was riding pillion was sure to be flung under his wheels; however, the motorbike made the turn without unseating either of its riders, and with a wink of its red tail lights, vanished up the narrow side street.

"We've got 'em now!" cried PC Anderson excitedly. "That's a dead end!"

Leaning hard on the steering wheel and crashing his gears, Fisher scraped half the paint off the flank of the car as he forced it up the alleyway in pursuit.

There in the headlights sat their quarry, stationary at last after a quarter of an hour's chase. The two riders were trapped between a towering brickwall and the police car, which was now crawling towards them like some growling luminous-eyes predator.

There was so little space between the car doors and the walls of the alley that Fisher and Anderson had difficulty extricating themselves from the vehicle. It injured their dignity to have to inch, crab-like, towards the miscreants. Fisher dragged his generous belly along the wall, tearing buttons off his shirt as he went, and finally snapping off the wing mirror with his backside.

"Get off the bike!" he bellowed at the smirking youths, who sat basking in the flashing blue light as though enjoying it.

They did as they were told, finally pulling free from the broken wing mirror, Fisher glared at them. They seemed to be in their late teens. The one who had been driving had long black hair, his insolent good looks reminded Fisher unpleasantly of his daughter's guitar-playing, layabout boyfriend. The second boy also had black hair, though his was short and stuck up in all directions; he wore glasses and a broad grin. Both were dressed in t-shirts emblazoned with a large golden bird; the emblem, no doubt, of some deafening, timeless rock band.

"No helmet!" Fisher yelled, pointing from one uncovered head to the other. "Exceeding the speed limit by-by a considerable amount!" (In fact, the speed registered had been greater than Fisher was prepared to accept that any motorcycle could travel.) "Failure to stop for the police!"

"We'd have loved to stop for a chat," said the boy in glasses,"only we were trying--"

"Don't get smart-you two are in a heap of trouble!" snarled Anderson. "Names!"

"Names?" repeated the long-haired driver."Er-Well, let's see. There's Wilberforce...Bathsheba...Elvendork..."

"And what's nice about that one is, you can use it for a boy OR a girl," said the boy in glasses.

"Oh, our names, did you mean?" asked the first, as Anderson spluttered with rage."You should've said! This here is James Potter, and I'm Sirius Black!"

"Things'll be seriously black for you in a minute, you cheeky little-"

But neither James nor Sirius was paying attention. They were suddenly as alert as gundogs, staring past Fisher and Anderson, over the roof of the police car, at the dark mouth of the alley. Then, with identical, fluid movements, they reached into their back pockets.

For the space of a heartbeat both policemen imagined guns gleaming at them, but a second later they saw that the motorcyclists had drawn nothing more than-

"Drumsticks?" jeered Anderson. "Right pair of jokers, aren't you? Right, we're arresting you on a charge of--"

But Anderson never got to name the charge. James and Sirius had shouted something incomprehensible, and the beams from the headlights had moved.

The policemen wheeled around, then staggered backwards. Three men were flying-actually flying- up the alley on broomsticks-and at the same moment,the police car was rearing up on its back wheels.

Fisher's knee bucked; as he sat down hard; Anderson tripped over Fisher's legs and fell on top of him, as flump-bang-crunch- they heard the mean on brooms slam into the suspended car and fall, apparently insensible, to the ground, while broken bits of broomstick clattered down around them.

The motorbike had roared into life again. His mouth hanging open, Fisher mustered the strength to look back at the two teenagers.

"Thanks very much!" called Sirius over the throb of the engine."We owe you one!"

"Yeah, nice meeting you!" said James. "And don't forget: Elvendork! It's unisex!"

There was an earth-shaking crash, and Fisher and Anderson threw their arms around each other in fright; their car had just fallen back to the ground. Now it was the motorcycle's turn to rear. Before the policemen's disbelieving eyes, it took off into thin air: James and Sirius zoomed away into the night sky, their tail light twinkling behind them like a vanishing ruby.



</answer>

<question from>

</question from>



<question>



Are there Hercule Poirot pastiches?



I know many Sherlock Holmes pastiches. But never found one of Poirot.



</question>



<answer from>



S T
Member since: 23 September 2006
Total points: 3932 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



"The Sunningdale Mystery," an astonishing pastiche of the Old Man in the Corner tales by Baroness Orczy.

Very close in every way to the originals.



</answer>



<answer from>



Barbaros...
Member since: 28 September 2006
Total points: 890 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



There are, but the most recent and currently available Agatha Christie pastiches are more 'Ariadne Oliver' than 'Poirot' and are written by Gilbert Adair.

'The Act of Roger Murgatroyd'

'A Mysterious Affair of Style'

They are more pastiche than parody, but tread a delicate line: there are a lot of Christie in-jokes.

If those titles tickle your fancy, the third in the 'Evadne Mount' trilogy,

'And Then There Was No-one.'

is out early next year.

http://www.amazon.co.uk/s/ref=nb_ss_w_h_...



Source(s):



General reading.



</answer>

<question>



I recently wrote a story for my children and  my husband suggested i get it published how do i do this?



i was told self publication was expensive so i dont want to down that route, i live in northern ireland if that helps, thanks.



</question>



<answer from>



walker
Member since: 03 April 2008
Total points: 300 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



your story sucks, get a job like the rest of us



</answer>



<answer from>



BoxerBab...
Member since: 07 July 2008
Total points: 301 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



ignore walker what does he know!!! what you need to do is actually contact a publishers look on the internet or in a book for a name then either contact them by phone or e mail they will ask to see your draft do not be put off by getting a first refusal because it is common that you get first knock backs and you shouldnt just contact one publisher quite a few will c
give the chance of getting accepted and the right deal also i wish you every good luck and keep at it creative is good !!!!



</answer>



<answer from>



eva
Member since: 30 July 2008
Total points: 424 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



The very first step, and really the only important step for you, is to land an agent. After you get an agent, it's the agent's job to sell you and your story to a publishing house. (And they indeed will work hard for you, because they'll be soaking up a very good portion of your profits.) Don't even think abut self-publishing. Look up an agent.



</answer>

<answer from>



Why so SERIOUS?
Member since: 21 July 2008
Total points: 722 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



OH please, when are you going to STOP!
I am a 16 year old girl, I believe it is important for you to know my age and I don't like the Twilight series at all...

Stephanie Mayers just dreamed about Twilight and started writing, she didn't plan her plot, and mark my words this affected her plot severely. I took this from another user called Why So Serious ?... She\He said, there are no subplots, and I agree, there are no subplots to keep you interested, only one plot and that is BELLA LOVES EDWARD, EDWARD LOVES BELLA'S SMELL, JACOB LOVES BELLA, BELLA LOVES JACOB.. The END!
While J.K Rowling has an AMAZING plot, she created a new world, and do not forget her subplots, J.K's subplots are more complex than Stephanie's main plot for crying out loud!!!



Do not get me started on Stephanie's style of writing, although some may find it good, is very weak, she uses the words too often and she writes three chapters each time she wants to describe how good looking Edward is. She frequently adds a big word to simple sentences just to make it look more professional, and that's what middle schoolers do. Besides, I would like to know, what is so fascinating about her writing in first person, I've recently discovered that it only makes the book longer and more boring. I practically vomited at each and every sick, cheesy love scene, at each and every sickening love sentence from Edward to Bella "My life was moonless before you..... Or whatever" *VOMITS* CHEESY, SICK AND STUPID.. My LITTLE 5 year old sister could do better than that!.
Tell me now, can Stephanie's style of writing compare to J.K's captivating, amazing writing ? First of all, J.K started easy, so six year olds can read her books, then the books developed as each and every fan grew, the books grew with them NOT losing her amazing style, or the ability to suck the reader in. Second, J.K doesn't use words to often, she tends to vary her ways of describing something, and NONE of her dialog lines where THAT CHEESY. Third, did J.K ever write 3 long chapters on how Harry was the chosen one, that was mentioned in each book, right, but she NEVER SAID more than "The boy who lived", see, a simple sentence that takes only a tiny space in the book, not OH SO PERFECT incredibly long paragraphs on Edward's golden eyes, amazing beauty or any other sickening thing.

Stephanie's saga is basically for young 13 year olds who didn't read many books to be able to judge with a professional point of view, though I don't call myself a professional, nor am I belittling any reader. But seriously, she stole her plot basically, now if any of the Twilighters ever read a classic book, or at least any OTHER book they'd understand what I mean!. Stephanie's plot isn't new, well I don't call human\vampire affection new, that is used in many books. Since vampires are known to be very seductive and lustful. So this means her plot is COMMON, someone long ago had that idea, the idea was written in many other AMAZINGLY written books, so why waste the time and pathetically TRY to copy a plot in a very crappy way that makes the reader want to hurl ? Spare my please! Spare my precious time, and other people's time. Now, tell me have you EVER read any other plot that has, even the slightest similarity to Harry Potter? NO there are no plots like it, J.K worked 15 years on it!! 15!!. We have to appreciate her work, she not only made drafts, she made drafts for the drafts, now how can that NOT BE professional, how can we not take that for granted ? And look how her books turned out to be! Thank god her work payed off.

Stephanie's characters well not all of them, but most, are very annoying and rather dimwitted, I wish not to relate to them to tell you the truth. Starting with Bella, the sick dependent, whiny, pathetic, oh-I'm-going-to-die every three pages girl, and the oh-so-perfect-god, the amazingly handsome, brilliant, obsessive, ABUSIVE Edward.. The only good character she has is Jacob! And he is the one I was referring to when I said "Not all of them". Look at J.K's characters, NONE of them is useless, none of them was left behind, I could easily give up Ezmy from Stephanie's series, she was useless, Neville the one character we thought to be useless KILLED NAGINI, the Horcrux, that is DEVELOPMENT. Severus, look at Snape, he's a master piece no character was ever as complex as he is!! Dumbledore, we all thought we knew him so well, then she surprises us with that amazing past, and complexity! Voldemort, even Voldemort the villain, he too is a master piece, he is so complex, the way he became Voldemort is just enough to intrigue any reader!

What morals can you learn from Twilight, list ONE GOOD moral and I'll back out, let me tell you what I learned from it:

1- Females are stupid, whiny and they should have no dreams or ambitions, they should lust the perfect man and that's it. Look at Bella, she PROVES that.
2- You have two men fighting over you, then you have succeeded in becoming the perfect female, and may the dominant male win.. Like animals you see! Jacob and Edward fighting over precious Bella.
3- You should forget your friends, your loved ones for this so called perfect man. Look at how Bella treats her friends, how she sulks around the house because oh so poor Bella doesn't have a boyfriend.
4- Men should be abusive, controlling and obsessive to the point that they sabotage your car so you don't go out, to the point that they jump and look at you when you're sleeping.. To these creepy points, that scares me just by reading them. Thank you Edward!

Now let me tell you what I learned from Harry Potter, and you tell me which book has better morals:

1- Be trustful.
2- Care for your friends, family and loved ones.
3- Love is important, you should know that it's one of the important essentials of life, no one and I mean NO ONE can live, if they're not loved.
4- Be brave, you may be small, young, foolish and careless. BUT! You sure can do a change in life.
5- Do not let anyone or anything, drive you away from doing what is right, what you believe in.
6- Just look at the amazing, truly deep, meaningful things that Dumbledore says. Look at how many quotes you can take from his speech ?
7- Facing obstacles ?, do not let that get you down, no! Go and try again and again and again, until you do it right.
8- Study! It's important that you learn, not only learn how to 'fight evil' or 'magic unreal stuff' NO! Learn and be eager for learning, sure they teach magical subjects in Hogwarts, but please, have a brain.. That sends a message to all of us, saying learning is essential, important and most important you cannot live without it.
8- Sacrifice, you must favour others, over yourself.
So which one ?

That's my opinion! PLEASE RESPECT IT!!

Don't get me started on Breaking Dawn, yes I read it.. It doesn't deserve to be called a book!

Harry Potter cannot be compared to that, it's pathetic that Twilighters compare Twilight to Harry Potter, or even say that they are in the same league. It sickens me how some say that Stephanie can compare to J.K, I take that as wishful thinking...
I apologize if you find this rude, but it just irritates me so much, that people compare them. Again I apologize, I am sorry! :)



Source(s):



Again, I copied this from another question I answered.

<category>



Arts & Humanities



Books & Authors



</category>



<question from>



Windswept F
Member since: 05 February 2008
Total points: 398 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



How to get paid for what i do?



I'm a writer, i have some stuff published, but ned money. i don't know anyone, any sites, or companies that will pay me for wat i do. i don't have much and cant pay others, for publishing my work, is their any were that i can get my stuff published but get paid at the same time?



</question>



<answer from>



Tam
Member since: 02 July 2007
Total points: 2173 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



first and fastest would be to try to get some short stories or articles published.  There are online competitions and magazines as well - the pay's not large but its faster than book publication and if you do decide to move into book publication it looks good to mention previous paying work in the last paragraph of the query letter.  Also your local newspaper may pay by the article to free lance writers - do some research and give them a call.

In the book publishing world, the pay is better but it takes longer and the competition is harder.  Which is probably why the pay is better.  Short of postage, printing up a first chapter or two, and investing in some high quality professional letterhead - you shouldn't have to put out any money up front.  Self-publishing is when you pay someone to print your book.  Publishing professionally is when you find an agent to represent you and they don't get paid until they sell your book to a publisher and get a cut of your advance from the sale.  Real agents don't charge reading fees, real agents don't recommend book doctors, real agents don't ask for any money up front.  Real publishers pay YOU not the other way around.  You, as an author, should always be the one getting paid for your work, not the other way around.  Self-publishing is a horse of an entirely different color (paisley) for people that just want to see their book in print in small amounts to give to friends or for people with really amazing marketing skills - that's when you spend money.



</answer>



<answer from>



arty_gre...
Member since: 06 December 2006
Total points: 688 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



How about making an e-book in pdf file people are getting used to this form now, promote it on ebay and book forums.



</answer>

<question>

</question>



<answer from>



E'ntellignet Thinking
Member since: 18 April 2006
Total points: 15736 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



He thought that by maybe turning them in he'd get Luna back, because they kidnapped her(took her away) to the Malfoy's because he was telling people through his magazine to help Harry, which the Voldemort 'ministry' didn't like.



</answer>



<answer from>



tim | e [Harry Potter Expert]
Member since: 24 June 2008
Total points: 906 (Level 2)



Contributing In:



History



</answer from>



<answer>



Xenoplilius 'attempted' to turn Harry, Ron and Hermione in because he thought that if he captured the trio and handed them to the Death Eaters, he'd get Luna back who'd been kidnapped on the way home on the Hogwarts Express.

It's sort of sad... he was so dedicated to making out that Harry was innocent all along, but when his daughter was snatched, he cracked. 
If it wasn't for Hermione's quick thinking during the trio's escape at the Lovegood's, they'd have been goners.



Hope this helped!
-Tim
(Harry Potter Expert)



</answer>

<question from>



Mella
Member since: 20 February 2007
Total points: 82 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What's the deal with recommending classics?



Whenever anyone, teen or adult, here asks for book recommendations, there's always that someone who recommends Wuthering Heights or To Kill A Mockingbird  or other classics, and I don't understand why. They are not the best books, some of the language used is hard to comprehend. And yes I have read them, and hated them (except P & P).
Those books were groundbreaking at the time when they were written, but time has moved on. So why do you recommend them when there are better modern books , ones that actually deal with today's issues , not last centuries...?
Basically, why live in the past?



</question>



<answer from>



SHEBAM92
Member since: 05 June 2007
Total points: 4826 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Books & Authors



</answer from>



<answer>



Most of them have underlying meaning and depth, unlike a lot of newer books.



</answer>



<answer from>



asdf
Member since: 02 June 2006
Total points: 6127 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Books & Authors



</answer from>



<answer>



Well, obviously "time has NOT moved on" because they are still classics. And, just because the writing may be a little challenging doesn't mean that you should shy away from classics; most of them have the most original plots out there, compared to some of today's books that are just the same stupid story. 
I like to recommend them because some of the situations are the same, no matter what time period. To Kill A Mockingbird deals with racism: there is racism in today's world, is there not? 
The fact that you say you like Pride and Prejudice totally disproves your point, because you are saying that you enjoy the book, and possibly relate to the plot or to some of the characters. The way you feel about P&P is the same way other people feel about other classics.



</answer>



<answer from>



EvilEdd
Member since: 25 July 2006
Total points: 1073 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



An important part of the definition of a classic is that it survives the test of time. There are lots of good books that have been written more recently, but many (or even most) of them will be forgotten before too long.



</answer>



<answer from>



Leah M
Member since: 13 December 2006
Total points: 2594 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Oh dear, you clearly have been reading the wrong classics.  It is so not about living in the past.  Yeah, there's some good modern books around but you can't beat books like Pride and Prejudice, A Tale of Two Cities and Jane Eyre.  I'm with you on Wuthering Heights though, I hated that one.
It's not that they were particularly ground breaking at the time, I mean, look at Dickens, he wasn't particularly original, he was just class.  Even Shakespeare used a lot of old stories, he just told them really well.  A classic is a classic because it's as good today as it was however many hundred years ago it was written.
You should watch yourself asking questions like that, it makes you sound a bit of a prat



Source(s):



I've got an MA in English Literature and I'm not old.



</answer>



<answer from>



orionmob...
Member since: 06 August 2007
Total points: 7174 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



True classics are not classics simply because they are enjoyable books. What makes a book a classic is dealing with timeless themes that are still applicable to modern times.  The word choice of those authors may seem dated and thereby sometimes difficult to read, but the value of the book is still there both in entertainment value and educational or historical importance. There are many, many wonderful modern books to read, but not at the expense of never reading the classics. There is time for both!



</answer>



<answer from>



mearbnea...
Member since: 01 June 2008
Total points: 508 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Because people want to sound smart. If they recommend them, that's what it suggests.



</answer>

marti
Member since: 04 January 2007

Books & Authors

<answer>



That is your opinion. Not everyone loves the classics. But most people recognize their worth in the literary world. I agree that Wuthering Heights is awful. But To Kill A Mockingbird is an amazing book. Just because you  think modern books are better, doesn't mean everyone else agrees.

But what books are suggested depends on the question. If you want only modern books, say that. If the question doesn't have specific parameters, then we can suggest whatever we feel the asker might enjoy.



</answer>

<answer from>



laheira2
Member since: 25 September 2007
Total points: 16329 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Books & Authors



</answer from>



<answer>



1. If the question warrants a classic recommendation, why not recommend one if it matches what the asker is requiring.

2. One of the basic (and to me, most important) characteristics of a classic is its timelessness.  The fact that you, personally, may not like the narrative style or the subject matter of most classics that you have read, doesn't make those books irrelevant in present day.  A classic like Jane Eyre is a story of love and it sends a message of love and hope.  A classic like Frankestein delves deeply into complex filial relationships not to mention the issue of messing with the natural order of things and someone playing "God".  An adventure classic like The Three Musketters deals with notions such as friendship and loyalty.  Modern issues?  War and Peace deals with the issue of invasion and war.  Little Women deals with the issue of how war affects a normal family (it may be a family from a couple of centuries ago, but still, it doesn't make it less understandable).  A Tree Grows in Brooklyn deals with the matter of coming of age, all teenagers irrespective of when they were born, can relate to that.  On top of that poverty, an alcoholic parent, etc.  I could go on and on and on.



3. Not all modern literature is better than a classic.

If you don't like classics because you find them boring, fine.  If you don't like them because you can't fully relate due to the time in which the action of the story takes place, fine.  Reading is as much a matter of personal taste as anything else so reading preferences are highly subjective.  However, don't disregard classics just because you, personally, do not like them.



</answer>



<answer from>



Lazer Kidz©
Member since: 08 June 2008
Total points: 687 (Level 2)



Contributing In:



Books & Authors



</answer from>



<answer>



Because people are sick of everyone recommending Harry Potter and Twilight. There are thousands of books in the world and yet only a few become popular.



</answer>



<answer from>



MOM KNOWS EVERYTHING
Member since: 09 June 2006
Total points: 27024 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



Reading a Classic is not "living in the past".



Books are called classics because they have stood the test of time, and still have something to say to us.  To Kill a Mockingbird was written in my lifetime. In the opinion of a lot of people who have read a lot of books, it remains one of the best books about racism in America ever written.  And if you find its language hard to comprehend, you need to improve your language skills.



</answer>

idril

<answer>



erm, sor-RY but some classics are easy to read- to kill a mockingbird, as you mentioned, is one of them. the characters are wonderful, the plot is great. i think those things go beyond the time when it was written.



besides, they are beautifully written, some of them, and if you're a reader looking for a challenge and some depth, i think les miserables would be far more suited to you than twilight.



we're not 'living in the past', we're enjoying the fruits of what the past has given us in the form of great books.

<answer from>



Sweet Voltaire
Member since: 20 April 2008
Total points: 1787 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I honesty don't think they're that difficult.  The language really isn't that difficult unless we're talking like, Shakespeare or something.  But once somebody is in high school they really shouldn't even have much of a problem with Shakespeare as long as they are good readers and read it slowly.  I read Shakespeare in 8th grade and it was no biggie.  If we are asked to recommend good books, we won't recommend something like The Clique or Twilight or Gossip Girl, because those aren't good books.  But there are plenty of good modern books that I have recommended.  They include Memoirs of a Geisha, Running With Scissors, The Perks of Being a Wallflower, The Secret Life of Bees and many more.  But some modern books that I like are very inappropriatefor someone in middle school or around that age.  I won't recommend a book like Running With Scissors to a 12 year old, even though they'd be able to read the words.  It's still a great book, though.  =]



</answer>



<answer from>



The Schwa
Member since: 29 December 2007
Total points: 1847 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



That is a very uneducated way to look at it.  These classic books actually have depth and meaning.  They're books that deal with more than just the times, they deal with the human condition and deeper philosophical questions.  Books that are written lately are written to make money, not to explore, debate, imagine and wonder.  They're all about money, shallow relationship problems, sex and other things of the sort.  Basically, each book on the shelf lately is not so different from the one next to it, especially as it pertains to young adult sections.  That's why we read it, instead of things like "Twilight" and "The Clique" and "Gossip Girls".  You should try it too- just because you didn't like Wuthering Heights or To Kill a Mockingbird doesn't mean that you won't like other classics, like Jekyll and Hyde or Frankenstein.



</answer>



<answer from>



misslave...
Member since: 11 October 2007
Total points: 1341 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Books & Authors



</answer from>



<answer>



You know the addage "True Classics Never Go Out of Style"? Well, it's true. People recommend them as good books because despite the passing of time, people still consider them GOOD BOOKS. And I'm NOT saying this personally about you, but I think a lot of people find these books "hard to comprehend" because they are lazier readers compared to that time. It's worth the read; sometimes it just takes more time.



</answer>



<answer from>



caring carer
Member since: 01 May 2008
Total points: 9547 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Books & Authors



</answer from>



<answer>



I have to agree with EvilEDD on this one.  Classics have stood the test of time.  I enjoyed Jane Eyre as a 9 year old.  I still love it even now at nearly 40 years later.



Todays modern books will be mostly forgotten in years to come and can you seriously see the Twilight series being around in 200 years time?



If you find the lauguage difficult can I suggest what I have done in the past - listen to the audio version and if its unabridged read the book along with the audio, this makes it easier to follow.

<answer>



To Kill A Mockingbird is dull.
Don't be so ignorant- clearly they are some of the best books, hence the popularity. You not understanding them does not make them bad books. It means you need to work on your vocabulary.
And you're naive to say that classics only deal with 'last century's issues' or 'uncool' things- Lolita, considered a classic, is about paedophilia and is certainly relevant today.
Pride and Prejudice is good but it was never groundbreaking :)

A lot of modern books are based on classics, except dumbed down. Which books do you like, may I ask?

Basically get your head out of the sand and invest in a dictionary. You not understanding them is due to your ignorance/lack of interest, not to them being bad books.

EDIT: You're wrong for saying people don't think the same as they did back then. It is society that thought differently, not people.
They are books, okay? Just as one cannot shun all modern books just because they didn't like/relate to one, you can't dismiss all the classics simply because you didn't relate to some. Why not try modern classics then- written in the 20th century? You might feel more of a rapport with them.



</answer>

I'm glad you asked this question because it seems to me like people are always knocking others for reading things like Twilight or Harry Potter, saying we should read classics, not trashy novels but at the end of the day, a book is not just for educational purposes, but enjoyment.
I do like some historical novels, like the memoires of a geisha and others like that. I love the Twilight and Harry Potter series' and am very fond of Malorie Blackman. 
I think it just depends on how you see reading. Some see it soley for enjoyment, others do not.
People shouldn't knock stories that are written now because after another century or whatever, they may well become classics too.
I personally learn more from reading modern books that older books because I relate better to it. People don't think the same now as they did when many classics were written therefore some of the points they make are not strictly relevant any more.

<answer>



I can't stand most modern books. It takes some time for me to foment with an author I like. I'm no bestselling author myself, but some of the tripe they pump out today can't keep me for more than a few pages. I've tried, I've really tried.



I started reading the classics when I was a kid, I wanted to know what all the fuss was about. I got through a few things, 20,000 Leagues Under The Sea, The Secret Garden, The Arabian Nights. Maybe all that influenced me for later. I don't have a hard time reading through the language, and when I have had trouble I discovered it passes once you get into the story.



To me, there's more story there because it wan't just a story. I can't speak for all classics as I still have a long way to go, but what I can say is that they have something that's missing from most of today's novels: soul. They are more real to me than just about anything else that sells today. They don't just say what goes on they leave the reader to think. They capture humanity in its essence perfectly, and people recognise that and cling to it. Some people have the power to put into words what others may spend a lifetime trying to explain. The story may be good, but it's when it speaks to you that counts.



Don't get me wrong, some things that are made today are good, but they're not great.



EDIT - I think The Schwa hit the nail on the head!



</answer>
