<question>



Responses to 'the turn of the screw'



howdy, i am researching gothic literature, in particular Henry James's Turn of the Screw. Just wondering that if you have read it, what have you thought of it. Do you think the Governess is insane and quint and miss jessel are figmants of her imagination or arer they real?



</question>



<answer from>



Bilbo
Member since: 08 November 2007
Total points: 15485 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Homework Help



</answer from>



<answer>



This is Henry James doing Gothic rather than the real thing, but none the worse for that. There are various allusions to other works such as Ann Radcliffe's Mysteries of Udolpho. Does she see them - we have to believe she thinks she does for the story to work. I don't think we can ever be sure - but the sense of malevolence seems real enough.



</answer>



<answer from>



Fortunat...
Member since: 18 July 2008
Total points: 299 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I think that the lure of the story is finding out whether the Governess is delusional or the children really communicate with ghosts - but it is purposefully never resolved. Every event can be explained either way - the children are seeing things or the Governess is stark mad - and no authoritative explanation is ever given as to what REALLY happened.

It's a great text to look at "unreliable narrators" and "narrative framing". Throughout the whole text we are asking ourselves "Is the governess reliable or not? Can we believe what she is telling us?", and that's the whole point of reading on - to find out! Sometimes we think "ah ha - the children are definitely in touch with the supernatural", and then on the very next page we think "ah ha - the governess is definitely bonkers"! Yet we never find out, because no reliable voice says "this is what was happening all along".



This is where narrative framing comes in. If I remember rightly, it's narrated by a(n unknown) female, who is listening to a man, who in turn is reading a letter written by the Governess. Therefore the text has two frames. The story, in letter form, is being read by a man, so this is the first frame: the Governess's story is within the man's story. But it is someone else who tells us that the letter is being read by a man, and so this is the second frame: the man's story is within the narrator's story!  So we have to think to ourselves, "Who is actually speaking here? Is it the Governess through her letter? or is it the man, who might be saying something slightly different to what is written down? or is it the narrating woman, who has forgotten or has changed what the man has said?!" It all gets very complicated... which is why it's so damn good!

And here's an interesting little thought experiment: how would we interpret the story if, at the end, we returned to one of the frames? If we went back to the man after he'd read the letter and he said, "And since then the Governess has been locked up in a mental asylum", we would surely think, "ah yes, she must have been bonkers then". Or if we returned to the female narrator and she said, "after my friend had read the letter I went to visit the actual house, and I'm sure I saw one of the ghosts by the lake", we would surely think, "ah yes, I knew all along that the children were actually seeing ghosts!". This helps us see the importance of narrative framing and unreliable narrators. The text just ends at the end of the letter, and so we don't return to one of the frames. There is no authoritative voice to say "here's what's happening, you can believe me".

Phew... that was a bit of a spiel. Hope it was of some use to you!



</answer>



<answer from>



jenkin19...
Member since: 01 December 2006
Total points: 7960 (Level 5)



</answer from>

</answer>

<answer>



The titles of four of James Herriot's books remind me of an old Anglican hymn.

The books remind me of beautiful, rolling hills, a skilled veterinarian who was both humble and humorous and often laughed at himself, all types of animals with varying degrees of ills healed by James Herriot and some of the specific stories in the books.

It reminds me of a bull with sunstroke, a horse that picked James Herriot up by the collar, a dog so badly injured that nobody but James Herriot could have saved his life - or even tried to, a woman who "made a difference" in the life of a sweet but badly abused dog and many other things.

All Things Dull and Ugly



All things dull and ugly,
All creatures short and squat,
All things rude and nasty,
The Lord God made the lot.

Each little snake that poisons,
Each little wasp that stings,
He made their brutish venom.
He made their horrid wings.

All things sick and cancerous,
All evil great and small,
All things foul and dangerous,
The Lord God made them all.

Each nasty little hornet,
Each beastly little squid--
Who made the spikey urchin?
Who made the sharks? He did!

All things scabbed and ulcerous,
All pox both great and small,
Putrid, foul and gangrenous,
The Lord God made them all.

Amen.

Music: Traditional
Arranged by: John Du Prez

<answer>



Think others have corrected your spelling here, but the book is called "The Tales of Beedle The Bard" due for release early December 08 in 3 different editions. US, UK & Collectors edition which is supposed to replicate the handmade book that was sold last year for almost £2million!

It doesn't actually have Harry Potter in it, though one of the stories it contains was in the last book of the harry potter series. It's a collection of wizarding tales, with strong moral guides, rather like aesops fables.
From reading reviews some of the stories will be quite dark compared with HP, though in the standard editions each story is accompanied by an analysis from Albus Dumbledore!

What the serious Harry Potter Fan should be looking out for is a coppy of the Harry Potter prequel, a short story starring Harry's dad. Though as only 10,000 copies have been published it will be difficult to get hold of a copy.



Source(s):



http://www.squidoo.com/Harry_Potter_Preq...
http://www.squidoo.com/tales_of_beadle_t...



</answer>

<answer>



Yes, I have some ideas, but you can't have them. Sorry. If you are writing for your own entertainment, then you can try writing fanfiction or something. If you are actually trying to write a story, then you need to come up with your own story. There are 2 parts to being an author in my opinion: thinking of a plot and writing the plot. You can't steal someone else's idea and call it your own.



</answer>

PogoStar

<answer>

<answer from>



War Games AM
Member since: 08 October 2007
Total points: 7117 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



If you can't come up with an idea, you won't be able to come up with the story.  That, and why would you want to use someone else's idea?  Or why would you expect someone else to let you use their idea?

I've just spent the last 3 hours fleshing out an idea for my next novel.  I've actually been working on it for almost a week, and will probably spend another week on it before I'm ready to start writing chapter 1.  The idea is part of the work of writing a story.  Don't expect others to do it for you, to let you use THEIR hard work, and for that matter...don't sell yourself short!  Come up with your own idea, and write it!



Source(s):



Writer



</answer>

<question from>



Derek
Member since: 14 July 2008
Total points: 31 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Has anyone ever used the book 'The magic of making up'? if so, did it work for you?



</question>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



I've used the book and set up a site for people to get a better idea of what's in it.  You can preview the book at http://www.tw-jackson.com

It's not going to work for everybody, and I don't think it claims to do so.  Some relationships are too far along to reconcile, others have problems that are too fundamental -- meaning you're just wrong for each other.



But a lot of people, over 6,000, have successfully used the book to get back together.  You won't know if it works for your particular situation unless you give it a try.

Best of luck to you.



Source(s):



www.tw-jackson.com



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



Hey Derek,

I find myself pretty confident answering these questions now.. I used the Magic of Making up months ago as a last resort to save my marriage.

To my success it WORKED!  Boy was I excited, everything paid off.  I had to come to a decision, pay the $39 for a book that guaranteed to work, or waste hundreds on marriage counseling.

The choice is yours but I chose choice #1.

To get a full review of the book visit www.comegetanswers.com

Good luck Derek!

Thanks



Source(s):



www.comegetanswers.com



</answer>






<original file>index;_ylt=At3BjVb86wTuQAwa4A1CF.7sBwx4cce.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk40867.txt</current file name>



<category>



Arts & Humanities



Books & Authors



</category>



<question from>



!@#$
Member since: 09 March 2008
Total points: 361 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Of Mice And Men essay for course work?



I Have To Write An English Essay On Of Mice And Me( the novel). I Have To Answer The Question: "The character lennie epitomises Steinbeck's message: no matter how hard we dream. reality always finds a way to shatter our fantasy" how far agree with this statement. What Am I supposed To write??



</question>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



That´s a tricky one as I am not sure Lennie epitomizes Steinbecks message.If indeed there is a message at all.But then you won´t get points for arguing with the teacher.It´s a simple tale.And Lennie is a simple character.When he talks of living off the fat of the land.He believes it.No fantasy.He is a realist.He touches pretty girls hair because they are pretty.No dream.Now the problem is Man..If that is reality..so be it.It is people that destroy Lennie.Fair play he strangles a girl.And so  George shoots him
,Now the title comes from a line from a Jon Donne poem which goes something like:The best laid plans of mice and men go astray...So again it not a fantasy but a plan.If any one knows better it should be George.He is the dreamer.Getting a little stake together to buy land when it ends in disaster every time.But to keep Lennie happy he tells him of a glowing future with rabbits and puppies and of course..the fat of the land.So in short tell your teacher they have it wrong.



Source(s):



The book



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



Well, you need a thesis statement that argues your point,  Are you going to agree with the question or not?  If you are, you could talk about George's realization that he cannot protect Lennie and his decision that he is better off dead.  In a way it's a shattering of his dream of them living on a homestead together, and is symbolic of all the characters' shattered dreams,



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



English essays = LOADS of writing! Plan the essay out; point example explain - make a point, use a quote from the story to back it up, and explain it :) You need one of these for each point the essay is worth. With these questions, they don't really want to know what you think straight away - you will need to argue both points, with a summary of what you think at the end. Don't forget an introduction consisting of your translation of the essay question. Have fun ;)



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



Of Mice and Men is a classic, and also one that I have never read, though it is on my list to read this winter.  However, there are numerous free on line resources that can help you with your study of this novel, most of which analyze the story, discuss themes and symbolism and other literary devices, and give character sketches.  If you do a search you will find many helpful resources.  Additionally hundreds of questions have been asked here on Y!A about Of Mice and Men so do a search for it in the Yahoo Answers search window and you will find lots of Q’s and A’s that should help you.



Source(s):



http://www.sparknotes.com/lit/micemen/
http://www.gradesaver.com/classicnotes/t...
http://www.lausd.k12.ca.us/Belmont_HS/mi...
http://www.universalteacher.org.uk/prose...



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>

</answer>

</answer from>



<answer>



Have you read the book? You're writing an opinion based essay so you will need to have a good grasp of what happened in the novel.  You might skim through the book with the parts about Lennie in your mind and write down what happens to him throughout the novel.  You basically just need to decide if you agree or disagree with that statement and then pull examples from the book that prove your point.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



I am an English teacher, and you should not have to post this kind of question.  What is your own English teacher up to?  You should know this book back to front.  I could write the essay for you, but I'm not going to.  When I teach any text, whether it's GCSE or A-level, I make absolutely sure that every single one of my students knows the book back to front, and they will not be fazed by any exam question.  They all pass with an A.  Speak to your teacher or your head or anyone who can find out why you have to post this kind of question here.



</answer>

I know you can read a lot of Classic Literature on the Internet legally - there would also be modern book sites but often the books are not legal so I would suggest you to avoid these.

Among the classic literature part, you can try out the following resource which has a really good collection:
http://www.webliterature.net/literature

Among the classic books, girls tend to love works by Jane Austen, the Bronte sisters and Lucy Montgomery to name a few - so chances are that you might also love many of them.

<answer>



There are some copies for sale on abebooks so you can find the bibliographic details on there. I cannot find any information on the author though, except that some copies of the book were published under his full name which was Edward George David Child.

<answer>



My mom and I enjoyed the Dark Towers series.



"In the story, Roland is the last living member of a knightly order known as gunslingers. The world he lives in is quite different from our own, yet it bears striking similarities to it. Politically organized along the lines of a feudal society, it shares technological and social characteristics with the American Old West, as well as bearing magical powers and the relics of a highly advanced, but long vanished, society. Roland's quest is to find the Dark Tower, a fabled building said to be the nexus of all universes. Roland's world is said to have "moved on," and indeed it appears to be coming apart at the seams — mighty nations have been torn apart by war, entire cities and regions vanish from the face of the earth without a trace, time does not flow in an orderly fashion; even the sun sometimes rises in the north and sets in the east. As the series opens, Roland's motives, goals, and his age are unclear, though later installments shed light on these mysteries."

- http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Dark_To...



Source(s):



Listened to a lot of Stephen King books on tape



</answer>

persipho...
Member since: 27 February 2007
Total points: 150467 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Books & Authors



</answer from>



<answer>



No dear, I don't win. I read this book over two weeks ago and not once did I ever say a single word to any of you about what was in it. I read your theories and chuckled, but I never answered them. I could have, but when I finished writing my review, I tore my ARC (they are softcover) into pieces and shredded it. I shared with nobody.



Ed isn't what you thought he was. He wanted to abort his own child. Then he tried to pawn it off on Jake. What is truly sad is Jake was a decent guy and Stephanie chose to make him the second pedo in the wolf clan. That is disgraceful. The high school was filled with girls he could have imprinted on. Not a baby.



I did not want it to come to this. I even wrote and asked Yahoo personally to shut this forum down tonight. I have been trying to prepare you for this. How many times have I said paper and ink. That is all they are. And it's true. That is all they are. Stephanie Meyer is on drugs. She is the one who loses. I doubt her publisher will release Midnight Sun now. And how are you going to feel when the movie is bad too?



I drove to B and N tonight. I saw kids in limousines in full prom regalia. It cost some parents big money for this party tonight. And it hurts me that she let everyone down. How many times have you heard me say I treat being an author responsibly? I care about what people think and how they react to my work.



And you haven't heard me say a single word about the fact that I donated stories to an anthology raising money to rebuild libraries in New Orleans, have you? How do you think I feel knowing all this money was spent on this trash when it could have gone to help the libraries?



There are no winners here. There is only one loser -- Stephanie Meyer. Now take the book back and get your money back. Send a message to her that you aren't supporting her drug habit and that her book sucks. Pax-C



</answer>

<question>



Most Popular Fairy tales?



what are the 10 most popuar fairy tales?
including ones like the ugly duckling? xxx



</question>



<answer from>



Marie
Member since: 16 June 2006
Total points: 2609 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Books & Authors



</answer from>



<answer>



Cinderella (One of the oldest fairy tales ever told)
Sleeping Beauty
Beauty and the Beast
Peter Pan
Hansel and Gretal
Aladdin  (Was included in 1001 Arabian Nights)
Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs
Little Red Riding Hood
The Three Little Pigs
Goldilocks and the Three Bears



Possible even Rapunzel
Rumpelstiltskin
Jack and the Bean Stock
The Princess and the Pea
The Emperors New Clothes

The Most Popular Fairy tales tend to have been changed and popularized by Disney. They generally don't resemble the original outside of basic story premise. It wasn't until The Grimm Brothers and Hans Christian Anderson cleaned them up that they lost their gruesomeness. They used to give Hostel and Saw a run for their money.

What tales are most popular to day is not necessarily what was popular 10 or 20 years ago.



Source(s):



http://www.rickwalton.com/freeu/brains/f...



</answer>



<answer from>



sparkey
Member since: 11 November 2007
Total points: 12427 (Level 6)

<question from>



Black Baribe
Member since: 11 July 2008
Total points: 73 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Tell me what you think of my love story?



Story of...



The two spy's who fell in love...

I was 17 then and living in england. I was staying with my gradmother, While my mother was living peacefull in america. One morning I lift for school. And I remember coming home! My gradmother came near me crying and said... You'r mother is in trouble. Then I knew I had to fly to the united states to save my mom. So I grab all my stuff, got on my first 232 airlines and took off. As soon as I arive! I knew I had to keep a clear eye for any signs of danger. I could not trust anyone!  I grab all my stuff and I hop on to a cab. While I was in the cab. The driver who kept looking at me trew his review mirror. I had to keep my cool. He could be trouble. Soon he drop me off at near the stree not too far from where my mother would stay! I pay the guy and he drove off. I ran down the street to my mother house, hoping to fine a clue. As soon as I got there. I went inside! I look around, then soon I found a letter saying... 
"If you want your mother alive! Bring me the blue stone before 9pm TONIGHT!!!!!"  The blue stone I though!
The blue stone was the blue ball neckless that cost millilons that my mother sent to me as a birthday gift. They need it that stone to take over the world. 
Before I lift! I seen a wallet on the ground that they had drop after they kidnap my mother. Inside the wallet was a picture id. The Id almost look like the driver who I was with inside the cab. Soon I knew this was my guy to grab. 
I left the house and I went down to my own friend that I knew who can help me fine out where to fine this guy I must kill. I arive to my friends house, told her what happen. She grab out her labtop and track down who he is. She got everything on info. I knew he was mines now. So then I head downtown. I went inside into a bathroom and put on a fake wig and clothes ware so noone will know who i was. I sat down, was reading a babys book of todays world. Soon I seen him walking! Black suit, shades, and good looking hair. I could not let him think I was onto him. So I acted like I was just heading somewhere else. I chew a peace of gum, trew it on the ground, hoping he step on it. He step on it! And now I could track down his foot prints on my eye glood ware that can see footprints. I flow his foot prints, seeing where it lead. He got near a place where the foot prints end. I felt I was goin to lose him! So i started to rush, hoping to catch up with him.  But as soon as I got there! COUGHT!!! He got me!! I froze up! Knowing if I dont panic, he wont atatck. He look at me with a straght face! Shook his head, and grab a picture of him from my pocket, and he grab a picture of me from out of his pocket! And hold them together. He smiled a bit! As for me all I could do is just look at him, I did not take a punch or even say a word. He just grab my hand and said...go fine your mother!
Then I said... Don't you have her?
He laugh and said... "My dear, I'm a spy too! I was sent to fine her as well. But you are doin it the wrong way. 
And I stap and said... Oh yeah! Like how would you know how to fine her?? 
Then he said... "How about I take you out to dinner and will fine out.



(Sorry Im goin to skip a few parts. cut this short!)



Soon me and him started to date. Then he made the most dangerest thing of all...
We started to marry.



And yup thats the story....what you think?



</question>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>

<answer>



you have MANY errors and its very hard to read. 
Your grammar needs improvement, you use many ! and . when they aren't necessary. 
You have a lot of misspelled words.
The story moves too fast and is flat.
You jump from past tense, to present, to past again, which makes reading it very confusing. 
Your characters are flat. You don't tell the reader much about them. We don't even know the main character's name. 
You have to do more showing. You tell to much. Also, explain a little more. Don't expect the reader to know everything. You can't make them guess as to why something happens.



Sorry if i sound a little harsh. I'm just trying to help out. By knowing and fixing your errors, you become a better author. You learn from your mistakes and therefore grow.

<question from>



tempest
Member since: 02 August 2008
Total points: 113 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



I'm writing a book and need to know something about book formats?



hey,
I am writing a book on Microsoft Word in A4 paper.
In A4 sized paper and font 12, the total amount of pages is 30.
Number of words is 14,746

How many pages would this be in an average book sized pages?
PS this is not the full book ,just where I got to up till now
thanks



</question>



<answer from>



princess...
Member since: 28 June 2007
Total points: 3384 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Books & Authors



</answer from>



<answer>



Measure a book. Put the size into the custom paper size on microsoft word and it'll get formatted into that size.

But roughly speaking, say about 4-500 words a page.

But you don't really need to know that if you have a word count.

Know that roughly a novella is anything from about 12,000-40,000. A novel is about 40,000 + though that would be the absolute minimum. An average novel is around 75-85000 words.



</answer>



<answer from>



hlnlange
Member since: 24 November 2006
Total points: 2766 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



If you do the layout in an A5 format, it will come to about 68 pages.  Remember, a printed book doesn't look good if you do the font in 12 so i will suggest you do the font in 10.5.



</answer>



<answer from>



Sela C
Member since: 22 June 2008
Total points: 2930 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Books & Authors



</answer from>



<answer>



Font: Courier New 12
Double Space
1" (2.5cm) margins all around

A manuscript page equals roughly 250 words -- or that's what's assumed, no matter the actual number.



For now, you don't need to worry about headers and page numbers, etc. But this format will tell you roughly where you are. A novel of 100K words will equal 400 ms (manuscript) pages.

Most novels run between 80K-120K, depending on genre and publisher specifications. Knowing what you're aiming for -- doing some advance research -- will help keep your story arc in control and on track. There's no point trying to submit a 120K romance novel. No one will take it. On the other hand, most fantasy publishers want something longer than 80K.



Source(s):



Published author



</answer>

<original file>index;_ylt=AvYAebx7MDAK50nmJpXL2_vsBwx3c2e.html</original file>

Arts & Humanities

<question from>



Andrew W
Member since: 23 June 2007
Total points: 96 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



How do you copyright pictures and stories?



</question>



<additional details>



I live in the UK



</additional details>



<answer from>



Ravyn
Member since: 20 March 2008
Total points: 821 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Here's the answer from the U.S. Copyright Office:

The way in which copyright protection is secured is frequently misunderstood. No publication or registration or other action in the Copyright Office is required to secure copyright. There are, however, certain definite advantages to registration.

Copyright is secured automatically when the work is created, and a work is "created" when it is fixed in a copy or phonorecord for the first time. "Copies" are material objects from which a work can be read or visually perceived either directly or with the aid of a machine or device, such as books, manuscripts, sheet music, film, videotape, or microfilm. "Phonorecords" are material objects embodying fixations of sounds (excluding, by statutory definition, motion picture soundtracks), such as cassette tapes, CDs, or LPs. Thus, for example, a song (the "work") can be fixed in sheet music ("copies") or in phonograph disks ("phonorecords"), or both.

If a work is prepared over a period of time, the part of the work that is fixed on a particular date constitutes the created work as of that date.

Here are more opinions and answers from other FAQ Farmers:



* To enforce a copyright in U.S. federal court, it must first be registered, as proof of ownership, and a copy deposited with the Library of Congress. Copyrights registered early do have the benefit of certain statutory fines, if an infringement is proven.



* It is sometimes asserted that: "To a large extent this depends on the laws of the country you live in. Copyrighting something is just a way of you asserting that you came up with an idea first. The simplest way to do this is to post a copy to yourself. The envelope will bear a postmark, which will bear up in court as the date you invented/wrote something, so long as the envelope is still sealed. However, it's better to try the Patent Office. There, for a small fee, you can patent inventions, and anyone coming up with a similar idea can then realize straight away that they are in breach of copyright."



However, this contains many common mis-perceptions and inaccuracies. For example, international copyright law is largely harmonious, under various conventions that are adopted in hundreds of countries.



* Under U.S. federal law: "In no case does copyright protection for an original work of authorship extend to any idea, procedure, process, system, method of operation, concept, principle, or discovery, regardless of the form in which it is described, explained, illustrated, or embodied in such work."



* Posting or mailing a copy of something to yourself is NOT an effective way to protect your IP (Intellectual Property). And only rarely would such a method ever hold up in court. File an application with the US Copyright Office, if you think you would benefit from having a registration. (See link to the right.) Find out what category your IP falls under - and not all things are eligible for copyright protection (ideas and titles of songs, stories or books, among other things), check the regs for this too - so you can figure out which application form you will need to fill out and send in, although it is not always simple. Applicants must follow the instructions precisely. Filing fees vary so check with the Copyright Office for current prices. Be prepared to wait for verification that your copyright has been approved and registered. ''Sometimes'' this can take months depending on how busy the office is at any given time, for your particular type of works.



A patent is not the same thing as a copyright as an earlier answer seems to imply. Patents and copyrights do not protect the same things. Nor do trademarks. And sometimes a combination of patent, copyright and trademark protection may be necessary to more fully protect your IP. If you are not familiar with the terms copyright, trademark, patent, service mark, visit the US Patent and Trademark Office (USPTO) and the Copyright Office's websites and read up on the differences. Keep in mind that copyright protection isn't what it used to be thanks to the internet, file-sharing and widespread ignorance or disregard of the laws pertaining to ownership of IP. Patents are a little easier to enforce because patents apply to specific inventions which are more tangible than songs, poems, stories, logos, etc. And having a copyright on file does not mean you can't lose a court case over ownership of and right to use IP, but it certainly gives you an edge and added protection.



A lawsuit for patent infringement can cost millions of dollars and take years to complete.



* Copyright protection, if any, is automatic and immediate, and any unauthorized copies are infringements. Patent protection only exists after a patent application is reviewed and a patent is issued, and a patent cannot be infringed until then. It often takes years to have a patent issued (hence, "patent pending"). Trademark protection is also "automatic", from the time of "first use", but only for a limited scope, and a trademark registration provides valuable benefits.



* To prove copyright infringement you must have a registered copyright and prove the defendant had access to your work, copied it without authority, and that the copying was substantial.



</answer>



<answer from>



durulz20...
Member since: 30 March 2006
Total points: 3249 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



In the UK copyright exists the moment the work is created.
The old days of posting a copy to yourself, or a bank manager (and leaving it unopened, to prove the date on which you created it) are long gone.
The moment you write something, or take a picture, copyright is automatically yours (unless you sign copyright over to someone else). It's even easier nowadays, since computers automatically save the date on which the file was created.
Copyright exists after death as well. Not sure if it's 50 or 75 years after death.
So, anyway, you don't have to copyright either pictures or stories - the copyright is automatically yours!



</answer>



<answer from>



zainab gangaali
Member since: 18 September 2006
Total points: 1711 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



by appliying to the original owner seeking for permission to use his/her product clearly stating what you really wants to use for.  good luck



Source(s):



personal experience



</answer>



<answer from>



Henry Hedgehog
Member since: 17 April 2008
Total points: 2188 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



In the UK, a work is protected by copyright automatically.

However, you might like to let people know by adding a copyright statement to it. This is what I use:



(C) 2008 Henry Hedgehog. All rights reserved.

The (C) should be a proper copyright symbol if possible.



</answer>

<question>



I just wrote this now, please judge it, thanks in advance.?



Be still child, do not cry
Do not let them find us, we come too far
Life will be better, that I promise
The fields will be greener, we will learn to smile

The men are coming child, please do not cry
They come with their dogs, as though to hunt 
They fear they have lost, those to earn their wealth
Shining their torches, nearer they’re getting

Don’t be scared child, please don’t be
I am but all you have now
Your mother you’ll meet up in the skies one day
She is up there guiding us through

Keep still child, for goodness sake keep still
The dogs might smell us, lord don’t let them find us
Master will but all forgive
To run from him, I have known some beat to death

Close your eyes child, the time had come
We have to move, slowly, deeper in the reeds
The men are near, they will find us
We shall move, more into the water

Close your eyes child, please close your eyes
We will move to the deeper water child
The men are yards away, their dogs at their heels
We have to move now, into the cold waters

Oh my child, say a prayer
It will soon be over, look above
Your mother’s guiding, she will keep us safe
Under the water child, we need to go

Take a deep breath child, we need to hide
The dogs will not smell us there
Under the water, we shall be safe
It will be cold, but be patient

Shh, do not shake child, don’t be scared
The dogs have retreated, the men have followed
Wait here for a while we shall child
When their lights fade, we will move

Oh my child, look at them go
I know it’s cold, but stay still for a while
They have gone, but they are still searching
In a bit child, we shall move

Look beyond child, over the bridge
Freedom is near, we shall go
We will be free child
Fear we shall know no more



</question>

well, for a start your title is wrong 'just love to write' does not make sense, if you're a good writer at least use proper English! 'who just loveS to write' and you already have a '.' (full stop) so there is not need for the '?' well its a question so there was no need for the full stop!

<answer from>



Chris S
Member since: 08 October 2006
Total points: 1544 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I am a author of a published book. A lot of the answers here are right but so off-putting. Have fun and experiment. A great book to learn from is BBC Bitesize Revision KS3. It is a fantastic resource that will help you to bring even more life to your characters and plot and structure of your writing.

Try to edit your work a bit more. Think of it as a block of stone and like a sculpter you must carefully chip away or edit it to produce something creative and readable. Writing is not so difficult. What is difficult is editing, making certain it all makes sense in the right context. It takes a keen eye for detail. Read the words aloud if you can and re-read, re-read and re-read again until you cannot see or hear anymore mistakes and reading it flows and flows and you are gripped by it.

Good luck!



Source(s):



Author of Chris Sullivan's Simple Effective Way to Control Cannabis
http://www.amazon.co.uk/Sullivans-Simple...



</answer>



<answer from>



manga freakxx
Member since: 03 June 2007
Total points: 5014 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



That's a great ambition.
Now, your poem... I'm not a poem expert, I'm a fiction writer, but I know how poems are supposed flow and I couldn't really... get the beat of yours. It was a great idea and I really loved the last stanza, but I felt like you were really trying to tell a story. Poems are generally a mixture between word play and a story with missing parts I think. Maybe you should try rewriting it as a short story - don't worry if it's only a page or half a page, because that really doesn't matter. And, if that doesn't work out, you can try messing around or rewriting the poem to see how that goes.
Now, I began to read your second piece of work - Cyborg Mania - but didn't finish it due to time. The first thing I noticed, however, was your change in tense in the first sentence. You go from past to present and the only way that would work would be if the line "he is neither man nor robot" was a thought or something like that. Otherwise, it should be "he was neither man nor robot". 
The second thing is that you do a lot of explaining. That's a no-no. What you want to do is tell the story, unravel it, allow the reader to be put inside the story and basically watch it unfold. Now, what you're explaining in the first paragraph is probably important for the reader to know. Try putting it in a prologue - ie, write out the event as it happens and, once it's finished, you can start on your first chapter. That's how I usually do it if I have info for the reader that happens prior to where I plan on starting the actual story. 
Skipping down a few paragraphs, you're recapping for some reason. You're also explaining, repeating and not showing the reader. It’s almost like you’re a writing textbook. IE - In one paragraph, you're talking about how Julie dies and Vaugn is incredibly sad. Instead of saying he's sad, he misses Julie, thus he tries to recreate Julie, etc, etc. you could say something like "Vaugn was at a loss of what to do with himself" (cheesy, no?), and it would show that without Julie, he'd be a bit lost in the world. Instead of telling the reader, you want to show them. Another example, instead of saying, “he was nervous” or something you could have him playing with a pen or nibbling his lip. Do get what I’m saying?
I'm gonna end here, because this is getting pretty lengthy. Haha. But, anyway, before you post, I hope you're editing, because it makes you look like an idiot if you don't and if you have any questions or want an opinion, whatever it is, feel free to email me. (;



Source(s):



I'm a writer myself.



</answer>



<answer from>



Mrs.Danny Noriega
Member since: 18 April 2008
Total points: 324 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



i can't give you advice (im not really good at that) but i can definetly tell you that your going somewhere with that



</answer>

<question from>



Cor blimey.
Member since: 09 November 2007
Total points: 2034 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



I need help with th party motto from George Orwell's 1984 ?



In George Orwell's 1984 the party motto is:

War is Peace
Freedom Is Slavery
Ignorance is Strength

I'm just finding this hard to understand because the extract from "the book" was rather complicated when it explained these concepts. So i was wondering if anyone could attempt to explain them more simply? Thanks :) x



</question>



<answer from>



iluvfonz...
Member since: 30 June 2007
Total points: 4167 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



They're examples of doublethink



Source(s):



http://www.cliffsnotes.com/WileyCDA/LitN...



</answer>



<answer from>



Want it bad!
Member since: 31 October 2007
Total points: 1811 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



This motto is meant to brainwash people into compliance and keep them from questioning big brother. They are saying that WAR is the only way to maintain PEACE and homogeny. The part about FREEDOM being SLAVERY is  sort of circular logic meant to keep an oppressed people down by convincing them that freedom is too hard and make you work too hard and you are actually a slave because you constantly have to worry about survival so why not let us take care of everything for you? And finally, have you ever heard that old addage, Ignorance is bliss, its sort of the same concept, what you don't know won't hurt you so as a people we are better off with ignorant citizens. It makes things run smoother as a whole.



</answer>



<answer from>



DR. LARRY MITCHELL
Member since: 21 August 2006
Total points: 277 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



That's the point- it doesn't make sense.
It's called "double-speak", or "newspeak".
You control language because that's the way you control thought.
You aren't being controlled, therefore, it makes no sense.

"Power don't come from a badge or a gun. Power comes from lying. Lying big, and gettin' the whole damn world to play along with you. Once you got everybody agreeing with what they know in their hearts ain't true, you've got 'em by the balls"



</answer>



<answer from>



Mutly
Member since: 20 December 2006
Total points: 3659 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



They're examples of doublethink.  My understanding of doublethink is that it was used to justify what the government was doing.  In other words, by going to war they were actually achieving peace so it was a good thing.
Freedom is a bad thing because you're really becoming enslaved by those who give freedom.
Ignorance is good and gives you strength because you don't have to worry about the truth.

I could be off but the basic idea of doublethink is that what you believe to be true is false and vice versa.



</answer>



<answer from>



Tyler T
Member since: 01 September 2007
Total points: 1009 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



the most important ideology from 1984 is "double think". That is extremely hard to explain, it basically meant that there can be two explanations from the same word or meaning. the motto is what the people are made to believe, not the proles (the poor under class people).



War is peace because there is no surplus of goods which lead to happier and advancement in people. the constant war kept people afraid and dependent (sounds like today almost). with constant war, there is no advance in culture or intelligence, which would lead to a revolution.

freedom is slavery because only the slaves are the ones who just "live". it might make one of the party members think, to be without big brother, to be without protection, without INGSOC, that meant to be free. then freedom is the worst. to be a slave of the party is to be free.

Ignorance is strength, because ignorance is bliss. what you dont know wont hurt you. if the Party and the proles knew that Oceania was put into fake wars as a tool of domination and mind control, if they knew that Big Brother didnt exist, if they knew that they were slaves, they might revolt. but its no use. the proles are kept dumb and the party kept undercontrol by fear.

Hope this helped. sorry for the grammer.  i just read 1984 again this summer. Great book.



</answer>

<answer from>



silverli...
Member since: 05 August 2008
Total points: 109 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



disclaimer (as it were): none of these beliefs are mine, beacause i am not just a statistic. And we thankfully live in a world that allows us to have our wars, our share of slavery and our choice not be ignorant.

George Orwell's 1984, is a shock tactic at bringing to the fore, the futility of life that can be, if we do not use our collective intellegence as an evolved race. 
Governments will always use double think as a weapon to stay in power. 
Just how powerful do us, the poeple, need to be, to carry on the code of progress we have been educated to propagate?

All happennings in the book are essentially a mental state, expressed in terms of a satirical tangibility (and the other way round) that can be empathised with.

Here is an attempt at explaining these concepts in a simple way.

1. war is peace: 
when at war, impositions on life and living make choices narrow. you either expose yourself and  face the consequences, or you comply with authority, however absolute - and war time brings in absolute authority. precise, all-reaching and containing.
you have no choices. your life ceases to exist. you merely follow orders. 
life is simple. 
there are no personal conflicts to tarry with. no dreams to pursue. no ambition. no rights. no privileges. 
You are a robot that will do the bidding.
no conflict, is peace.
War is, therefore, peace.
1984 is such a scene. Existentialist. Robotic. Where everything is a duty to Big Brother. And every such duty is clearly chalked out and dispensed.



2. Freedom is slavery:
When you are free to be, to think, to act, and every one in your community shares this freewill, there are bound to be expectations, responsibilities, successes and failures. 
You are therefore also bound in that sense. Bound to those responsibilities that are due to those who depend on you. You are bound to expectations that these very people will impose on you. 
You are a slave to  desires of success and a slave to fear of failure. and the repercussions thereof. 
Life is a steady path of bondage and slavery.
Freedom is, therefore, slavery.
slavery to life and its many facets.
Hence Big brother solves your problem. He reduces you to a number. Where you simply exist, without thought.
In a brain-dead existence, you are free of the bindings of freedom. you are free of any personal responsibilities, emotions and desires.

3. Ignorance is strength:
problems arise when you know right from wrong, or believe one way or the other. Dealing with these problems are taxing. Ideals and ideology, knowlege and learning, progress and fulfilment, come with a whole lot of issues spoken of in motto 1 and 2. 
when you don't know, and simply follow directive, there is only one way to go. all your senses are channelised towards only one goal. and the goal is always the same- please Big Brother. there are no credits to be taken. No gratidute to be given. 
This makes you strong, as no energy is expended on any distractions.
Think about this: you are learning to drive in a foreign country. the rules are very clear and exacting. 
which will be easier? learning to drive from scratch, or first unlearning all your old driving habits and then learning the requirements as per your new track? And if you do manage to learn the new way of driving, how sure are you that your old habits will not visit every now and again?
ignorance is therefore strength.
when you have nothing to compare to, no two ways to chose from, just one track to follow - that is you are ignorant to any thing else- you are strong.

The idea of the book, as i see it, is to express the exasperation at what our lives have become. and a frantic atempt at putting the world right, before it is too late. 1984 was written when 1984 was in the future. the fear of what is to come can make the worst among us change our ways. and if you can actually see yourself in that horrid future, can you even imagine what the fear will be like?



</answer>

<question>



If you've read Lord of the Flies...?



does it have like a hidden meaning?
because Ive read it but I feel like Ive missed something because it was supposed to be really good and meaningful but I'm just confused!
any ideas?!?



</question>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



Its just about the interaction between isolated group of young people and how they overcome their differences mirror to all human kind,a battle between wrong and right,between sexuality and leadership



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



It is a novel that makes us think about ourselves and makes us wonder how we would do if we were in similar circumstances.  It points out that civilized behavior may not be what we would do if the norms and mores of society were removed.

Lord of the Flies is a classic in that it is assigned reading in many schools, both high schools and colleges.



As a result there are numerous free on line resources that can help you with your study of this novel, most of which analyze the story, discuss themes and symbolism and other literary devices, and give character sketches.  If you do a search you will find many helpful resources.  Additionally hundreds of questions have been asked here on Y!A about LOTF so do a search for it in the Yahoo Answers search window and you will find lots of Q’s and A’s that should help you.



http://www.gerenser.com/lotf/
http://www.gradesaver.com/classicnotes/t...
http://www.bellmore-merrick.k12.ny.us/lo...



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>

thats shows "Human Nature"



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



No hidden meaning.  It's about power struggles, relationships, fear of the unknown, personalities, morality, politics, and egos.  It's a wonderful book.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



the hidden meaning of lord of the flies was to show the reader that when you take away all of the materialistic things in society and it's just a bunch of little boys on an island it shows how they formed their own structure of "government" in that some boys were in more power than others. they were stranded on an island and in the end it came out to be just like a real country that can give orders to the underclass workers. it also shows how people revolt against the leaders. the way the conch shell had so much power and whoever held it was idolized for that time.
the last time i read the book was two years ago so my memory is kind of faded, but i hope that this helps.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



TITLE OF THE NOVEL



Lord of the Flies refers to Beelzebub, another name for the devil. He is also called the Lord of Filth and Dung. Throughout the novel, the children grow dirtier and dirtier, an outward reflection of their inner state. As their savagery and evil increases, they seek a symbol, a god to worship. When Jack and his hunters kill a boar, they have their opportunity; they leave the pig's head impaled on a stake as an offering to the beast. The head is soon rotting and covered with flies. The head, referred to as the "Lord of the Flies" then serves as a symbol of the evil and savagery of Jack's tribe of hunters. At the end of the novel, Ralph, with disgust, knocks the boar's skull to the ground and seizes the stick to use as a spear. He understands the evil that surrounds him in the person of Jack, and he seeks to destroy it.



ENDING OF THE NOVEL



The novel ends with naval officers arriving on the island. The one that spies Ralph and the savages who chase him, at first sees the boys as dirty children involved in fun and games. When he learns from Ralph what has happened on the island, he is amazed that civilized British children could sink to such a low level of humanity. Ralph and the boys listening to his scolding and break into tears that quickly become sobs. They are crying over the horror of their experience and relief over returning to civilization. As the boys weep, the naval officer simply looks out to sea to allow them to regain their composure. The ending is abrupt, appearing almost contrived.



The naval officer fails to see the significance of the boys' experience. His not realizing what has happened on the island mirrors his own inability to recognize evil within himself and all mankind. When he mentions fun and games, the reader is jerked back to reality. These are children who should be innocent and should be playing games. Instead, they have become the reality in all of us --- not that of innocence, but of evil.



It is ironic that the naval officer while appearing to represent civilization and rational society actually represents the evil present in civilization just like the boys themselves. He is a soldier who fights wars, which is certainly civilization at it's worst.



Source(s):



http://www.pinkmonkey.com/booknotes/monk...



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



The story is an allegorical tale showing how thin is the veneer of civilisation when its normal constraints are removed.  There follows a power struggle between the forces of good and those of evil.

Golding leaves it to the imagination of the reader as to how this struggle plays out because the outcome is clouded by the arrival of the rescue party.



Source(s):



Lord of the Flies by William Golding



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



The hidden meaning has long been demonstrated by the gradual and ever increasing amount of juvenile violence in Western society.  YOu only have to think of the murder of the 7year old boy by two others under ten in the UK or the thousands of gang attacks and bashings,committed by what were at one time considered "harmless young people". Add to that the ever increasing number of  home invasions and the degeneration of many many juveniles into at the least mentally deficient Graffiti maniacs or at worst, mindless murderous thugs.
And Why? because forty years ago a group of ignorant adults decided that the time had come to pass laws empowering children to be exempt from corporal punishment and to go do exactly as they like without either parental or school control. 
Now just look at the price we are all paying for it!
Bring back public flogging as they have in Singapore and watch it transform juvenile deliquents into the mild little underlings  they once were(and their parents have forgotten how to create)...OVERNIGHT!



Source(s):



The reality of using controlled violence to prevent violence out of control



</answer>

<answer>



They appeal strongly to many teenage girls as they are very romantic.  And the hero, Edward Cullen, seems to go down very big with most of the girls who read the books.  Personally, I liked Jacob much better than Edward as he seemed more human, but I never really thought he had much chance with Bella, she was always too hung up on Edward.

I quite enjoyed them, especially the first one which I thought was quite good.  I liked Bella, I found her clumsiness and lack of interest in clothes endearing (I find clothes very boring myself, so I identified with that).  However, I found myself less charmed by the later books, she moped over Edward far too much and it began to get on my nerves.  and the last book I thought had a very tame ending, I was most disappointed.

I agree with you about the Harry Potter books being much better though, the characters are far more interesting, the plots much more intricate and exciting, and there is far more humour.



</answer>



<answer from>



Scrapbook Queen ♥
Member since: 27 August 2008
Total points: 794 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Have you read them?

Twilight makes ALOT of sense, Edward explains it.

New Moon is named so because the events in that book are the darkest time in Bella's Life (like the cycle of a New Moon)

Eclipse is named that because Bella experiences a life one.

Breaking Dawn is named because when dawn breaks, it's the beginning of a new day. I.E. Bella's life as a vampire



They do so have a plot, BTW!!

Stephenie Meyer is an AMAZING author. If she is so terrible than why do so many people like her books?!?!

Bella has a very good personality; Smart, clumsy, accident-prone, bad luck magnet, stubborn, loving and warm
Edward's: Thorough, intelligent, witty, protective, loving, caring.

JK Rowling is an amazing author, also. I love love love love LOVE the Harry Potter Books, but I also love the Twilight books. You should give 'em a chance, they are really good.

And the big deal is that so many people like them. The same 'big deal' there is about HP; the writing and plot is amazing, and it's just really popular!



</answer>

<answer>



The Constant Gardener by John le Carre
Les Miserables by Victor Hugo
To Kill A Mockingbird by Harper Lee

Two of them are old books, I know, but here it's completely new.  I've been wanting to read them all my life, but since I live in Indonesia, I have to wait.  I can't easily buy classics books here unlike in US or UK.  So two months ago, in my honeymoon trip, I saw those books on the "new books" shelf in a store and decided to buy it straight on.

To kill a mocking bird was first published in 1960's and I have to wait for about 40 years for the translated edition to be published in my country! (I'm still 23 anyways lol)

And Les Miserables?  I know since it's now in public domain, I can just download it.  But it was too heavy for me since my English is very poor.  It's relatively pricey because the book is huge and thick, but who cares? lol



As for the Constant Gardener? well..it's just because... I have no special reason on buying it.

<answer>

He's a good man that can't recognize decent women when they come into his life.

Contributing In:



Books & Authors



</answer from>



<answer>



The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe (and the other books in the Chronicles of Narnia) by C.S. Lewis

A Little Princess by Frances Hodgson Burnett

The Secret Garden by Frances Hodgson Burnett

Heidi by Johanna Spyri

Rebecca of Sunnybrook Farm by Kate Douglas Wiggin

Pollyanna by Eleanor H. Porter

(Of course, all of the above are considered children's classics.)

The Eyre Affair by Jasper Fforde (Thursday Next already loves someone. The story doesn't show the process of falling in love.)

any Miss Marple mystery by Agatha Christie :)

Jane and the Unpleasantness at Scargrave Manor by Stephanie Barron (This is the first Jane Austen mystery story, written as though by Jane Austen. Though later in the books there is a man who becomes important to her, in the first there is no love interest.)

The Turn of the Screw by Henry James

A Walk in Wolf Wood by Mary Stewart (again, this is more a children's fantasy)

This is actually a rather tough question, since there is often a love interest or falling in love somewhere in the story.

***Edit: I did think of My Cousin Rachel by Daphne du Maurier in which the protagonist is a man, who does fall in love with Rachel. However, even at the end of the story, you are not sure about Rachel: is she good or bad, did she murder or not, did she love or not? Not precisely what you wanted, but...

In The Old Curiosity Shop by Charles Dickens, the female lead doesn't fall in love. If you consider Estella to be the lead female, Great Expectations doesn't have her fall in love. Pip does, she doesn't.



</answer>



<answer from>

Member since: 09 January 2008
Total points: 1781 (Level 3)

<question>



How many people have written endings for The Salmon of Doubt?



Can you recommend any? It just about gets interesting when it stops. I think all the basic setup is there, all the major characters(clearly Dirk is working for a future/subconscious version of himself) and plot devices that are necessary though of course you'd add more. I'd give it a go myself, but I know I'm not a good enough author!



</question>



<additional details>



hello again, probablygraham. I know no-one could ever write a definitive ending, but I also know that there are some very talented, very Adams-inspired authors out there. There was an anthology fairly recently - the Fortean Times reviewed it - of stories written by a plethora of popular Scifi authors, based on notes and concepts left by Edgar Allan Poe. It would be nice to see a similar tome for Adams. Inspired by, not ripping off.



</additional details>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



I think any ending would be wrong if you think about where most of his books ended up. What a terrible loss it was.

In case you don't know the author, if you like Douglas Adams, try to get a selection of Robert Sheckley - I'm sure he influenced him.



</answer>

<question from>



tiffluvs...
Member since: 26 June 2008
Total points: 213 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



I need help writing a plot for 2 kings 5:1-5:14 in the Bible...?



please help I don't really know what to write and i have to write a paper. but i have to write a couple of sentences for the plot



</question>



<answer from>



flutterb...
Member since: 09 September 2008
Total points: 482 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



The mighty warrior Naaman, suffering from leprosy, was nevertheless greatly admired by the King of Aram. On the word of his wife's young slave girl, he is sent by the King of Aram to seek out a prophet of Samaria who can heal him. The King of Israel receives Naaman and the letter from the King of Aram and is offended that the King would send him such a person and expect him to help, thinking he was trying to pick a fight.

The prophet Elisha, hearing of this snub, summons Naaman and offers him a very simple cure for his leprosy. But because of Naaman's lack of faith and the offense he feels Elisha has given him by not meeting him face-to-face, he rejects this cure. His officers then remind Naaman that as a great warrior, if Elisha had set him some difficult task to accomplish to be cured, he would have followed Elisha's directions without question. Naaman comes to his senses, obeys Elisha and is cured.
*************
Not great - but the best I could come up with...Good luck.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



very great thank you



</asker's comment>

<question>



"Page 2 of Babar" - anything in a book that shocked or saddened you in early childhood?



Early on 'The Story of Babar' the little elephant's mother is 'shot by a cruel hunter', with an accompanying picture.  Some parents think this is too much for little children to take.
At age three, I saw the picture of Henry the Green Engine, sobbing bricked up in a tunnel, and I disliked it so much I tore it out of the book!

Robert Louis Stevenson's Child's Garden of Verses is filled with poems that are very sad and even as a child I understood the sadness.  He felt his loneliness and isolation from being a sick child, that touched me as a kid and still does today.

<answer from>



reader
Member since: 12 January 2008
Total points: 20227 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Books & Authors



</answer from>



<answer>



This poem used to just break my heart, seriously. My first taste of empathy, I guess.

King John's Christmas, AA Milne

King John was not a good man --
He had his little ways.
And sometimes no one spoke to him
For days and days and days.
And men who came across him, 
When walking in the town,
Gave him a supercilious stare,
Or passed with noses in the air --
And bad King John stood dumbly there, 
Blushing beneath his crown.

King John was not a good man,
And no good friends had he.
He stayed in every afternoon...
But no one came to tea.
And, round about December, 
The cards upon his shelf
Which wished him lots of Christmas cheer,
And fortune in the coming year,
Were never from his near and dear,
But only from himself.

King John was not a good man,
Yet had his hopes and fears.
They'd given him no present now
For years and years and years.
But every year at Christmas,
While minstrels stood about,
Collecting tribute from the young
For all the songs they might have sung,
He stole away upstairs and hung
A hopeful stocking out.

King John was not a good man,
He lived his live aloof;
Alone he thought a message out
While climbing up the roof.
He wrote it down and propped it
Against the chimney stack:
"TO ALL AND SUNDRY - NEAR AND FAR -
F. Christmas in particular."
And signed it not "Johannes R."
But very humbly, "Jack."

"I want some crackers,
And I want some candy;
I think a box of chocolates
Would come in handy;
I don't mind oranges,
I do like nuts!
And I SHOULD like a pocket-knife
That really cuts.
And, oh! Father Christmas, if you love me at all,
Bring me a big, red, india-rubber ball!"

King John was not a good man --
He wrote this message out, 
And gat him to this room again,
Descending by the spout.
And all that night he lay there, 
A prey to hopes and fears.
"I think that's him a-coming now!"
(Anxiety bedewed his brow.)
"He'll bring one present, anyhow --
The first I had for years."

"Forget about the crackers,
And forget the candy;
I'm sure a box of chocolates
Would never come in handy;
I don't like oranges,
I don't want nuts,
And I HAVE got a pocket-knife
That almost cuts.
But, oh! Father christmas, if you love me at all,
Bring me a big, red, india-rubber ball!"

King John was not a good man,
Next morning when the sun
Rose up to tell a waiting world
That Christmas had begun,
And people seized their stockings,
And opened them with glee,
And crackers, toys and games appeared,
And lips with sticky sweets were smeared,
King John said grimly: "As I feared,
Nothing again for me!"

"I did want crackers,
And I did want candy;
I know a box of chocolates
Would come in handy;
I do love oranges,
I did want nuts!
And, oh! if Father Christmas, had loved me at all,
He would have brought a big, red, 
india-rubber ball!"

King John stood by the window,
And frowned to see below
The happy bands of boys and girls
All playing in the snow.
A while he stood there watching,
And envying them all ...
When through the window big and red
There hurtled by his royal head,
And bounced and fell upon the bed,
An india-rubber ball!

AND, OH, FATHER CHRISTMAS,
MY BLESSINGS ON YOU FALL
FOR BRINGING HIM
A BIG, RED,
INDIA-RUBBER
BALL!

And another by the same author:

http://www.cs.rice.edu/~ssiyer/minstrels...

I was always so glad that he did get a little bit of butter for his bread!

I'm sure there are more, but those are what sprang to mind.
Nice question, thanks for asking.



</answer>



<answer from>

Member since: 03 March 2007

xxmachin...

Contributing In:

<answer>



eh, it is like the parents that won't let their child see Bambi.

You don't want your child to end up a hothouse flower. If they can't take reading Babar, what happens when someone they know and care about dies?  Do you run out and buy a "special" book to help them deal with the death?



..and because I can't resist referencing Herman Hesse in an answer on Babar.  It reminds me of in Siddhartha when the hero has never seen an old person in his life, do you really want your 21 year old to have a people-die epiphany in college?



</answer>

<question from>



*La tua cantante...*
Member since: 29 August 2007
Total points: 464 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Can anyone help me translate this Shakespeare monologue into modern english?



Helena's monolgue from a Midsummer Nights Dream.

HELENA: How happy some o'er other some can be! 
Through Athens I am thought as fair as she. 
But what of that? Demetrius thinks not so; 
He will not know what all but he do know. 
And as he errs, doting on Hermia's eyes, 
So I, admiring of his qualities. 
Things base and vile, holding no quantity, 
Love can transpose to form and dignity. 
Love looks not with the eyes, but with the mind, 
And therefore is winged Cupid painted blind. 
Nor hath Love's mind of any judgment taste; 
Wings, and no eyes, figure unheedy haste. 
And therefore is Love said to be a child, 
Because in choice he is so oft beguiled. 
As waggish boys in game themselves forswear, 
So the boy Love is perjured everywhere. 
For ere Demetrius looked on Hermia's eyne, 
He hailed down oaths that he was only mine; 
And when this hail some heat from Hermia felt, 
So he dissolved, and show'rs of oaths did melt. 
I will go tell him of fair Hermia's flight. 
Then to the wood will he to-morrow night 
Pursue her; and for this intelligence 
If I have thanks, it is a dear expense. 
But herein mean I to enrich my pain, 
To have his sight thither and back again.



Thanks so much!
Tora

P.S Is this the whole monologue?
XD



</question>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



Some people are so much luckier than others!
Everyone in Athens thinks I'm just as attractive as her,
But what good is that? Demetrius doesn't think so.
He refuses to see what everyone else can see.
And just like he makes a big mistake, going crazy about Hermia's eyes,
I'm exactly the same about him.
Love is able to transform things which are horrible, common and worthless
Into something beautiful and special.
People in love see with the mind, not the eyes,
And that's why in pictures Cupid (the god of love) is always shown as blind. 
And the mind of a person in love isn't able to think sensibly;
Someone with wings and no eyes is going to act too quickly and rashly.
That's why Love [i.e. Cupid] is often described as being a child,
Because he so often makes stupid choices.
Just like boys who are mucking around tell fibs 
So the boy Love contradicts himself all over the place.
e.g. before Demetrius saw Hermia's eyes,
He made a hailstorm of promises that he was my guy, and mine alone;
But when he started to find Hermia hot,
He and all his promises to me all melted away.
I will go and tell him that beautiful Hermia is planning to run off with Lysander.
Then he will go to the wood tomorrow night
To chase after her; even if he thanks me
For this information, it will still cost me dear [i.e. because he'll still end up with Hermia].
But I intend to make my suffering even greater by doing this, 
Just so that I can be with him on the journey there and back.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



How happy some can get over over others.
Throughout Athens people consider me to be as beautiful as she, but who cares? Demetrius doesn't think so. And he will not change his mind. But he is wrong when he dots on Hermia's eyes. I am the one admiring him. Things that are ugly, love can make beautiful because love does not look with the eyes, but through the heart and that is why cupid is blind. And love has no judgement, it has wings and no eyes. So you make rash decisions without giving thought. And so love is said to be a child because it often makes the wrong decision. As boys in a game they lie, so a boy in love contradicts himself everywhere. For while Demetrius looked on Hermia's eye, he made oaths and swore that he was only mine.And when he received a little attention from Hermia, he forgot all his other oaths. I will tell him that Hermia left, and then to the woods he will go tomorrow night to pursue her. And for this information he will thank me. I don't want him to chase after her, it will only her me more, but I want him to be thankful to me. If only I were not blind with love, so that I could think again.

That's a rough translation, I think that is the entire monologue, but I am no where near my book so I cannot check. But I hope it helped.

If you were looking for a basic rundown of what is going on, it is that Helena is in love with Demitrius who is in love with Hermia, who does not love him. She has plans to runaway with someone else and she told Helena because they used to be friends. Helena plans to tell Demetrius that she is running away because she thinks the news will make him happy with her, but she knows she is being foolish, but she wants to tell him anyway. And the reason she is so obsessed with Demetrius is they had had a previous fling and he had swore that he loved her only, but then she found out he was trying to woo Hermia as well and he chose Hermia, but Helena was not ready to let him go.



</answer>

no answerer details



</answer from>

</answer>

<category>



Arts & Humanities



Books & Authors

<question from>



aantonio...
Member since: 23 August 2008
Total points: 60 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



In the short story Superman and Paula Browns New Snowsuit, what war is going on?



Who was the war between and what year? Thanks



</question>



<answer from>



Enquire
Member since: 05 December 2007



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Hi



Superman and Paula Brown's New Snowsuit is set during the winter of 1941  (on 7 December 1941 the Japanese attacked the US naval base at Pearl Harbour). After this attack, the US felt forced to enter World War Two.

I've added some useful links for you in the sources bit below.



This answer was provided by Enquire, a 24-hour, live question answering and enquiry service offered by public librarians across England and Scotland in collaboration with partners in the United States.



If you liked our answer and would like us to help you find another, you can chat with one of us right now by clicking on Enquire on the People’s Network site at http://www.peoplesnetwork.gov.uk



Source(s):



http://www.bbc.co.uk/schools/gcsebitesiz... 
http://www.universalteacher.org.uk/antho...



</answer>



<asker's comment>



All the info I wanted. thanks



</asker's comment>






<original file>index;_ylt=AkmBBV1Ccs3jXhPVaCFeO2nsBwx4794.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk44216.txt</current file name>



<category>



Arts & Humanities



Books & Authors



</category>



<question from>



Keys
Member since: 07 June 2007
Total points: 4420 (Level 4)



</question from>



<question>



Very easy 10 points. What works better in a story?



What works better for main characters?

6 identical teenage girls as the main characters or
Sextuplets broken up into 3 girls and 3 boys?

What do you think would work best for variety, sibling rivalry etc?
Please say why you pick what you pick



</question>



<additional details>



They is identical because it is easier, and I thought it had more impact



Saying easy 10 points got a lot of answers in a short space of time and actually coming up with an answer to the question is very as it's just two choices and you need to do is pick 1



I've done creative stuff in other stories. They wouldn't be identical right down to personality because that would be laziness, I did plan to make them different and not completely the same.



I can see how that's misleading, I meant identical as in appearance wise.



To avoid further confusion, this is what I mean by 6 identical teenage girls: Identical in physical appearance. Personality-wise there will be differences



</additional details>



<answer from>

Member since: 10 August 2008

<answer>



The second one. But it depends on your plot. In the first option are they friends or siblings? 6 identical siblings is too implausible and there is not much you could do with six identical people that you couldn't do with just two. The second option is much more varied and you could do more with boys and girls than with just girls.



</answer>



<answer from>



John G
Member since: 16 May 2008
Total points: 151 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



The problem you would run into with 6 identical teenage girls is that you'd probably have to rely on cardboard characterizations in order for the reader to distinguish between them; i.e, The 'Smart' One, The 'Artsy' One, The 'Rebel', The 'Flirt', etc.

If pressed, I'd probably go with the 3 boy, 3 girl formula, although you're gonna run up against the 'Brady Bunch' syndrome--so avoid any Boys vs Girls scenarios. Instead, utilize the natural irony of the fact that they attract a lot of attention at school because of their sextuplet status, but at the same time find themselves individually feeling isolated in the family sphere because they are just one of six similar siblings.

Either way, you've got quite a challenge to write something compelling without coming across as just a wacky Disney Channel send up. Good Luck!



</answer>



<answer from>



Holly M
Member since: 24 April 2008
Total points: 2857 (Level 4)



</answer from>
