<answer from>



MUSIC Feeds My SOUL]
Member since: 11 September 2007
Total points: 2050 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Seriously , 6 teenage identical girls as main characters would be so boring. 
On a first hear , it sounds  like they are identical twins or something.



I think it would be more interesting if you make them have different personalities from each other. If you make them all the same ,the story wouldn't be enjoyable and fun to read. Like this ,the characters won't have depth and the readers won't find them realistic. In my opinion, the whole point in writing  real characters in a book is for the reader to find them  believable and to feel like he/she can relate with the characters.
if you can't make them any different , I suggest you not to start writing a book. If you are lazy , to make various characters in a book , you aren't creative. By writing a book , the author shouldn't lack creativity.

On other hand, 3 girls and 3 boys. It sounds more interesting than the first option. After all , boys possess a different nature from girls.
With this , you can have male and female readers , something that you can't have with your first option.
the Male readers can relate to the 3 boys characters and the Female readers with the girls characters.

Either way , you can't have identical and same characters in a story.

xx Greetings



Source(s):



EDIT: Then why did you say that you'd like to have 6 IDENTICAL girls in your book?
I suppose you meant their personality?

EDIT: Why all of them would have a same appearance?
I'm sorry , I don't know anything about what are you planning to write. But if they have different personality , it's normal for them  to have a different appearance , unless if they are sisters?



</answer>

<answer>



If you want love then read " a farewell to arms" it is about love and war. it is amazing. I read it when i was in freshman year of highschool. it is about a woman who falls in love with this guy, it takes place during ww1. He is a ambulance driver. He falls in love with this nurse. She likes him too, but she thinks she is to old for him. But they both love each other, they wind up getting together, then some other stuff happens, i dont want to give it away. This is a true love story. i love this book, one of my favorite. i read it lots of time. this book really is tryue love. <answer from>



SpotsB4m...
Member since: 03 August 2007
Total points: 7806 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Jane Eyre by Charlotte Bronte is definitely a must read. The basic storyline of the story is that Jane falls in love and she has to choose between love or what she believes is right. It begins with her as a child and works up to when she's eighteen and wants a change of scene and to escape where she's stayed for most of her life. http://www.amazon.co.uk/Jane-Eyre-Pengui...

Pride and Prejudice was good as well. It definitely kept me reading. if you haven't seen the film, it's about Elizabeth Bennet and Mr. Darcy, characters which begin with conflict. http://www.amazon.co.uk/Pride-Prejudice-...

The Handmaid's Tale is a very deep story that is about a dystopia. It explores a world where very few women are able to have children and those that can are forced to have children for the rich. It's not really a romance, but it is a very good read. http://www.amazon.co.uk/Handmaids-Tale-C...

Tamar is also another favourite of mine. It is set in World War Two and is a story of love and betrayal. It jumps from future to past through two people. A wartime love story with twists and turns. http://www.amazon.co.uk/Tamar-Mal-Peet/d...

The Mediator series next because it sounds relaly good. It's about a girl who can talk to ghosts and falls in love with one. http://www.amazon.co.uk/Mediator-Love-Yo...

Then there's also The Dark Night Series that I want to read, which is about a girl who gets marked to join the vampire world and falls in love. http://www.amazon.com/Marked-House-Night...

If you like Twilight, then you will probably like The Host, which is also written by Stephenie Meyer. It's about a love triangle within two bodies; that's next on my list to read. http://www.amazon.com/Host-Novel-Stephen...

You might also want to check out Blue Bloods- http://www.amazon.com/Blue-Bloods-Meliss... Another set of books I hope to read; they sound really good.



</answer>

<answer from>



rich w
Member since: 21 August 2008
Total points: 616 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



You generally can't find more than a couple of pages or a chapter of a book like Potter on the internet, because the publisher and the author have a financial stake in people purchasing the work.  If you could read a big chunk of it online, then you might decide you don't want to buy it.  Copyright laws prevent people from electronically disseminating copyrighted materials.



</answer>



<answer from>

<answer>



Rich W has given you the correct answer.  You will NOT be able to download an e version of any of the Harry Potter series.  The reason is as Rich W states.

You can log on to the Harry Potter website and see extracts from the books.  This website also has links for J. K. Rowling's official site.



Source(s):



the harry potter wikkipedia

the leaky cauldren .org

the leaky cauldren wiikpedia



the harry potter lexicon wikkipedia

All of these sites are great links to Harry Potter world and also explain more about copyright.



</answer>

<answer>



1) Snape, definitely. He's the true hero of the book IMO; he's the only one who redeems himself. I really hated the way he died - he deserved better.

2) Luna Lovegood. She's just so delightfully dotty and insightful at the same time.

3) Sirius Black. I have a lot of issues with Sirius, he's immature and spiteful sometimes, but I can't help liking him anyway.

4) Remus Lupin. He's weak and a bit of a coward but he's also nice and loving.

5) Hermione. When she's not being a leaky faucet. She can be ruthless and manipulative, but her heart's in the right place.



</answer>

<answer from>



plethora de sarcasm
Member since: 01 May 2008
Total points: 4629 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Movies



Books & Authors



</answer from>



<answer>



1. Hermione Granger--I love strong, intelligent female characters and Hermione is the ultimate one. She never takes any crap from anyone and she always stands up for herself and her friends. And most importantly she's not afraid to voice her opinions whether people agree with her or not.



2. Harry Potter--I love Harry. Not only is he a courageous, caring, and self-sacrificing human being...he is HILARiOUs! I think most people think Ron is the funniest character, but I think the stuff Harry says and thinks is by far the funniest. I think JK Rowling uses her own sarcastic, dry humor for harry. He's such a great character.

3. Luna Lovegood---She's so quirky and weird. And I love how she says the most awkward things and she doesn't care how uncomfortable it makes the people around her. She's just living in her own little world.



4. Lily Potter---she was such a cool person who loved her child so much and it's a shame that she only lived 21 years. I would love for JK Rowling to write a book about Lily. I think it would be very interesting. I mean Lily was a muggle-born and Voldemort still wanted her on his side. That's how intelligent she was.



5. Weasley twins--They're so fun to read about. Whenever one of them appears on the page things just get so much more interesting and they always brighten the mood.



</answer>

<category>



Arts & Humanities



Books & Authors



</category>



<question from>



I am a Vampire &lt;3
Member since: 15 June 2008
Total points: 1426 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



Whats happening with the Midnight Sun Leak?



I'm not downloading something ILLEGAL! But I don't understand why Stephenie Meyer hasn't but anything about it on her website! Are the rumors about her wanting Midnight Sun Leaked true? Also is it just a publicity stunt? I'm really annoyed about it all!



</question>



<answer from>



purplepp...
Member since: 08 June 2007
Total points: 263 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Voters</evaluation>



At first I was sure that Smeyer was doing the leaking. She just updated her page. My heart goes out to her and, being a fellow author, I understand what she means concerning writing any further.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~...

As some of you may have heard, my partial draft of Midnight Sun was illegally posted on the Internet and has since been virally distributed without my knowledge or permission or the knowledge or permission of my publisher.

I have a good idea of how the leak happened as there were very few copies of Midnight Sun that left my possession and each was unique. Due to little changes I made to the manuscript at different times, I can tell when each left my possession and to whom it was given. The manuscript that was illegally distributed on the Internet was given to trusted individuals for a good purpose. I have no comment beyond that as I believe that there was no malicious intent with the initial distribution.

I did not want my readers to experience Midnight Sun before it was completed, edited and published. I think it is important for everybody to understand that what happened was a huge violation of my rights as an author, not to mention me as a human being. As the author of the Twilight Saga, I control the copyright and it is up to the owner of the copyright to decide when the books should be made public; this is the same for musicians and filmmakers. Just because someone buys a book or movie or song, or gets a download off the Internet, doesn't mean that they own the right to reproduce and distribute it. Unfortunately, with the Internet, it is easy for people to obtain and share items that do not legally belong to them. No matter how this is done, it is still dishonest. This has been a very upsetting experience for me, but I hope it will at least leave my fans with a better understanding of copyright and the importance of artistic control.

So where does this leave Midnight Sun? My first feeling was that there was no way to continue. Writing isn't like math; in math, two plus two always equals four no matter what your mood is like. With writing, the way you feel changes everything. If I tried to write Midnight Sun now, in my current frame of mind, James would probably win and all the Cullens would die, which wouldn't dovetail too well with the original story. In any case, I feel too sad about what has happened to continue working on Midnight Sun, and so it is on hold indefinitely.

I'd rather my fans not read this version of Midnight Sun. It was only an incomplete draft; the writing is messy and flawed and full of mistakes. But how do I comment on this violation without driving more people to look for the illegal posting? It has taken me a while to decide how and if I could respond. But to end the confusion, I've decided to make the draft available here (at the end of this message on the Midnight Sun page). This way, my readers don't have to feel they have to make a sacrifice to stay honest. I hope this fragment gives you further insight into Edward's head and adds a new dimension to the Twilight story. That's what inspired me to write it in the first place.

I do want to take a moment and thank the wonderful fans who have been so supportive of me over the past three years. I cannot begin to tell you how much each of you means to me. I only hope this note will stop all the confusion and online speculation so that the Twilight universe can once again become the happy escape it used to be. After this incredibly busy year, I am now focusing on spending more time with my family and working on some other writing projects.

--Stephenie



Source(s):



stepheniemeyer.com



s



</answer>

<question>

</answer from>

</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



I like to use a free website called YAKiToMe! http://www.yakitome.com that turns any electronic text into an audio book. It reads aloud PDF, txt, MS Word documents, html webpages, Powerpoint, RSS feeds, email, ... you name it. Turns the text into an audio mp3 that you can podcast to your iPod, listen on your computer while you read along, or share with others.  It has many high-quality reading voices in different languages, too. I use it to listen to work and free classic books from Project Gutenberg http://www.gutenberg.org.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>

me

<question from>



nixter
Member since: 20 November 2007
Total points: 27 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Will you read the beginning of my story? And criticise...?



So here I lie, as the dawn breaks for summer.  I should say one last goodbye before I leave.  She has made it clear that she did not want a best friend anymore, and only now have I come to accept it.  After fighting it for so long, now I do not know what to think about.



She gave me the chain around my neck as her promise.  And I really want to believe it again.  So I quoted it into my thigh and I watched the blood seeping out of the B then the E then the S then the T.  It surprised me that I am still alive, that I am bleeding and that my heart is still beating.



I remember how quickly we got close.  Lying there with her felt so comfortable.  I am not sure what we said to each other, all I remember is the subtle flow of thoughts and emotions.



I did not normally have people sleeping round at my house, I liked being alone, I was comfortable being alone.  I could do what ever I wanted, whether that is to cry or laugh or frown or any another doing, no one could judge me.  But now, I can’t stand being alone.



A thought began to creep into my head, I should tell her my secret, if you can’t tell her, then you wont be able to tell anyone.
“I want to tell you something, but I don’t know how.” 
“Go on then.” 
She shifted her position so that she was facing me.  I had obviously made my secret into somewhat of a tease.



“I don’t know how…”
“Just say!”
“I really don’t know how.” I pause. “Well…”



Grace watched me, smiling, that fact that she was interested made it a lot worse.  The light warmed her skin highlighting her constant blush.  She said with a certain softness that made me feel very safe,



“You can tell me anything you know.”



I have known Grace for years through high school.  And we didn’t really talk too much; honestly, I hadn’t really noticed her.  She is heavily interested in science related topics, so before this, our few, yet memorable conversations were mostly on articles in the New Scientist magazine, or what we were studying currently.



Thinking about it now, I don’t know how I found the courage to tell her, I hardly knew her.  This secret, was my only secret, the secret that I had been denying and hiding, but the secret that can be used to define me.



“Go on then!” 
I sunk my face into the pillow to hide my discomfort.  After a while of building myself to tell her, and then not being able to, she started to give up a little bit.  She saw that I was very uncomfortable.  To my relief we began talking off the topic for I while.



My palms were sweaty at the thought of telling someone.  But there was something about Grace, certain safeness, she does not seem to judge, or tell rumours.  It was the fact that she was so open about everything and how she treated you like her best friend even if you have just met her, or if you found her annoying.  I did not know how she would respond to this.  I did not think that I would tell her that it was a sexual obsession; the fact that I was a bisexual would be enough for her to handle.



Silence became fixed.
“Ok, I will tell you.” I gestured for her to come closer, “I am obsessed with my English teacher.”
“Oh my god! Guess who I like?”



“Who is a women” I forced out painfully. 
“Really?” 
She didn’t seem surprised at all.  Disappointment hung on my face; I planned to blurt out everything I had been keeping in for somebody to devour and reply, instead she asked.



“Guess who I like?”
“I don’t know.”
 “Dr. Reynolds”



She began a long rant, which I could listen to again. Dr. Reynolds was our Chemistry teacher, she had had him last year and going into GSCE science for the first time she thought, in these exact words, 
“Oh God, Blue lips, Yellow skin, who is this guy?” 
She began to like him when he began to say that she was smart.  Then it went downhill from there, or uphill, depends on how you want to look at it!  From then on she started to notice things, how well he teaches his lessons, his intelligence, his sullen stance are just a few examples.  She displayed a look on her face that I have grown so attached to.  The look read pure bliss with a hint of vulnerability.  She told me about her dream, where he was just kissing her, and that was it.  But I could understand how she felt because when she tried to explain it, the look moved to her eyes.



Seeing Grace’s face light up was confusing, not because it was weird that she liked a thirty-somewhat year old teacher, but because she was that attracted to a man. It is bizarre have girls, especially young pretty girls like Grace went for such plain men, it must be genetic, because I simply did not understand.  I wished I were normal so much; it would be so much easier.



Her pace slowed as she remembered what I had told her.



“You know, it does not surprise me.”
“Really? Am I that obvious?”
“No, I mean many girls are Bi-curious at this age.” 
“No, I am bisexual.”
It was uncomfortable listening to myself saying the word; I don’t think I had ever said it ou



</question>



<additional details>



There is always going to be something missing from now on.  Always.  Everything known to me is gone, what’s left is nothingness, only a journey ahead, for which I am not prepared.



So I retrace my past, to come to terms with the present, to find out if I will ever be able to find the right tools to carry on in my journey.  And if I close my eyes tight enough and wish hard enough, then maybe, just maybe I will be able to fall into the pages, and relive the words.

It is basically the path to enlightenment, and she is going to find out that she is a lebian shhh!



</additional details>

<question>



Book Writing Letters and Sizes?

Size and type of Font (lettering) 
Approx how-many words to a page

</answer from>



<answer>



Font type and size various from publisher to publisher, book to book.

The industry standard is 250 words per page.



</answer>

<question>



How to make reading funner!?



How to make it funner[lol] what shall I try to do while reading books?
serious answers please.



</question>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



Umm well ... I'm going to give you some rules.. And they're not rules i found, i just made them up !! :P lollol



1) Always make sure you're comfy. (Sit in a big chair with a blanket and pillows, or sit outside in the sun on a comfy hair..)

2) Have a drink with you.. Not water, but lemonaide or your favorite drink.



3) Bring something to eat.. But something that you eat with your hands.. Like a chocolate bar, or even a popsicle !

4) Don't leave the blinds shut and don't turn the lights off.. Make it bright..If it's dim or dark you will get tired very fast and you won't feel like reading... (In less you like reading..)

5) If you wear glasses, make sure you wear them when you read. Without them, it might make you disey or give your eyes a really hard time..



6) Never read when the radio or TV is on, that will make it very very hard to read and understand the book..



7) Read a book you like.. (In less it's homework and you have no choice and you have to read a crappy book..)



8) Last but not least, tell your self you enjoy the book, even if you don't, just tell yourself you do.. And don't read to long, because next time you have to read, you won't want to because you'll remember how long it was last time........ Anyway, good luck and try to enjoy the book.. But just to tell you, if you don't like reading and you don't have to, than DON'T ! Never waste your time doing something that sucks, when you know you don't have to.. Life is to short to let that happen. But if you have no choice because it's homework, than make sure you read it... :P



Source(s):



Myself.



</answer>

Philosiphia- The Guggenheim Grotto- Harry Potter (the series)- JK Rowling
Cry Of the Icemark- Half a Week Before the Winter- Vanessa Carlton

Those are the prominient ones.

<question from>

<question>



What page numbers are these quotes from twilight and Lord of the flies on?



The thought of you still white cold to never see you blush scarlet again to never see that flash of intuition in your eyes when you see through my pretenses would be unendurable.- twilight

The pile of guts buzzed like a saw - lord of the flies

Through the nausea and dizziness I saw something that gave me a sudden final shred of hope... the blood- spreading crimson across my white shirt...- twilight

Johnyy yawning still burst into noisy tears and was slapped by Bill till he choked on them.- lord of the flies

best answer to the most right page numbers. :]

<answer from>



crucita
Member since: 13 September 2007
Total points: 353 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



the first one is in pg 273
the second in pg 192
third in pg 213
and the fourth in 137



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thank you!



</asker's comment>

Sophie
Member since: 14 July 2007

</question from>



<question>



The Strange Case of Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde?



help please!! im out of ideas!
"how does this book represent victorian England?"

i've put about how it shows people had to act a certain way, because when Hyde does things that are out of the norm, everybody is shocked at him

any more ideas???



</question>



<additional details>



it's for a-level, and thanks everyone for the help i really appreciate it!! getting more of those ideas flowing! i also thought about how Mr Utterson talks with Mr Enfield, even though they have nothing in common, just to be polite, representing England at the time to have been very much about keeping up appearences



</additional details>



<answer from>
Member since: 26 November 2007
Total points: 2419 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Ok, that is a good start. Think a little more deeply into what you already have: Why would the doctor need an alter ego? Why would he keep his amazing discovery secret? 
Also: How does Stevenson describe the setting?
Hope this helps.



</answer>



<answer from>



sarah_si...
Member since: 14 September 2008
Total points: 142 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I actually had to read this for school for summer reading. You have a good point about acting a certain way, also people were not rich. When the little girl is trampled, her family is paid for her injuries. This site was amazing and helped a lot: http://www.novelguide.com/dr.jekyllandmr...



</answer>



<answer from>



i_am_jea...
Member since: 15 May 2006
Total points: 4072 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



This is a GCSE text! Have you not taken any notice in class? Most copies have notes about the setting as well.  Go back and read the book again, highlight things that are out of sync with today's society, and you will have found your own answer.  After all the teacher wants your answer and arguement.



</answer>



<answer from>



Kerry D
Member since: 08 September 2008
Total points: 357 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



You could talk about how Dr. jekyll represents the middle class, respectable side of Victorian England with high morals and social values, whereas Hyde is more coarse and vulgar - he could represent the working class side of Victorian England.
It also highlights the Victorian preoccupation with medical science and the advances they believed they were making as well as the theory of degeneration, but that may be a little advanced if you are doing GCSE.



</answer>



<answer from>



L Mendy
Member since: 17 January 2007
Total points: 2154 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



The way the description is always dark and gloomy... was Victorian England actually like this? Or is this relevant to the story only?

The relationship of the three men... How they take walks together... etc. What does this say about general relationships in those times.

Also go a bit deeper in the characterisation of both Jekyll and Hyde... he's exploring the idea of skitzophrenia... something that in the Victorian times wasn't fully understood. Explore the feelings and context that this has too.



Source(s):



A level English student... Read Jekyll and Hyde.



</answer>

<answer>

Hope you find at least one book here that you may like to read but if not just take a trip to your local library or bookshop. I especially recommend second hand bookshops because not only do you get a wider variety but you can get for anything up to a quarter of the price as it is new.

<question from>



sede
Member since: 12 March 2006
Total points: 329 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Does anyone know of free literary agents?



am writing a book and would like an agent to assess its potentials, thing is most agents charge money and i have read that if your book is good, it will sell itself. Can anyone recommend a good agent who will read your manuscript without charging until you get a publisher interested enough?



</question>



<answer from>



budda m
Member since: 28 September 2006
Total points: 4044 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



You could try triggerstreet website for free reviews, it was set up by Kevin spacey the actor.



Source(s):



http://www.triggerstreet.com/gyrobase/in...



</answer>



<answer from>



Lakely
Member since: 01 December 2006
Total points: 21019 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



A legitimate literary agent will not charge to find you a publisher. They make money on a percentage of the sale of the book. They may charge a small amount for copy fees, but those are just small office expenses.

Those who charge to place your book are not legitimate. Never pay upfront for an agent.

There is a book called "Writer's Market" It lists a large number of Agents and says what kind of books the are looking for and how to approach each one.



</answer>






<original file>index;_ylt=AsDn6vMtBQEl.W.PmWE6GNLwBwxf618.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk47598.txt</current file name>



<category>



Arts & Humanities



Books & Authors



</category>



<question from>



Charly
Member since: 17 September 2008
Total points: 124 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Book lists - does anyone know a good one?



Does anyone know where I can find a top 100 book list or something like that. I watched A Walk To Remember one too many times I think and Mandy Moore mentions the top 100 list by someone. I was wondering if it actually exists or if there's something like it. I am a very avid reader and want to get into some GOOD books.



</question>



<answer from>



Abby C
Member since: 17 September 2008
Total points: 152 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I was looking for a great book list myself for the longest time. There's tons of great books out there and I wanted to choose the right one. Like you, I also don't jump on the bandwagon and read whatever the current reading fad is. The great thing is there is a reading journal that addresses the need for great book lists all in one place, and it helps you organize your reading for you.

I found this really great book lovers journal at http://www.bibliopages.com -- it's called Read, Remember and Recommend, a reading journal for book lovers. It's a spiral bound reading journal with Awards Book Lists including the Pulitzer Prize for Fiction, Los Angeles Times Award for Fiction and National Book Award for Fiction), Notable lists (BBC’S Top 100 is included) and Author Pages.

There's also a space for you to write down your personal favorites, list down the books you loaned, and write down insights you may have about books you've read. The best thing about is the book suggestions -- the book selections are awesome and will help any book lover read the right books.

It really helped organize my book reading because of the tons of lists that it has. You won't have to worry about the next book to read. :)

Find it at http://www.bibliopages.com. Happy reading!



Source(s):



http://www.bibliopages.com



</answer>



<asker's comment>



THANK YOU!!!



</asker's comment>

<question from>



sparkle_...
Member since: 15 September 2008

</question from>



<question>



How can i find an agent to publish my book?



I am writing a book and i would like to find an agent to publish my book, i have no idea where to start, can anybody help?



</question>



<answer from>



Stef
Member since: 01 March 2006
Total points: 343 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



writersmarket.com, you pay $3.00 a month for the service, but it gives you access to literary agents. Most of whom you can send your querys to via e-mail, so that's nice, and it saves bundles in postage. Good luck!

*plug* www.StefanieEllis.net *plug*



</answer>



<answer from>



Chris Pascale
Member since: 02 June 2008
Total points: 484 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Writer's Market will give you some good info, but that won't ge you an agent; that will merely give you a directory of agents.

Agents are not interested in writers that have no proof of having sold work.



I published a novel over 2 years ago and thought that was my ticket when I had articles in New York newspapers about me finding missiles in Iraq as a Marine (google: Christopher Pascale). I was wrong.

My novel is in its 2nd printing and I'm working as a freelance writer with two articles on my resume along with about 500 copies sold of my novel.



As you build your resume and maybe get regular work on a paper or magazine you'll show that you already have a base that will bring in money. When you have that you could argue that you won't need an agent, but that's the nature of the beast.



</answer>



<answer from>



Mich
Member since: 04 April 2008
Total points: 1484 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Have you bought the recent 'Writer's and Artist's Yearbook, maybe that will help.



</answer>

Raja S

My friend,



I have been teaching and writing books for many years. I have been teaching English Literature to university students for about 25 years.

Now I sell well and my books are liked.
If you visit my site you will get a link from there and send me a private message. I will instruct you without any charge. I like to help the students and upcoming writers because one day I was also like you.
God bless you
Rajasir
http://rajasir.com
http://www.rajasirji.webs.com

I did not spend a single penny and my books got published. The links are given below. Visit those sites and start publishing for free. If you have any problem, send me an email.

<answer from>



Kaladan
Member since: 15 October 2006
Total points: 539 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



It is good that you want to get an agent for your book.

You must ask yourself these questions about your book first.

What genre is it in? Like is it fantasy, romance, horror, thriller, children? If the story is one of those genres, look for agents who are in that genre that your book is in, don't go for the first agent you see on a page without investigating the agent first.

How do they want to see your book? Do they want you to send a query first detailing within one page what your story is about, single space or do they want that and the first 3 chapters of the story?

Has the story been completely edited by a beta reader or an editor before I send it off to an agent? If not, get it done before you send it. Agents will reject any manuscript that has poor spelling, grammar and sentence structures and formated wrong. 12 font in Times New Roman, with an inch margin on every side of the page, double spaced.

Are you thick skinned for rejections? If you aren't, you better grow a thick skin as most of the time, you will be rejected. But do not let that chase you off from getting an agent, it just means that your story was not right for that agent, try another agent on your list. Try searching for an agent here: http://www.litmatch.net Go to the search for agents by using the Advanced Search and type what genre the book is in.

Are you able to wait for a response? Usually they take no more than four to five weeks but they could go up to six months before they read your query and get back to you.

Do you have the query written out already describing yourself as who you are as in I'm a teen or a young adult or a well traveled traveler who decided to put down my adventures or something like that and what your story is about, what genre it is and if it is ready to be sent to them?

If you can say yes, to all of them, you can do it just keep your head held high and start on the next novel while you are waiting for a response from the agents. But if you get an agent, if they ask for a certain amount of money up front to put you on their list of authors - RUN, DON'T WALK AWAY FROM THAT AGENT. Most agents will not ask for money as they will get paid when you get paid. But there are legit agents who will charge a reading fee which they will state on their website, be sure the agent is associated with the AAR which is the group that all agents are a member of.

I hope that I didn't chase you off from becoming an author or searching for an agent. It will take effort and time to find an agent that is good for your story, so don't give up on the first rejection, keep going.

Good luck.



Source(s):



I used myself for the source as I am looking for an agent for my books too. :-)



</answer>



<answer from>



redastra...
Member since: 23 November 2006
Total points: 96 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



just do a search on agents a publishers.

but may i sugest, XLIBRIS self publication ltd?

<question>



What is a similar book to Little Women?



I recently read Little Women and absolutely loved it and was wondering if anyone knew any similar books to it?
Thanks.



</question>



<answer from>



Bess
Member since: 14 April 2006
Total points: 5419 (Level 5)

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I loved it too. Why don't you tyr the following by the same author:
Thesequels to Little Women, namely Good Wives, Jo's boys and Little Men
Eight Cousins and its sequel Rose in Bloom
The Chase
Jack and Jill
A Modern Cinderella
An Old-Fashioned Girl
Under The Lilacs

Try the following books too:-
Pride and Prejudice, Sense and Sensibility, Persuasion, Emma and Mansfield Park by Jane Austen
Jane Eyre by Charlotte Bronte
What Katy did and its sequels(What Katy did at School , What Katy did Next, Clover and In The High Valley) by Susan Coolidge
Anne of Green Gables and its sequels(Anne of Avonlea, Anne of the Island, Anne's House of Dreams, Rainbow Valley, Rilla of Ingleside) by Lucy Maud Montgomery
Daddy Long Legs, Just Patty, When Patty Went To College, Jerry, Jerry Junior, The Four Pools Mystery by Jean Webster

Hope this list helps!



</answer>

<answer from>



Louise C
Member since: 09 January 2008
Total points: 41910 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



History



Books & Authors



Gender & Women's Studies



</answer from>



<answer>



You might enjoy 'Daddy Long Legs' by Jean Webster, which is about an orphan girl who is sent to college by a mysterious benefactor.  It is set in a later period than 'Little Women', it was published in 1912, but it is a delightful book, and gives a wonderfully vivid impression of what life was like in a girls college at the turn of the last century.  The book is told in the form of the letters that Judy writes to her anonymous benefactor, and it really is a lovely book.

'Anne of Green Gables' by L.M. Montgomery is another book you might like.  Again the heroine is an orphan, and she is adopted by an elderly brother and sister who actually wanted a boy to help on their farm, and at first are dismayed to get a girl.  However, they get to like her and decide to keep her.

Also of course you might enjoy the other books that Louisa M Alcott wrote.



</answer>






<original file>index;_ylt=AsVM91AkesipA_vkvxNs7dnsBwx3890.html</original file>

</category>



<question from>



Miss Questions
Member since: 02 July 2007
Total points: 4227 (Level 4)



</question from>



<question>



A-LEVEL ENGLISH LIT--Thomas Hardy, "Your Last Drive" Q. on a line....?



When he says,



"Dear Ghost, in the past, did you ever find the though, 'What Profit' move me much?"

What does this line mean?

Thank you!!

ALEVEL type explenations!!



</question>



<answer from>



Jord17
Member since: 15 September 2008
Total points: 179 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



The speaker poses a rhetorical question to the now-dead subject of the poem: in the past when something 'moved' you, did you ask yourself "what profit" do I gain from such emotions?  The implication is that when humans experience strong emotions, we value those emotions for what they are.  Therefore, when the speaker calls the subject "past love, praise, indifference, blame", he is saying that those memories are valuable unto themselves.  Yes, the ghost will never know the speaker thinks of this yet the speaker is glad he will have those thoughts.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks!! A really good answer! :)



</asker's comment>






<original file>index;_ylt=At.TsbYn9SMo7o9hZdmd0WsgBgx7901.html</original file>

<question from>



LottyBet...
Member since: 14 January 2008
Total points: 3458 (Level 4)



</question from>



<question>



Is there a particular order to the Dexter books by Jeff Lindsay?



I want to read the books the TV show Dexter is based on but there seems to be loads of them and I don't know if they follow on and are in order or if they are they separate stories?



</question>



<additional details>



I've watched season 1 and I'm currently watching the 2nd. I'm in the UK so I don't think season 3 will be on for ages (season 2 is still only on Sky it hasn't even got to normal TV yet) x x



Hiya Trixie. I think just start reading the books. Like the first answer says they are different from the show.



</additional details>



<answer from>



Tatiana C
Member since: 11 September 2008
Total points: 138 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Darkly Dreaming Dexter
Dearly Devoted Dexter
Dexter in the Dark

All the books are good, but they differ pretty significantly from the show. Some major plot points were changed from the novels. As to which is better... that's a toss up. There are things I like about both, but I'm really inclined to like the show more. That's very unusual for me, but there you have it.

This being said, one thing I really like about the book is that it more effectively communicates how... cold Dexter is. On the show, his fake warmth almost seems so genuine, you come to believe it. In the book, there is no mistaking Dexter for the monster he is.

I highly recommend you read the books AND watch the show (season three starts next month, so you've got some catching up to do!)



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks great answer x



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Enquire
Member since: 05 December 2007



</answer from>



<answer>



To add to this answer, the 4th book in the series is Dexter by Design, which is out in the UK in February 2009.
The Fantastic Fiction website http://www.fantasticfiction.co.uk/l/jeff... is excellent for listing books in series, and your local library can help with this as well.

<question>



Was Shakespeare rich and were his plays a success immediately? Thanks?



Thank You =]



</question>



<answer from>



allen555
Member since: 18 October 2006
Total points: 12518 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



No and no. He left his second best bed to his wife in his will. He was born and died on 23rd April. His plays were of limited success during his life and he always struggled to pay the bills.



</answer>



<answer from>



SteveT
Member since: 06 October 2006
Total points: 21531 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



He became quite rich - certainly better off than most playwrights of his day and bought a share in the theatre his company used and a country house back in his home town.

Some of his plays were more successful than others but he was certainly famous as a playwright in his own lifetime.

You can clearly see that this was the case because of the Folio edition of his plays published soon after his death.  Had the plays not already been successful this would not have been brought out because it would never have sold.

His plays remained popular up to the Civil War, then became less so after the Restoration and were revived once again in the late eighteenth century and have remained on stage ever since



</answer>



<answer from>



Lucky Man 2
Member since: 06 October 2007
Total points: 12669 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



No the plays did not become famous until much later.



</answer>



<answer from>



Jim L
Member since: 23 December 2007
Total points: 6655 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



History



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes, his plays were a success and he became rich, though not immediately.  He was able to buy the biggest house in Stratford and get a grant of arms for his family.



Source(s):



Lives of Shakespeare



</answer>



<answer from>



Jackie Brown
Member since: 13 March 2007
Total points: 3180 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Books & Authors



</answer from>



<answer>



A lot of info. about Shakespeare during his playwright years is unknown - they are called "The Lost Years" by Shakespearean scholars. We DO know that his plays were very popular in his time - and he did make a decent living. But specifics on just how rich he was are unknown. It is likely that he spent as much as he made, as soon as he made it, based on what we know of his lifestyle.



I would suggest checking out this website:

http://www.shakespeare-online.com/biogra...

There is a great biography - with detailed info. There is even a copy of his will ;) That might help you - it would at least tell you much money he had left when he died.



</answer>



<answer from>



piccolo0...
Member since: 05 May 2008
Total points: 1571 (Level 3)

Fun fun answers to this question though eh?

<question from>



ruby
Member since: 17 September 2008
Total points: 96 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



I think Tennyson wrote "oh for the touch of a hand that is now gone, and the voice that is free" ?



can anyone tell me what poem it comes from



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



Ruby, it's "Break, break, break".



See the difference is '... a voice that is still' and not '... a voice that is free'

Break, break, break,



On thy cold gray stones, O sea!
And I would that my tongue could utter



The thoughts that arise in me.

O, well for the fisherman's boy,



That he shouts with his sister at play!
O, well for the sailor lad,



That he sings in his boat on the bay!

And the stately ships go on



To their haven under the hill;
But O for the touch of a vanished hand,



And the sound of a voice that is still!

Break, break, break,



At the foot of thy crags, O sea!
But the tender grace of a day that is dead



Will never come back to me.

-- Alfred, Lord Tennyson



</answer>

<question from>



Annerszz
Member since: 09 July 2008
Total points: 392 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



What order do these go in? Or is there any?



'Kurt Vonnegut' books.
Is there a certain order? Are they any good?



</question>



<answer from>



Enquire
Member since: 05 December 2007



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Here is a list of all of his books and short stories. 
I don't think there is any order, or if there is it will be in the order they were written, so go by the year it was published.
As to whether or not they are "any good", that is a matter of opinion and taste, you'll just have to read them and decide for yourself.

Novels
Player Piano (1952) 
The Sirens of Titan (1959) 
Mother Night (1961) 
Cat's Cradle (1963) 
God Bless You, Mr. Rosewater; or, Pearls before Swine (1965) 
Slaughterhouse-Five; or, The Children's Crusade (1969) 
Breakfast of Champions; or, Goodbye Blue Monday (1973) 
Slapstick; or, Lonesome No More (1976) 
Jailbird (1979) 
Deadeye Dick (1982) 
Galápagos (1985) 
Bluebeard (1987) 
Hocus Pocus (1990) 
Timequake (1997)



Collections of short stories and essays
Canary in a Cathouse (1961) 
Welcome to the Monkey House: A Collection of Short Works (1968) 
Wampeters, Foma and Granfalloons (1974) 
Palm Sunday (1981) 
Fates Worse than Death (1991) 
Bagombo Snuff Box: Uncollected Short Fiction (1999) 
God Bless You, Dr. Kevorkian (1999) 
A Man Without a Country (2005) 
Armageddon in Retrospect (2008, posthumous)



If you want more information about Kurt Vonnegut. Try the wikipedia entry, or visit his official website. See the links below.

This answer was provided by Enquire, a 24-hour, live question answering and enquiry service offered by public librarians across England and Scotland in collaboration with partners in the United States.



If you liked our answer and would like us to help you find another, you can chat with one of us right now by clicking on Enquire on the People’s Network site at http://www.peoplesnetwork.gov.uk



Source(s):



http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kurt_Vonneg...
http://www.vonnegut.com/



</answer>



<asker's comment>



thank you!



</asker's comment>

<question from>



Evolet
Member since: 26 March 2008
Total points: 47 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Best Arthurian book told from Guinevere's point of view?



I'm into Guinevere from the Arthurian Legend and want to read all the trilogies told from her point of view that are out there. First one I started with was The Dragon Queen by Alice Borchardt but I didn't like it that much because the characters didn't come alive to me and I couldn't relate to them emotionally.



So which trilogy do you think is the best? And why?



I want to read:
Queen of Camelot by Nancy McKenzie
The Guinevere Trilogy by Persia Woolley
The Guinevere Trilogy by Rosalind Miles
The Guinevere Trilogy by Sarah Newman
Young Guinevere by Robert D. San Souci

If I'm missing anything out then let me know or recommend me more! Thanks.



</question>



<answer from>



Motörhead Fan
Member since: 08 May 2007
Total points: 4850 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Guinevere's autobiography says this:

"I don't know why I bothered following Arthur, he was a drunk, and the quest for the Grail consumed him! After nearly six years of touring with the Round Table, I decided to quit and take up my own solo career!"



</answer>



<answer from>



Jude
Member since: 20 June 2006
Total points: 15334 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



'The Mists of Avalon' by Marion Bradley is a great read, it is actually told from the point of view of Morgaine who was the half-sister of King Arthur.  However it also looks at Guinevere's point of view as well.  It is basically the Arthurian legend from the point of view of the women in Arthur's life, and is a really good book.



</answer>



<answer from>



Chutch
Member since: 04 June 2007
Total points: 786 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Just to add to Jude's answer the Marion Bradley books are also part of a trilogy.

The Mists of Avalon
The Lady of Avalon
(Priestess of Avon) bit unsure about the title of that one, it was a while ago!

I would definitely re-read them again though as they are very good and really delve deep into the Arthur myth.

Happy reading!

<answer from>



Ichigo
Member since: 31 March 2008
Total points: 144 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I consider myself to be really good at the beginnings, but I have a hard time with the ending if I don't have it when I start writing. I don't really have trouble with writing the scenes unless I'm writing something I know nothing about, or I am lacking inspiration. When that happens I take a break, clear my head, and then come back and read what I already wrote, editing. Most of the time my pen just flows and I don't even think about all the details, my brain adds them as I edit. Sometimes I wake up in the middle of the night with an excellent idea, but I forget it when I get up in the morning. I hate when that happens, so I learned to put a notebook by my bedside.



</answer>



<answer from>



Archie + Gossip girl!

<answer from>



WildSpir...
Member since: 09 September 2008
Total points: 129 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Sometimes, I myself am writing a story and have been for quite a while. Every once in a while I will have times when I cant write to save my life and end up deleting everything that I had just wrote. I find that if you decide to create something in your story that will change the outcome or plot that you should sit down and prepare yourself for everything that you will need to explain, write, and extrapolate on. If you suddenly decide to add some random character "cause he's cool." Make sure that you have a reason behind the sudden change. I tend to add things that dont have a true meaning and are pointless to the plot and overall scheme of things. Make sure that you try to keep everything close to the plot to avoid the reader losing interest and getting confused. AND about endings . . . I DO find that difficult because I just want to keep going on and on . . . and on . . . kinda like this answer.

lol, I love to write and it kinda is apparent . . . would you like to read my story.



</answer>

<answer>



Yeah I do find it hard to write stories.



I have no problem with having ideas for them but I can never ever finish writing one. If I have the beginning I don't have the middle or the end, or i might just get an idea for one scene and not be able to move much further from there.

I am also dyslexic, I don't have many problems with spellings but grammar and punctuation can be quite a problem for me.

After saying all that I probably think i'd find it much harder NOT writing stories because then they would just stay in my head and clutter up against each other until they drive me crazy. So I guess its good to look at it all in perspective

<answer from>



CameronS...
Member since: 20 August 2008
Total points: 370 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I'm 122000 words into my new novel, and I think my head is about to explode. There are so many things I'm worried about- it's too long, the plot doesn't make sense, some of the characters are paper-thin . . . the only thing that's keeping me going is the knowledge that some of the book is really good, and that if I work hard and focus, I WILL be able to finish it. I need to keep reminding myself that it's a LONG HAUL- I wrote three novels in a year and none of them were good enough to publish, and then I wrote a novel in 14 months and it WAS good enough, so the longer I take the better the follow-up will be.

I'm a terribly disorganised writer, so I don't 'plan' the days work like most authors. Instead, I just let the scenes flow. I always try and end a scene with a killer sentence that is so good that the reader has to keep going, and on the rare day that nothing comes to me, I get antsy and nervous. I aim to write two thousand words a day, and it's quite depressing to know that of those 2000 words, 1500 will end up being 'cut'.

The other thing that keeps me going is the fact that I love writing- the worst days writing I ever did was still better than my best day of 'real' work.

I ca



</answer>



<answer from>



Jenna
Member since: 10 May 2008
Total points: 281 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Writing comes quite naturally to me. It is the good ideas, stories, plots that don't flow as easily! It is very frustrating!



</answer>

<answer from>



sensualg...
Member since: 11 July 2006
Total points: 598 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I love writing.  Usually I'm inspired to write by a scene in a movie or something particularly good or bad I've read in a book, other times it may be a dream I've had that I think has some really good solid elements and plot points.  In all the cases I have a very vivid picture of who and what I want.  Occasionally my characters get off center because I'm having a bad day or a particularly good day and my characters don't seem true to the scene or themselves.  It's then that I may work the re-writes to get them back on track, really look at the scene.  Most of the time when I have one idea I find it breaks off and blossoms into several ideas and the words always seem to flow.  Lately I've felt like I've used all the words in the English language to describe my loves scenes and romantic moments (I'm a romance writer) then I realized how many abandoned notes I had scribbled around and tore into them.  Many times I'll skip those scenes until I feel amorous.  Similarly if I want a particularly authentic fight scene I'll study an action adventure movie or wait until someone ticks me off driving and pour those emotions into the writing.  And I've learned not to give the emotion away, I can stew for a minute or two but mostly I can analyze in a way that I can then project into the story whether it be by setting or tone or plot or character.



And somewhere along the lines the story speeds up and in order to keep up and stay true to the story I do handwrites then type that way I can have a type of outline to follow and re-work.  I may have the scenes out of order in the book but at least they're all there and then the typewritten copy is linnear so I don't lose any plot points, build up, character development etc...



I make sure I do a page a day or sometimes a chapter even when I don't want to and when it's so bad I put it somewhere else because later I need a fight and that scene I wrote before is close to perfect with a few edits.  Either way I don't 'delete' per se I just put to one side that way the ideas are always available to step up when I think I'm fresh out of ideas.  Even if they don't work sometimes they can be an inspiration and sometimes that's all a writer needs.

J...



</answer>



<answer from>



La la la
Member since: 13 August 2007
Total points: 1098 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes



</answer>

<answer from>



Marie111
Member since: 28 August 2008
Total points: 860 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Well, this is only my opinion but I was very moved by "The Five People you Meet in Heaven."



I'm not that great at sticking with a book. If it bores me, it bores me, and I tend to abandon it a couple of chapters in; but this one I read right through. I couldn't put it down.

It's very nicely written with a simple narrative style, so no need for a dictionary in one hand as you read. And I think it would make great subject material for an essay. There's a lot to explore there in terms of human relationships and how they interweave both in this life and possibly the one beyond.



But everyone is different, and you must go by what you like yourself.



</answer>

<answer from>



jess7878
Member since: 02 July 2008
Total points: 152 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



"Before you, Bella, my life was like a moonless night. Very dark, but there were stars - points of light and reason....And then you shot across my sky like a meteor. Suddenly everything was on fire; there was brilliancy, there was beauty. When you were gone, when the meteor had fallen over the horizon, everything went black. Nothing had changed, but my eyes were blinded by light. I couldn't see the stars anymore, and there was no more reason for anything."



- Edward to Bella in NEW MOON

I know it's a long one...but I love it! I cried the first time I read it. I know, I'm such a sap.



Jessica Brody
author of THE FIDELITY FILES (St. Martin's Press 2008)
http://www.TheFidelityFiles.com



</answer>

<question>



Is being an author that great?



i'm 16 years old,love writing ,i almost do it instinctively.The words flow down and they're just there.But i'm afraid that's the wrong thing for me,i'm afraid that even if i got published and became a well known author would that realy be great...what do u think?..should i die and be sure that there's one soul out there that felt happy or hopeful for reading my books.I know it sounds stupid,but i can't just be average in the one arena i believe i belong in...so what is greatness really?



</question>

<question from>



Book C
Member since: 30 October 2008
Total points: 96 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Canadian book Publisher POD?



Many places for Canadians to self-publish at an affordable price with small minimums are usually in the USA, where postage costs are often more than the printing cost. Using Create-a-space.com service (https://www.createspace.com/) a soft cover book cost an amazing $4.10 (US) to print but $24.00 and up to mail it. With current currency exchange- there is not way to sell the book in Canada. Similar problems occur with Lulu.com (http://lulu.com), the printing cost  is affordable, but shipping at 2-3 times that cost for delivery from South Carolina. A Small Mystery Novel that the author has added $1.00 to his printing cost, sold for $6.95 (US$) but shipping and packaging was $21.30 more.



Readers BookCase Publishing is offering both conventional and self-publish services, as made in Canada, geared to Canadian marketing and affordable. Picking economical book sizing, will give you  books printed and delivered at price you will be able to sell. Authors are able to avoid shipping costs, by selling it on line through their eStore. https://wingrove-press.com/books/



Most of the other sources for printing in Canada, charge large setup fees or require a large production run. BlitzPrint (www.Blitzprint.com) quoted Size: 6x9



Number of Pages: 190



Finishing:  Soft Cover Binding



Prepress:



Disk/Files Provided



Proofs:



PDF Proof Supplied



Shipping:



FOB Plant



Paper Stock:



Interior will be printed on 60 pound book offset



Covers are printed full color on one side on 10pt C1S. All covers are automatically laminated.



All prices in Canadian Dollars:



Qty: 100 Price: $ 627



Qty: 250 Price: $ 1,241



Qty: 500 Price: $ 2,207



--------------------------------------...



Additional Charges: One-time Setup Fee, based on the following:



$58 for supplied PDF files, print ready
$116 for supplied SOURCE files, print ready
OR, use our all-inclusive design services http://www.blitzprint.com/design.htm



Corrections or alterations to jobs in production will be subject to additional charges.



Shipping is invoiced at actual cost.



Terms: 100% up front with shipping charges collected prior to books shipping



This quote is based on Print Ready Files supplied and current paper prices and is subject to confirmation at time of order placement.



Please add to this answer, if you find affordable priced Canadian POD,  for as a Canadian there don't seem to be many alternatives, other than  going with the relatively new family run business mentioned earlier.



</question>

<question>



ISBN and ISSN question?



Our company has published a few books/journals that have both an ISBN and an ISSN. The director now wants barcodes on the books. Do I need to print a barcode for both ISBN and ISSN on the book?



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



Well, I'd say that was a decision to be made by "the director", whoever that is.



If he or she wants barcodes, he or she should tell you what type of barcodes he or she wants.



</answer>

<question from>

<question>



What were Edna's "Awakenings?"?

<question from>



Mr. Man
Member since: 02 January 2008
Total points: 1939 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



Perks of being a Wallflower songs?



If you were making a movie about this book, what songs would you use and why. Here's a breif summary of the book:



"As "Charlie" enters high school he must deal with the suicide of his single close friend in his class and an ever continuing feeling of guilt over the death of his Aunt. As an entering freshman, Charlie finds friendship in two seniors Sam (who he falls in love with) and Patrick. Sam and Patrick introduce Charlie to their friends, who immediatly accept Charlie into the group. As Charlie begins to get into school his English teacher, Bill, recognizes his genius and begins to give him work beyond the class room to stimulate and interest him. The relationship between Bill and Charlie progresses from teacher and student to a true friendship.



As the book countinues Charlie matures and begins to become intergrated into highschool. He deals with his first girlfriend and his first breakup, Sex, drugs and rock and roll all are introduced to him. As he begins to become more confortable with his life, he uncovers an ugly supressed memory that changes his life."



Thanks!



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



I don't mean to be obvious, but you'd have to use the Smiths' track "Asleep" in a very understated kind of way (given its importance in the book.  You're talking about that MTV/Chbosky book, right?).



I would probably also use some new Iron and Wine, and likely some Grizzly Bear.



</answer>

<question from>



Jesus_ch...

<question>



Is it good to write a list of books that I know I want to read?



I made a list of books that I do want to read. And I cross them off when I am finished with the books. And I will just keep adding more books until I am down reading. Which I know wont be for a while.



</question>



<answer from>



mt_evere...
Member since: 02 September 2008
Total points: 541 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Yep, I've done that. It was my New Year's Resolution to read more this year...so I made a list of books I want to read early on and actually what happened is I started adding more *cough Twilight saga cough* and so I kept adding and reading...and some of the older books have taken a back seat...It's a nice thing to have that list around to remind you.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Bess
Member since: 14 April 2006
Total points: 5734 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



I think that's a very good idea. As such you will know which books precisely you want and not choose any nonsense. The problem with me is that I always lose my lists and as such spend, or rather waste, a lot of time trying to remember what books I want to look for and read. I does not matter however long you take to read all the books on your list, the essential is that you have taken the pains to write it down and go by it, which, believe me, is very essential.



Hope this helps and good reading!



</answer>



<answer from>



Tammish
Member since: 20 October 2008
Total points: 552 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Counterpoint here--lists make me feel guilty. (Looking at all those titles that I have yet to cross off...) And having a list tends to take away, for me, the joy of discovery when I walk the shelves at the public library or the aisles at the local bookstore. I don't want to pick up a book and say, "Okay, here's one for the list." I want to pick up a book and be so excited by the premise or the writing that I MUST read this book right now. Lists end up feeling too much like "should reads" to me.



But whatever keeps ANY of us reading, I'm all in favor of it.



</answer>



<answer from>



Lila~!...
Member since: 03 October 2008
Total points: 920 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yep! I did this on monday. I've got 46 books on my list so far and i'm half way through the first one already.
I wrote it out in different coloured pens so it's more readable and stuck it on the wall. Every time i finish a book i'm going to cross it off and date it and replace with another book.
Good luck!



</answer>



<answer from>



John B
Member since: 05 November 2007
Total points: 597 (Level 2)

<question>



What is up with Twilight?



what is it abot...just a brief summary please? (in your own effin words, seriously people, dont copy and paste it from a dumb website ty :) )all of my friends are walking around campus looking down, reading the book Twilight,the say its about vampires,i'm not sure if i want to read it,but i saw a commercial earlier today and it seems intersting.

</additional details>



<answer from>



Menina Bonita▐▐
Member since: 11 March 2008
Total points: 141 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



lol i know what you mean everybody around me was practically hypnoticed by that book i was like 'vampires? hell no i am not reading them' guess what? i became addicted



twilight is pretty much about a girl who falls in love with a vampire. She moves to a small town named Forks (in Washington) in order to live with her father. She's intrigued by this gorgeous boy named Edward Cullen and his family because no one in the school really knows anythign about them, and they seem to be perfect. She's also awfully curious as to why Edward seems to hate her from the very first second. A lot of stuff happens, she finds out Edward's a vampire and lucky for her, he likes her enough to resist her blood. The rest of the book is about their struggles because obviously it can't be easy for a vampire and human to be in love. wiki has a great summary but it tells most major plot elements so if u want to know all of the story, look at it. I loved this book, and if you haven't read it yet, read it! hope this helps =]



</answer>



<answer from>



HEY84
Member since: 14 August 2008
Total points: 850 (Level 2)

<answer>

<answer from>



vanilla
Member since: 30 October 2008
Total points: 147 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



You gotta read it girl before the movie comes out November 21!!! Seriously, I can't put it down, its amazing!!! Simple but beautiful girl Bella moved to sleepy town Forks to live with her father after her mum decides to remarry... She goes into this high school and was intrigued by a group of students who were too good looking and sophisticated yet strange in a way cos during lunch hour when everybody else are eating, the group just sits there everyday NOT eating at all (LOL)..Then to make it short, she fell in love with one of the guys named Edward Cullen & found out he was a Vampire....Simple plot but the way it was being written, awesome!! My fave line would be, 'I MAY NOT BE HUMAN, BUT I AM STILL A MAN..." cos he was so in love with her and fighting so hard not to suck her blood and kill her.... Later on in the story, it becomes a love triangle of some sort between him, a Vampire, Bella, a human, and Jacob Black, who happens to be a werewolf.... :)



</answer>

<question>



Can you suggest any good books for 13 year old girl to read?



Looking for present ideas. My niece has asked for books, but wants a surprise. She loves reading and has read a lot of the obvious choices.



</question>



<answer from>



marqueen...
Member since: 26 January 2008
Total points: 26971 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Books & Authors



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Eight Cousins, Little Women, Little Men, Jo's Boys - Louisa May Alcott
Pride and Prejudice by Jane Austen
Anne of Green Gables and sequels by Lucy Maud Montgomery



Fantasy:
Inkheart series by Cornelia Funke
Fablehaven series by Brandon Mull
Eragon, Eldest, Brisingr by Christopher Paolini
The Chronicles of Narnia by CS Lewis
A Wrinkle in Time series by Madeleine L'Engle
The Hobbit and The Lord of the Rings Trilogy by JRR Tolkien
http://books4teensandadults.googlepages....



</answer>

</asker's comment>

Anything by Gail Carson Levine - ex: Ella Enchanted, The Two Princesses of Bamarre, Fairest
Anything by Shannon Hale - ex: Princess Academy, The Goose Girl, Book of a Thousand Days
Most books by Meg Cabot - ex: The Mediator series, The Princess Diaries series
The Nancy Drew series by Carolyn Keene
A Northern Light by Jennifer Donelly
The Private series by Kate Brian
The Luxe by Anna Godbersen (series)



I'm 14 so I probably have a lot of the same interests as your niece. I hope I helped!

<question>



I've completed a children's book including artwork. What next?



I wrote a children's book for some students at my school. It's completely finished including the art work. Everything is put together and completed. Where do I go from here in order to publish is, distribute it, get it in the hands of parents and children everywhere and make a little money doing it?



</question>



<answer from>



Kabillio...
Member since: 14 June 2008
Total points: 650 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Christopher Little Literacy Agency



They dealt with the likes of JK ROwling and Darren Shan and of course moi



Source(s):



My Brain



</answer>



<answer from>



MOM KNOWS EVERYTHING
Member since: 09 June 2006
Total points: 27744 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



Sorry to contradict the previous answer, but Christopher Little is not accepting any submissions at this time.
http://www.christopherlittle.net/



This website will help you find an agent who might handle your work
http://www.writers.net/agents.html



</answer>

<question from>

<question>



Help with writing a childrens story for english? Is this a good start?



Once upon a time lived a little boy named Peter. He lived with his mummy and daddy in a small yellow cottage. The cottage had really tiny windows with red curtains, a blue door and a bright colouful garden full of pretty flowers. Behind the cottage was a huge green grassed feild with lots of brown tall horses on.



Any ideas of where i could go with the story what could happen please help im really bad at writing storys



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



Maybe lil Petey could go out and pick red, red apples, green grapes from a vine, orange pumpkins from the patch and the most purple blue blue berries from a bush when it rains and it seems the rain is washing away all the colors.  It is as if the world is a steel gray.  Pete complains how he hates the rain for stealing his 'happiness and joy' but his parents explain why we need the rain and just when Petey accepts rain as a good thing and dressing in his duck suit (rain suit) it stops.  Next comes fog making it spooky and scary and then the rain bow which fill the sky with all the colors around his little yellow cottage.



J...



</answer>






<original file>790.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk81651.txt</current file name>




<category>



Arts & Humanities



Books & Authors



</category>



<question from>



♥perishe...
Member since: 07 July 2006
Total points: 3606 (Level 4)



</question from>



<question>



What's up with alfred, lord tennyson's name?



why does alfred, lord tennyson's name have a comma?



</question>



<additional details>



oh. then, why do people call him alfred lord tennyson, but they call byron byron?



</additional details>



<answer from>



MOM KNOWS EVERYTHING
Member since: 09 June 2006
Total points: 27675 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



Because the "Lord" is not his name, it's his title.



So his name was Alfred Tennyson.  Once he became a Lord, one way to write his name is Alfred, Lord Tennyson.



The same applies to Byron.



His full name, reflecting his title,  was George Gordon, Lord Byron.
Queen Elizabeth can be referred to, among other things, as Queen Elizabeth II, Lord of Mann.



ETA:  To answer your further question, people refer to both men in various ways.  Tennyson is often called "Tennyson".  Byron is often called "Lord Byron".



Source(s):



http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lord



</answer>



<answer from>



scandalous candice
Member since: 11 June 2007
Total points: 719 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



He was a 1st Baron, a descendant of King Edward II of England, and appropriately one would write his name as such.



His full name and title is Alfred Tennyson, 1st Baron Tennyson.



When you are a descendant of a King your title is a show of familial tie, regency and honor.



Source(s):



BA/MA English



</answer>

Hey :) I read ALOT, lol. I use the website: whatshouldireadnext.com

<answer from>



MOM KNOWS EVERYTHING
Member since: 09 June 2006
Total points: 27675 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



I love to browse the library shelves, picking up books that look interesting, and reading their cover blurbs.  I also keep track of my favorite authors, and try to read their new books when they come out.



But here's a marvelous website where people talk about books all the time.  I get most of my ideas lately from friends I've made on this site.



www.librarything.com



</answer>



<answer from>



perishe...
Member since: 07 July 2006
Total points: 3606 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



I do one of the following:
-go to barnes and noble
-go on goodreads.com (their motto is "see what your friends are reading!"
-go on amazon.com which lets you know what others bought
-if I had a local used bookstore w/ people I liked I would ask them
-read other books of authors whose book you liked
-read the books of that authors' friends/ associated authors
-look on a top 100 books list (though those are ehh)



</answer>



<answer from>



BooksLuv...
Member since: 18 April 2006
Total points: 4109 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Read the monthly reviews in papers. You will be able to gauge whether you like the story line or not from the review. That's pretty effective.
Get a library membership. You can check out books and authors to see if you like them. Borrow books from friends and get recommendations from friends as well. Happy Reading!



</answer>



<answer from>



theacrob
Member since: 18 July 2007
Total points: 3169 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



One book usually leads to another. If I like an author, I will read more of his or her books. I read about the author (who inspired him or her, what time period they are from) and get ideas from that.



Also, I hang out in book stores a lot.



I read book reviews in magazines and in the newspaper. This leads me to books I might not have heard of otherwise.



My friends are readers, and I am interested in what they like to read.



Mostly, I just read what I never had time to read in school.



</answer>
