<question from>



tarek rahil
Member since: 25 October 2008
Total points: 70 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



How can a detective become one in a novel?



i mean what are the motivations behind becoming a detective ..is there's any reason or way to do so in  young age(i need this for my novel so help plz)



</question>



<answer from>



mt_evere...
Member since: 02 September 2008
Total points: 545 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Well...my favorite detectives have a gift for seeing things others don't...and they're able to put these little things together and make big things out of them which lead to the case being solved...these are TV detectives though...not sure if there's a dramatic difference...



So your detective could maybe as a child (unless it's supposed to be a child detective, either way) Could just realize they have a knack for seeing the unseen...they're able to think logically...they have a want to help others...there could be a certain case that hit close to home with them and they felt compelled to help solve it because of something that happened in their life...



That's my input...if I knew more about the character I might be able to help more...maybe...hope I have helped though!



</answer>



<answer from>



MOM KNOWS EVERYTHING
Member since: 09 June 2006
Total points: 27677 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



Depends on where you are.  In the United States, there are different types of detective.  There are police detectives, private detectives, and so on.  You cannot become either of those things until you are an adult, and for a police detective you need a lot of training and experience, and you have to pass a difficult test.



Private detectives have to be licensed.  As for "motivation", I assume you mean what makes a person WANT to be a detective?



You can surely make that part up for the purposes of your novel.



</answer>

<answer>

</answer>



<answer from>



ensign18...
Member since: 16 June 2006
Total points: 5658 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



No, I think fiction readers -- seeing how a plausible world can be constructed within a work of non-fact -- tend to gain perspective on the world around them, discerning what works and what doesn't.  Whether the setting is another planet or one familiar to them from our world already, the fact that every reality has certain rules the author(s) are willing to follow (see a story lately without cause preceding effect or the "pull" of gravity?) indicates rules that readers can and must follow.



Whether they choose to write their own fiction (I've written two novels, one novella, and I'm working now on one more of each) or whatever direction they take in life, they discern a specific framework to work in inspired by a fictional example.



Often, that's the only way to communicate a truth to a reader or hearer -- consider epics like the Iliad or the Odyssey, the Star Wars saga, or the parables of Jesus for they communicate some specific truth about human beings because they're all written by and for ... human beings.



Far from losing their capacity to think logically, fiction and material presented as fiction (Christians, I am NOT saying Jesus' parables are fiction, please reread this section and substitute "story" for "fiction" if it pleases you), from "The Cat In The Hat" to "Watchmen" enables its reader to draw conclusions from it about life they never would have from mere fact.



</answer>

<question>

LOTS of fights, assassinations, sex, and other exciting material! so can anyone tell me where and how to publish a book?!!!

sorry about the same additional details twice! lo! i thought it had failed the first time when i wrote it, so i came back and wrote it again!



Spywriter, thanks for the tips!!! don't worry though! i'm not planning on trying to publish it until i've gone over my story a few times (AFTER i've completed it!), and make any changes i see fit! actually i'm in the process of reading it through what i've written so far, right now, although i'm not finished yet (because my story is so long even now that i have a hard time remembering what i wrote!), and ALREADY i've made several changes! so u don't worry about that!



oh...one thing...about the name!!! sorry, i wrote 'Shinobi no mono' in my original question instead of 'The Shinobi no mono' which is what i actually dubbed my story as!!! lo! forgot to write 'the'!!!

<answer from>



A+J forever
Member since: 05 February 2007
Total points: 999 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



www.quizilla.com is a good place to post up your stories. they publish it for you, so your ideas cant be stolen. u can post about one a day to keep your readers coming back for more. (although u can post as many as u want. i usually like posting one a day)



its great! but make sure to save all ur stuff on your computer because sometimes the site crashes and you have to rewrite it if you were writing it on the web. a lot of ppl who use quizilla post very long stories, so your book should be fine. also, readers rate your stuff, so you can have a good idea of what people think of your stories before getting them officially published on paper.



good luck to you! :)



btw, my URL on quizilla is gummybare76



although it doesnt really work anymore cuz i think someone hacked into it, you can read my stuff if you like.



see you on quizilla! :D



</answer>

<category>



Arts & Humanities



Books & Authors



</category>



<question from>



Meg D
Member since: 22 October 2008
Total points: 162 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Coming up with a plot?



I like to write and I'm just wondering what some ways are that you guys use to come up with plot ideas.  Any suggestions?



</question>



<answer from>



roximunr...
Member since: 03 March 2007
Total points: 731 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Thinly veiled stories of people from your past.



Items in the newspaper or on the news that make you think "what if".



Writer's Digest books. They have more than a few on creating writing ideas.



Personal fantasy involving thinly veiled people from your present. But you could get sued.



Take an old OLD idea and modernize it (like centuries old. ie Homer's Odyssey became Oh Brother Where Art Thou)



Read John Campbell's and Carl Jung and Caroline Myss' books about archetypes. Place archetypes in modern setting.



Write your own little Million Little Pieces. Fool Oprah!



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks for the ideas!



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



lawlman9...
Member since: 31 October 2007
Total points: 130 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Do something like, cause and effect, and tie stuff together. Like: this bad event happened, so this guy did something to stop that, but in stopping that, the guy used something that would make another bad thing happen.



Then, try to add some personal stuff if you like: The guy did not know who was his father, and the bad thing is a bad guy which is his father. Probably the father tells his side of the story and the main character has an inner conflict.



Cause and effect, relationships, past events, keep those in mind ;D.



</answer>



<answer from>



wolf heart
Member since: 20 October 2008
Total points: 156 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



me an my group of friends are all writing and have written two books. the way that we come up with plot ideas is to sometimes think oh something that you like our hate about your life. then you would come up with a main character. he/she would be like you. you would be able to make up a life wheter its in the gladiator days, caveman days, or 7003. my group all has their own character in my story. that makes it easier on cominng up with the characters personalities. also for the plot, there may be a tv show or movie that you like, you could base your story of of that.



</answer>



<answer from>



Mrs. Sasuke Uchiha
Member since: 04 August 2008
Total points: 258 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



base it loosley on things from your past, or write about something you love. if you daydream a lot, write your daydreams down, you may be able to make your ideas a book. that's what i did!



</answer>

<question>



Title for this story?



I got the idea for this while passing by an old animal hospital, the place looks abandoned. Anyway got this idea for a story how it starts of like this.



Info: Birch-wood animal hospital was once a busy vet's office, patients varied from common pets to exotics. The office remained open until it folded on July 12th 1985. The building had been closed due to financial and health reasons. Now taking up residence are former patients  that were left behind. The main character is Walker, an albino Belgian shepherd. Other residents include Mozart the cat,  Mullet the english mastiff, Dayton the ferret and other characters, including Portia, another shepherd. One day, Walker hears howling and other noises from a locked room.  After week of hearing the noise, Walker decides to investigate and discovers one of the main causes of why the office was closed.



I had originally titled the story 'Condemned' since the vet's office is no longer used but thought it was little dark. The animals do talk in the story. It's not a horror story since I don't write in that catagory.



Anyway, could use some title suggestions, any takers?



</question>

<question>



Are there any other women in their thirties in love with Edward Cullen?



I'm a happily married, 33-year-old woman, but I just can't get him off my mind. Now, I know he looks 17, but he's so much more mature, wise, and romantic because of his years in existence. He's a dream come true. Am I the only woman in this age group to have feelings for this fictional character?



</question>



<additional details>



It's funny ... some people think older women liking Edward is comparable to a pedophile. Yet, it's okay for him to love someone who is so young and impressionable. To me, that seems more wrong. He's got the mind of a man and the body of a boy...



</additional details>



<answer from>



springer...
Member since: 16 October 2008
Total points: 238 (Level 1)

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



love your question - I'm in my fifties and love Edward - when someone in my writers group recommended twilight I said no way i hate stories with vampires and werewolves - was I wrong! love the whole series and although I write romance novels I just couldn't get enough of this story



</answer>



<asker's comment>



I love this answer. I have trouble thinking of Edward as a physical being, so to me he is ageless. It's the idea of him that I love--his compassion, devotion, wisdom, and inner being. On the surface he seems overbearing and harsh, but if you look deeper, you will see the beauty in his intensity.



</asker's comment>

<question from>

<question>



Granny nightgown needed?



Where can I find a granny nightgown with cap for a reasonable price. I can only find expensive authentic prairie ones and others have wolfe parts attached to it. Help, I need it for Halloween!



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



You could probably buy a long flannel nightgown at any major department store.  You might have to make your own hat.  You could buy some flannel at a fabric store.  I think that the kind of hat you are describing would probably just be a circle gathered with ribbon.  Someone at the fabric store might be able to help you with how to make one.



</answer>

<question from>



Abz.

</question from>



<question>



Help...Title for my Story?



3 boys(who are brothers) find a door to another world. a world of combat and magic. innit they find an enemy and the truth abou their horrific past and a long suffering battle begins. (Thats the plot line of my story).



I need good titles with descriptive words in it. Please Help.



ASAP. (:
x



</question>



<additional details>



It just has to be Descriptive lol.
It has to be really good. Eye-Catching.
Something using the word "Brotherhood". like Blood Brothers, or Brothers in arms or just anything reallllly good. (:
thankyou. x



</additional details>



<answer from>



durulz20...
Member since: 30 March 2006
Total points: 4608 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Lion, Witch and the Wardrobe.



</answer>



<answer from>



sn0zb0z
Member since: 20 April 2008
Total points: 6317 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Video & Online Games



</answer from>



<answer>



Sounds interesting. Why does it need to be descriptive? I think as long as it gives the reader some idea of what it is about or stands out then it's good. Without reading the story or having more to go on its not easy to come up with a title.



Also if you haven't actually written it yet then I suggest writing it (or at least a large part of it). Title isn't that important and if you have the story it will be easier to get a title.



Worlds combined?
Brothers together: A new world?
A past forgotten?
A past revealed?



If I were you I'd write down key words that are to do with the story and see what you come up with



</answer>



<answer from>



Helena-Jayne S
Member since: 30 October 2008
Total points: 109 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



The mysterious door



</answer>



<answer from>



los
Member since: 08 August 2006

</answer>



<answer from>



vamanosd...

<answer>

</answer>



<answer from>



Megan M.
Member since: 21 March 2007
Total points: 7190 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



um. you're the writer. writes write their OWN titles.



But I can help you, try choosing a name or phrase out of your book thats interesting, and at least has something to do with your book.



Try writing the title AFTER you write the book, I can promise you that that helps alot when searching for a title.



Source(s):



~Long time writer



</answer>

<current file name>yqa_uk85141.txt</current file name>




<category>



Arts & Humanities



Books & Authors



</category>



<question from>



belle_45...
Member since: 23 July 2008
Total points: 301 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



In Northanger Abbey, when does catherine first meet eleanor Tilney?



chapter please:)



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



Chapter VIII
http://www.mollands.net/etexts/northange...
"Here they were interrupted by a request from Mrs. Thorpe to Mrs. Allen, that she would move a little to accommodate Mrs. Hughes and Miss Tilney with seats, as they had agreed to join their party. This was accordingly done, Mr. Tilney still continuing standing before them; and after a few minutes' consideration, he asked Catherine to dance with him. This compliment, delightful as it was, produced severe mortification to the lady; and in giving her denial, she expressed her sorrow on the occasion so very much as if she really felt it that had Thorpe, who joined her just afterwards, been half a minute earlier, he might have thought her sufferings rather too acute. The very easy manner in which he then told her that he had kept her waiting did not by any means reconcile her more to her lot; nor did the particulars which he entered into while they were standing up, of the horses and dogs of the friend whom he had just left, and of a proposed exchange of terriers between them, interest her so much as to prevent her looking very often towards that part of the room where she had left Mr. Tilney. Of her dear Isabella, to whom she particularly longed to point out that gentleman, she could see nothing. They were in different sets. She was separated from all her party, and away from all her acquaintance; -- one mortification succeeded another, and from the whole she deduced this useful lesson, that to go previously engaged to a ball does not necessarily increase either the dignity or enjoyment of a young lady. From such a moralizing strain as this, she was suddenly roused by a touch on the shoulder, and turning round, perceived Mrs. Hughes directly behind her, attended by Miss Tilney and a gentleman. "I beg your pardon, Miss Morland," said she, "for this liberty, -- but I cannot anyhow get to Miss Thorpe, and Mrs. Thorpe said she was sure you would not have the least objection to letting in this young lady by you." Mrs. Hughes could not have applied to any creature in the room more happy to oblige her than Catherine. The young ladies were introduced to each other, Miss Tilney expressing a proper sense of such goodness, Miss Morland with the real delicacy of a generous mind making light of the obligation; and Mrs. Hughes, satisfied with having so respectably settled her young charge, returned to her party."



</answer>

<answer>



Yes, but the books have to be old enough not to be protected by copyright law any longer (usually at least 75 years old.)



That site is www.gutenberg.org.



There are thousands of books available there, but if you're looking for something recent, it won't be available to read for free on line.  Authors and publishers are entitled to be paid for their work, you know.



</answer>

<original file>1207.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk85606.txt</current file name>




<category>



Arts & Humanities



Books & Authors



</category>



<question from>



drizzttw...
Member since: 08 July 2008
Total points: 653 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Wrote a opening to a story ( gory )?



I’m going to tell you about the day that I lost my childhood, the day that started the rest of my life, that changed my ambitions, my goals, and ultimately my life.



It was three years ago in the small city of Charlottetown Prince Edward Island.  I was attending my regular schedule going to classes at Colonel  Gray High School but we just called it the gray back then.



I remember my first hint that something wasn’t quite right when my teacher..or substitute as she was for the past few days walked in and started speaking to the class.



Her voice was rough and low as a males and she had appeared to have started to sprout a bit of a beard.  I didn’t think much of it at the time, it was just one of those things that me and the other students in my class would make fun of her for later but, as the class progressed I could have sworn her face was starting to protrude around her mouth and her fingernails were getting longer.



Around the middle of class she started speaking very spaced she sort of sounded like that space captain on that “Star Trek” show.  I knew then and there something wasn’t right she didn’t even seem worried, like she didn’t know what was happening to her.



I got the gut feeling that I should leave the room, I felt in danger, so I raised my hand and asked if I could go to the bathroom and she said sure but, she looked like she was going to kill me.



I came back to the class after an extra long trip to the bathroom to find that the small plexiglass window on the door was covered in a red piece of paper, or so I thought it was.
I knocked on the door impatiently, I wanted to get back in because I didn’t need the teacher any angrier with me then she already was.



After about five minutes of knocking I got frustrated and walked outside to go to the window,  something didn’t feel right, my class was full of the “druggies” so it was usually very loud but I heard nothing.



I approached the window with caution and flipped off some kids who were making fun of me for stalking along the wall and when I got there and peered into the window. What I saw made me vomit there right against the chalkboard a kid I knew his name was Richard I think but he went by “big D” was through the board, his blood splattered across the board like some gruesome abstract portrait.



That’s not all I saw, the majority of the kids were hunched over their desks still as boards blood pooling beneath their skulls and I soon found out what really was covering the door, a thick trail of blood that lead down to the body of an old enemy of mine Percy Stone.



I slumped down to the grass horrified, that was the first lucky thing that saved my life that day for just as my head moved from where it was this beast jumped though the window maw clamping down with a thud where my head hd been moments before.
“****!” I exasperated, “what the hell was that thing!”



Before I could get a good look, it was off, into another classroom.



Stupidly I followed it to try to stop it, ha that’s a laugh if only I had known what the effects of this action would have been maybe I would have stopped but probably not I enjoy this life to much.



I saw it go into my morning math room and I swung my myself through the broken window.  What I saw startled me even more, the students were half massacred bodies littered the ground. and what was left of the living students were to scared to move the were all looking towards the same scene.



I followed their gaze and saw it, my teacher, or what as humanly left of her at least feeding on my math teacher.  I flinched as a heard the bone crunch and near vomited again at the gruesome sight and this saved my life for the second time that day, for as I keeled over in near vomiting state it jumped at me again and missed only to hit one of the few living students in the chest.



I  heard a horrible cracking sound which could only be the breaking of everyone of the girls ribs as the giant beast struck.



what do you honestly think :P



</question>

<category>



Arts & Humanities



Books & Authors



</category>



<question from>



selig t
Member since: 07 December 2007
Total points: 267 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



What is the difference between an epic poem and a novel?



</question>



<answer from>



theacrob
Member since: 18 July 2007
Total points: 3179 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Prose



</answer>



<answer from>



MOM KNOWS EVERYTHING
Member since: 09 June 2006
Total points: 27683 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



An epic poem is a story told in verse form.  A novel is written in prose form.



A fairly obvious distinction.



</answer>



<answer from>



LJ K
Member since: 28 May 2007
Total points: 48027 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Books & Authors



</answer from>



<answer>



Since most short stories can be of length anywhere from a few hundred words to about 17,500 words, and novellas 'start' at 17,500 and can be up to 40,000 words in length, with novels starting at 40,000 words on up to the stratosphere, the length of epic poems takes them right out of any possibility of being a novel since none I know of are at least 40,000 words long, though of course I don't know all epic poems.



Add to that the fact epic poems have at least a recognized meter if not a recognized rhyme and you see that epic poems and novels are most certainly not the same type of writing at all.



Source(s):



http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/novella
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/epic_poem
Suggest you follow any "External Links" to be found at the bottom of these entries for more information on this question.
Eng. Lit degree, post-grad writing courses, made living primarily as journalist who also had short fiction published and worked as editor, tutor, playwright before semi-retirement.



</answer>

<answer>

It's about a boy who has led a normal life until his parents and sister were brutally murdered by demons. <original file>13740.html</original file>

<category>



Arts & Humanities



Books & Authors



</category>



<question from>



Azriel
Member since: 29 February 2008
Total points: 8210 (Level 5)



</question from>



<question>



Authors - does one need to complete all research for a novel before beginning to write?



My mother along with a couple distant relatives of mine are working on a historical fiction novel based on real geneological events in our anscestor's lives.



My mother is working in the research end of things at the moment but will also be involved in the writing.



She recently wrote to the woman (some distant cousin or other) who is doing the main writing asking if next time they meet up they could discuss how the story is going to be written - what person it will be written in, whether or not there will be a narrator, whether or not they will flip between present and past etc. She also wanted to discuss a timeline for the writing of the book so they can have general deadlines to aim for.



She got a rather snippy response which basically said that such a thing is impossible without first gathering ALL their research about the setting, time-period, people, etc. That writing a novel can take up to 20 years and there is no way they can even begin to discuss writing chapters of the book beyond the first (which she already wrote).
Here's a quote "Before plotting, we need to determine the
theme, characters, events, descriptions, relationships, etc., etc.,etc. and so much more. Once we know those, we can go on to determine the structure and form of the book as well as how we will deal with issues like continuous or contiguous time, linear vs. non-linear construction , voice, point of
view, genre, and so on."



My question is - which of them is being unreasonable?
Is it unreasonable of my mom to expect to be able to flesh out the book's POV and general construction without having all the research done first? Or is the other lady unreasonable not to have a general idea of these things by this time?
(they've been working on this for about 5-6 months.)



</question>



<answer from>



BooksLuv...
Member since: 18 April 2006
Total points: 4137 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



I think both are being slightly unreasonable. Authors generally finish most of the research before they begin, but this definitely does not mean you cant discuss plots and characters or chapters before the research is complete. Both need to be done simultaneously. For eg, to get an outline of the characters, it is necessary to know which character is placed where, who is narrating, who is being villified,etc.Genre also needs to be kept in mind when conducting research. I think both should be involved in both parts of the novel's making.



</answer>



<answer from>



ruff-ruff grrrr
Member since: 27 December 2007
Total points: 1282 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Both are unreasonable.  The distant cousin is unreasonable for stating a novel like this could take upwards of twenty years.  That's complete nonsense.



I'll give her three at the most, but not twenty.



She is right however when she says SOME of the other things have to be understood better before a plot can be developed.  Characters, events, descriptions, and relationships are important.  Theme however, is something the writer develops AFTER the first draft.  Otherwise, if a writer begins with a theme, he's only going to end up with a preachy book that goes nowhere.



On the other hand, your mother is being unreasonable by saying she can develop the POV and time period construction without knowing these characters and their times better.  This isn't the case with complete fiction. Fiction writers make it up as they go along.  In her case however, she's dealing with real people who lived real lives.  How does your mother know she's not going to run into an engaging great-grandfather later on after she begins to write?  Someone who captivates her imagination, and shows her that he is what the whole family is about?  And therefore, should be who the book is about?  In that case, she'd have to scrap the whole book and start over again.



Both are being unreasonable.



ADD:
Your mother probably just wanted to discuss the concept of the book, because she's excited about starting it.  In that case, why not advise her to write a few short stories about the characters she does know.  Later, when she and her cousin get together, perhaps she can pull some of these SS's out and see if any of them will fit into the novel.  If not, she can start submitting them to some reputable journals so that she'll be able to find an agent once she does finish her book.



</answer>

<question from>



Bridget
Member since: 12 August 2008
Total points: 562 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Read my short story? Thoughts? Advice?



I don't know how I got here; all I know is, I've never been here before. A strange world between worlds. A world of nothingness. A space that is all mine. I see black, a deep black surrounding me, echoing through my mind. Everything's simple, slow, and clam; yet my mind has never been so busy. My mind is a waterfall, a constant rush of all lost thoughts and memories.



I remember my grandmother, and how her hands used to look like crinkled sandpaper; but were like velvet to touch. I remember letting the waves wash sticky watermelon from my skin at the beach. I remember how naked and smooth my legs felt, the fist time I shaved them. I remember stripping sheets of ugly wallpaper. I remember feeling weightless as my father pushes me on our old tire swing. What ever happened to our tire swing? I am an empty shell, occupied by nothing but a string of consciousness. My mind is on random.



I have flashes of unexplained images. Scrunched up paper, shriveling as it is slowly consumed by fire. A pink, toothless baby, taking his first breath. A flower opening itself. My dog. A tree crashing to the ground. Orange cordial spilling on a clean counter. Rubble clicking over one another. Ripples on an otherwise still lake. The wind turning the pages of a magazine, like an unobserved force.



Frustration melts through my body, taking away my warmth. I want to be able to smell, to open my eyes, to be in control of my body. I take a deep breath and tense up all over, an attempt to free myself from this calm that has become my prison. I focus. I hoping to hear, to twitch, to point, anything. Out of the blue, I cam smell my Grandma's house, the smell of old ladies. Then:



"Uh! Did you see that?! Roy? She moved her finger! Look! Look! She's doing it again!" A familiar voice fills the air.



Where have I heard her voice before? I can't remember.



I feel a clammy hand at my cheek, "Julia? Can you hear me, sweetheart?"



I focus on my finger, I move it.



The woman sobs, "Oh thank god" she whispers, "It's your mother darling. We're both here, your brother and I."



I feel a small hand on my leg; then a soft face, wet from tears. The vibrations from his sobs run up my body. I can't believe I forgot her voice, my adoring mother.



"Can you hear me sweetness? Are you there?"



I try to speak, my energy is gone. I want nothing more than to hold her hand, to show her that I hear her; but I'm cemented to the bed, a prisoner in my own body. I feel tired.



Mum starts to weep.



"It's okay, I'm fine. Just help me wake up." I try to tell her, nothing comes out.



"I'm so sorry Julia. I'm so, so sorry. Please wake up. Please."



Her tears send tingles down my spine as they land on my neck.



"I've called Auntie Jill, she's going to bring the re..." Her voice fades until it's gone completely. Then silence.



I remember my mother cradling me as I cried for one reason or another; she moped my runny nose with her sleeve and hummed. As my head pressed against her breast, I could hear her heart and her breathing. I felt as though I was back in the womb. Completely safe and warm. I try to imagine such a place, the womb, being a baby. It seems a world away.



I remember taking Roy to the park when he was a baby, he was so new and perfectly unspoiled. Everything we saw was like a new discovery through his eyes, he was fascinated. He'd stare at each blade of grass like it were a piece of art; and dig his tiny finger nails into the dirt, trying to stay as attached to this new world as he could. At that age, everything was so precious, so raw and untouched. It's a wonder how similar we all used to be, once upon a time.



I can hear a slow, steady beeping now. Then, a smoker's cough. I fall back asleep.



My chest hurts, like nothing I've ever felt before. My face is burning up. I can't breath, I can't think, there's nothing but pain. I feel hands all over me, they turn me onto my side. There's a sudden, sharp stab in my back, my chest hurts less now. I fall asleep.



I feel sunlight on my legs, and hear my mother in the background. She's crying. Please don't cry, Mum. I hear a man's voice, then heavy footsteps leaving the room; Mum's wailing grows louder. I put all my energy into trying to speak to her; instead, I get a headache. I drift off.



I remember being nine and climbing a tree, as high as I could. Not once did I look down. I just kept climbing and climbing, up and up. I stood on the highest branch. As I looked out, I could see the red roofs of houses, and aeroplanes, and clouds, and the horizon. It made me feel so small. Then I looked directly below, and felt even smaller. If ever I knew how to get down, it had escaped me now. I sat in that tree for a whole afternoon, with my Aunt underneath, yelling. I sat in the sun, my skin burned. When I finally decided to come down, I slipped and landed on my arm. I had to get a cast. The hospital room smelled o



</question>

<original file>13752.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk87475.txt</current file name>




<category>



Arts & Humanities



Books & Authors



</category>



<question from>



Stacey
Member since: 22 October 2008
Total points: 332 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Would any good writers / editors care to critique three paragraphs?



I'm currently writing the first draft of my first novel, and I want everything to be prefect. If you have any input, be honest and please don't sugar coat anything. If it's terrible, feel free to say so, but at the same time please offer any advice.



One more note: These are the first paragraphs of the book. Do they make you want to continue reading?



- - -



Imagine this:
You are growing up with many close friends who invite you to the movie theatre every time a good flick comes to the big screen. You are blessed with a father to admire, a mother to take care of you, and a younger sister to protect. You are getting good grades in school, and have recently begun to explore your future – Colleges, careers, the whole package. Albeit, life is far from perfect, you are still able to wake up each morning with a smile on your face and momentum in your heart – Momentum to live every day to the fullest.



Now imagine this:
Instead of visiting the movie theatre with your friends, you are sitting on a bed, vomiting into a basin because your stomach cannot handle the high doses of chemotherapy.



Your father worries about you all day and all night, your mother cries quietly as she drifts off into a troubled slumber, and your sister watches you from across the room, wondering if you will be with her as she grows up. You wake up each morning feeling as tired as you felt the night before, and every day you fight against a vicious disease that has claimed many, many lives, and now threatens your own.



The disease is childhood cancer.
Every school day, forty-six children are diagnosed with cancer. One in three hundred children will be diagnosed before their twentieth birthday. Cancer is the number one killer of children in the United States and is more deadly than Cystic Fibrosis, Muscular Dystrophy, Asthma, and AIDS combined.



Every child diagnosed with cancer comes from a different background; they all have unique personalities with distinct goals and aspirations for their lives. Moreover, each child has a different story. This is the story of one of those children.



</question>



<answer from>



LJ K
Member since: 28 May 2007
Total points: 48085 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Books & Authors



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I think this is good.
I would only change one thing, which I'll mention since you ask.
Try "Although life is far from perfect, you are still able..."
Suggesting that because in an otherwise smooth read, the use of 'Albeit' slows the reader as the only word there that just doesn't fit with the rest.



I would be happy to read the story of this child.
I think cancer is a subject that many people have dealt with (or may in the future) even 'simply watching' family/friends battle this disease in its many forms, as I have.



Good going.
One word of caution: As you wrote in your prologue here, 'life is far from perfect,' and so is most writing, even good writing.



Very little of anything I know about is 'perfect,' so suggest you try not to set that high a goal for yourself per: your lead-in asking for critiques.



Oops. Another word of caution: if you plan to try for publication (not vanity press but real publication) suggest you post no more online.



It is not unheard of for scouts, agents, publishers to take a look at what is online, and if they see a piece cross their desk they recall seeing online, free, for millions to read already... there will be no sale.



ADD: The terminology around oncology is rather mysterious to most of us, but the chemo I saw being given was by I.V.



It looked like a 'dose' to me; but I have no idea what it's name is. Chemo is usually given during a set time, though for some a return for more occurs. Ah, you prob'ly know what you need to know on that. If not, you know how to do research.



No caps after a dash is correct and a good call.



Disease names in caps, I'd say, depends on why/when/who and et cetera. Like I said, very little is perfect and one of the beauties of writing is that, barring grammar error, a writer (even with grammar error in some cases) does as thought best and as long as the story supports 'different' usage, differences can work.



Thinking now of Vonnegut's reporting on the bombing of Dresden, which he was indeed witness to and gives himself one line about in Slaughterhouse-Five ("Oz") which is not only factual but a sci-fi time-travel story as well.



2nd ADD: Your use of 'momentum' in the heart is fine as it is explained immediately. It's a word you're using to describe a 'feeling,' which is a sensation many people allocate to the heart.



And I think every child DOES come from a different background, as even those in the same family see the dynamics around them differently. If you want to clarify that, it's done easily enough by using a substitute for 'background,' but not really so necessary here.
This IS your first draft, after all.



Source(s):



Eng. Lit. degree, post-grad writing courses; made living primarily as journalist but also published short fiction, had one play produced (surprise), been an editor and tutor; now retired but still writing, only at a much slower pace.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Wow, thank you so much for the very well written advice. :)



Yes, the correct term is, "dose" because it sums up how much they give you.



And the reason I'm striving for a perfect book is because I know it won't be. Reach for the moon so that when you miss you'll still land on a star. :)



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Tiger Lily
Member since: 10 May 2008
Total points: 1140 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



That's pretty good.  I love the sense of drama at the end of the last paragraph.
I would probably read this story.



</answer>



<answer from>



Anne N
Member since: 03 March 2008
Total points: 473 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Up until the last sentence it sounds like one of those PSAs you'd hear on tv asking for donations.



</answer>



<answer from>



tonalc2
Member since: 20 June 2008
Total points: 23894 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



San Francisco



Elections



</answer from>



<answer>



I like the contrasting lives and then the description.  It's an interesting introduction to a story.



There is some clunky sentence construction, grammar and word usage.  Some things that stood out for me:



A heart cannot have "momentum."  "Albeit" is a very formal word to use for a casual narrative (and doesn't need a comma).  Don't capitalize a word after a dash.



You don't get a "dose" of chemotherapy; it's either a dose of medicine or a round of chemotherapy.  Instead of "many, many" lives, give a number--hundreds, thousands.



Don't capitalize the names of diseases (except AIDS, but that's because it's an acronym).



It's a very broad brush to say that "every" child comes from a different background; I'm sure there are many with the same types of backgrounds.



As you can tell, I'm kind of a nitpicker.



</answer>

What would you say is the theme for the book the secret life of bees?

<answer from>



judy-oz

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Set in South Carolina in 1964, The Secret Life of Bees tells the story of Lily Owens, whose life has been shaped around the blurred memory of the afternoon her mother was killed. When Lily's fierce-hearted "stand-in mother," Rosaleen, insults three of the town's fiercest racists, Lily decides they should both escape to Tiburon, South Carolina - a town that holds the secret to her mother's past. There they are taken in by an eccentric trio of black beekeeping sisters who introduce Lily to a mesmerizing world of bees, honey, and the Black Madonna who presides over their household. This is a remarkable story about divine female power and the transforming power of love - a story that women will share and pass on to their daughters for years to come.

<question from>



Maddie M
Member since: 21 July 2008
Total points: 73 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Hills Like White Elephants?



I have to come up with a thesis for "Hills Like White Elephants" by Ernest Hemingway. Does anyone have ideas? I can not come up with one.



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



I don't normally give out homework help, but  I am assuming that you read this, as it isn't very long, and not much happens in the story.



I read this story in college It was a long time ago, but I HATED this story, so I remember some of it.
Then I had to write the same essay.



All I remember is that Hemmingway and his girlfriend are standing around in a Spanish Train station waiting to get on a train somewhere so the girlfriend can go have an abortion, and it is hot, and nothing much happens.



The story was against everything I believed...and to be honest I don't remember anything happening in the story. All I remember was miserable people  just sitting in the miserable hot train station and everyone was miserable. They had spiritually dead lives, and they were selfish, atheist, spiritually dead and morally dead people, and I just really disliked them. I disliked the story, the setting, everything.



So that is what I wrote. I wrote that I hated it. My exact words were "What this story really needs is for an F-105 to pop up from behind those hills and drop a load of napalm on the train station, incinerating the carachters, the setting and everything, and perhaps then Mr. Hemmingway can write something that is worthy of his tallents and worth the readers time."



You don't normally take on Hemmingway, regarded by most teachers as the greatest American Author ever, but my teacher was open minded and honest and let me get away with it. Your teacher may or may not be as open minded.



(Personally I think Margaret Mitchell wrote "the great american novel", judged by it's sales figures and enduring popularity Gone with the Wind beats out the more "literary" books.)



So if you hated it, like I did,  just say you hated it. Make sure you can give good reasons for why you hated it though.



And be aware you are taking a bit of risk when you do that



</answer>

<question from>



Chef Ross Eats Books

<question>



What would it feel like to ride a horse AFTER you village has just tortured u 4 a crime u didn't comit?



Ok, so I'm writing a scene in which a innocent teenaged girl is wrongfully accused of murdering a child. Her village goes on a witch hunt for her and the main accuser tries to torture her into a confession. We don't get a graphic description of the torture, except when the girl tells us, that she pissed herself from the pain (is that really possible?)



We do get to see the accuser shave her head (her does so to humuliate her) and are told that he checks to be sure blood is the only thing left on her scalp.



Anyhow, just as they are about to hang her, she is rescued last minute by her childhood, friend who is on horseback.



The two escape the village and are riding across the desert.



While they are riding, she discovers that her childhood friend is a werewolf and starting to change.



</question>



<additional details>



EDIT: right now i have the protagonist riding in front of her friend on the horse and they're making very small talk with no mention of what happened in the village. Then, when they stop riding, the friend is telling the protagonist that he's going to have to leave her somewhere else because he is a werewolf and if they are still together at sunrise he'll hunt her



</additional details>



<answer from>



A girl who smiles
Member since: 11 April 2008
Total points: 430 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



oooo I like it!



sounds really great!

<answer from>



Georgie T
Member since: 19 July 2008
Total points: 376 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



When writing one should write about what one knows.  Urinating from pain or laughter is not uncommon-check a medical book.



Gee????  hummm I don't know -  Small talk after just escaping from people who were torturing me and being covered in blood from that ?????NA...I wouldn't be making small talk, I would be barely breathing.



WEREWOLF at SUNRISE??? Never saw any of the Lon Cheney Movies did you...Werewolf's are suppose to transition at the rise of the full moon and by sunrise are again human.



Head shaving usually doesn't leave residuals of blood unless more than hair is being removed..It was use usually used to show that someone was a betrayer of the group and not just as a general method of humiliation.  Besides you have them in a DESERT..the village would have stoned her.



What time period is this you didn't indicate so I had to guess.



Source(s):



40 + years writing short stories, some of which have been published.



</answer>

<question from>

<question>



Help  for  my book (:?



i need some advice on the book im writing.
its the first book ive written, but i know theres going to be a sequal
its not going to be published or anything, its just a bit of fun.
so basically there's this 17 year old girl who's going out with this older guy, whos 20, and he's a famous actor.
but he cheats on her.
i've got three endings for the book and i dont know how to end it, what do you think?
1- they break up and go their seperate ways
2- they get back together
3- they break up but she has to find him to tell him shes pregnant?



thanks x



</question>

<question from>



ChelseaC...
Member since: 31 May 2008
Total points: 3497 (Level 4)



</question from>



<question>



Do you get emotional when you read a book?



I do.
I mean I start crying and throwing books.
Lol.
My mum thinks there is something wrong with me.
Hehe.



</question>



<answer from>



patticha...
Member since: 20 April 2008
Total points: 16830 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Emotional? I get nearly hysterical sometimes!



I lost it while reading "The Life Of Pi." I cried all the way through "The Art of Racing in the Rain" and STILL can't even talk about that book without tearing up. "Bel Canto" nearly put me off the edge.



I've read "The Weekend" by Peter Cameron a dozen times and cry everytime.



LOL



I too have thrown a book across the room. I'll get so worn out emotionally, I have to put it aside for a couple of days!



There is nothing wrong with you. You get into the words, you get into the story, you FEEL it. The authors love you for it.



Source(s):



Writer/Editor



</answer>



<asker's comment>



I guess my mum just doesn't understand.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Emma
Member since: 18 September 2008
Total points: 282 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yeah I totally get that... sometimes I'll get so into it that I'll be sitting there reading with the biggest smile on my face cause something happy or funny just happened and I don't realize it until someone looks at me weird lol my best friend says I'm a freak...pshaw... I'm also big on getting mad at a character or the author and I'll start like yelling at the book or I'll throw it across the room if something happens that I don't like. It's funny cause I'll do it in public and people look at me weird cause I'm freaking out at a book :)



</answer>

Total points: 5960 (Level 5)

<answer>



I do. I get so involved with the characters! My friends try to stay away when I read, as I get angry, sad, happy and so on. One time I was reading Noughts and Crosses (by Malorie Blackman) at the bus stop. At the end its really, really sad. I burst into tears. A lovely old lady came over and said, "are you alright, dear?" I replied, weeping, "no! Callum's dead!" And the old lady tried to comfort me, thinking I'd lost someone who wasn't fictional. Oh, the shame! lol.



jamie xx

If a book makes me emotional, chances are it's a good book.

<question>



Tell Me Books I Should Read?



Don't Like - Harry Potter,Lord of the Rings,Romance,Fantasy or Sci Fi



I Like - Black Comedy, Fiction, basically books someone with a sense of humor/personality similar to a male Daria or Jane (from daria) or Janeane Garofalo would like



I am a 23 year old Male so please something close to age appropriate and gender appropriate.



I have a dry and sarcastic sense of humor.I also want books on the more unconventional side, because I get bored with the same old thing all the time.I also want something that is a bit of an easy read because I have a short attention span but not too easy or I'd get bored with it.However I also want something that isn't too predictable because I don't like things I can see the ending a mile away.



Just finished Reading - Ella Minnow Pea, The Mezzanine



</question>



<answer from>



Juliana
Member since: 11 March 2008
Total points: 9870 (Level 5)

<answer>

He's written quite a few books that use the same character. They are smart and quirky, entertaining, very laugh out loud. Spy type stuff but all have gripping storylines. Look up Wild Fire on amazon. <answer from>



patticha...
Member since: 20 April 2008
Total points: 16830 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



I loved "Ella Minnow Pea." Clever.



It's not fiction, but I'm wondering if you would like "Rammer Jammer Yellow Hammer." It's about an Alabama football fan who followed the team around for a year in an old RV. It's hysterical. I'm not a huge football fan and not a fan of Alabama in particular, but this book is too much. I laughed til I was nearly sick. I'd recommend it for just about anyone. It's by Warren St. John, who writes for the NYT.



You might enjoy any of the mysteries by Tim Dorsey. He's a bit like Elmore Leonard, twisted, dark, hysterically funny. Great stories, all set in Florida, eccentric characters. Wonderful. Some of the titles are Triggerfish Twist, Orange Crush, Torpedo Juice. Check him out at http://www.timdorsey.com/home.html



If you haven't read Elmore Leonard, you might enjoy him. "Get Shorty" was one of his books made into a movie. Great characters, crazy story lines, fun to read.



Hope this helps!



</answer>

<question from>



Farihah Le Fume
Member since: 08 February 2008
Total points: 885 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



What are some Jane Austen grammar words or phrases?



well they don't really belong to her but she had a intelligent sense of vocabulary.



some grammar words i'm aware of: propriety, deficient, composure etc.



</question>



<answer from>



ck1
Member since: 13 August 2007
Total points: 48048 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Books & Authors



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



It really depends on what you would consider grammar words. Age, grade and reading level would change which would be considered vocabulary words.



From chapter 2:
hypocritical
discretion
emphatic
acquaintance
nonsense
astonishment
tumult



Some other words you may consider:
imprudent
exigence
unintelligible
compassionate
consolatory
obstinacy
comparative
acquiescence
importune
impertinence
abominably
palliation
actuated
laudable
vindication
assiduously
condescension
obsequious
sufficiently



These are just some which may qualify. You can search through the story for others here: http://www.online-literature.com/austen/...



I hope this helps.



Note: These are merely from Pride and Prejudice. The site I gave you has all six of her major novels, and you can search for words and phrases in each.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



some vocab words are similiar to the ones in sense & sensibility.



thanks, just what i needed ;)



</asker's comment>

Arts & Humanities

</category>



<question from>



Stacey
Member since: 22 October 2008
Total points: 332 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Is writing a blog about a book a bad idea?



Is it true that a publisher will not work with a book that has been seen on the internet?



The reason I ask is because I am writing my first novel, and I had an idea that if people saw very (and I mean very) short sneak peeks of the book that got them interested, then they would be more likely to buy it and refer it to friends a relatives once it is on the shelf. But tonight I read something from a fellow Yahoo! Answers user that made me think otherwise.



I was planning on starting a blog, just a general blog to write in about my life and strange events of random days like plenty of teenagers do. But in the midst of that blog, I was planning on throwing in some entries about the novel I am writing, entries to introduce the two main characters and how I relate to their personalities and such, and giving my friends / blog readers updates on how the writing process is going. Maybe even throwing in a sentence or two to get people interested. If I did this, would my chances of being published in the future be altered at all?



Like I said before, I would think that a publisher would be happier to see that people are already interested in the book.



</question>



<answer from>



Jessica P
Member since: 27 August 2008
Total points: 1599 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I wouldn't post anything online purely due to plagiarism concerns. Some of the people who like your idea, won't hesitate in stealing it. That being said I do like the idea of getting hype for the book through a blog.
One thing you could do would be to write it first, posting things like 'I worked on the novel today, will post some soon' to gain hype for the people who read your blog, but don't put any on until it's finished and you've shown it to a publisher or had it copyrighted. That way people know you're writing a novel and want to read it, but can't actually steal it. The other thing you could do would be to post small bits of it online like the title, character bios, or small one liners that show off your writing without giving anything away.
Good luck, I'd love to read the blog!



</answer>



<asker's comment>



That's exactly what I had in mind! :) Just character biographies, and maybe just a single sentence, one that no one could really do anything with even if they stole it. Thanks!



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Lynn's Angel Savious
Member since: 23 March 2006
Total points: 11481 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



It's not wise to post something in a place like The Internet. Most likely it can be copied off of you. If you like to give some sneak peeks, how about gathering around your friends and family to show some insights in your novel?



</answer>



<answer from>



Idiot kid
Member since: 27 October 2008
Total points: 364 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Do NOT put something online that are planning to publish. You can discuss the book, but I would highly recommend not putting actual text on the internet.



</answer>



<answer from>



Carnage
Member since: 31 October 2008
Total points: 123 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



DO NOT PUT ANYTHING YOU PLAN TO PUBLISH ONLINE!  It is simply asking to be stolen and plagarized.



</answer>

<question from>



pandicul...
Member since: 06 May 2008
Total points: 84 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Can a good writer of fiction be self taught?



Not taking any courses.  Just writing and writing and writing, and finally it starts to be good writing?  Can you name any that claim to be self taught?  There's lots of musicians who say they are self taught.



</question>



<answer from>



mrquesti...
Member since: 26 April 2006
Total points: 9268 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes, of course you can be self taught. Jack London is one of the most famous examples, but there are many like him. They didn't go to a school of writers, but they read tons of good books before they started writing.



</answer>



<answer from>



jess
Member since: 09 October 2008
Total points: 232 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I'm pretty sure people like Steinbeck and Hemingway were never taught anything but they took things from places they'd been and people they'd met, experiences they'd had to build their stories, some of them were half non-fiction. There are some things that just can't be taught, some people just have a talent and know how to use it.



</answer>



<answer from>



Maddog Salamander
Member since: 14 August 2006
Total points: 4329 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Stephen King comes to mind.  Most writers do a lot of writing before stepping into a writing class.  From my experience, writing classes give a person the opportunity to write, and some exercises to facilitate those opportunities.



Terry Goodkind, also, is a product just sitting down and writing until something good came out.



</answer>



<answer from>



Mavisthe...
Member since: 02 August 2008
Total points: 18339 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Homework Help



Books & Authors



Higher Education (University +)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes, but you have to have a sense of what's good and why. The way to get that is from reading both good and bad writing.



However, even if you don't take classes, it can really help to read some books and articles on the craft of writing. The ones put out by Writer's Digest are very good. Several authors have also written books with their insights into the writing process - it can be quite helpful to read different views on it.



</answer>



<answer from>



papyrus
Member since: 10 October 2008
Total points: 657 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I believe JK Rowling is self taught.  Just read a lot, write a lot, and let your imagination loose :)



</answer>

<question>



Will someone please read my (very) short story trilogy and give an honest review?



I have written a (very) short story trilogy (1,750 words each) and would really appreciate it if someone would read it and give an honest review.



Part I: http://www.writing.com/main/view_item/it...
Part II: http://www.writing.com/main/view_item/it...
Part III: http://www.writing.com/main/view_item/it...



(I know the first part isn't that amazing, but it does get better towards the end of the series)



Thank you very much!!
(PS: It would be nice if you could give it a mark out of, let's say, 10)



</question>



<additional details>



The story is called Back.



'What if you could go back in time to prevent a loved one's death?'



</additional details>



<answer from>



Kabillio...
Member since: 14 June 2008
Total points: 637 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I swear i reviewed the first one for you? I think i said ur ending style was brilliant. Well once again u proved me right. In part II i liked ur ending. But, in part III i thought u should've stopped with A time paradox and forgotten about the last paragraph. It would've been a very good ending.



The story was brilliant, i thought it was a good style u worked on. Good on you. Have a star.



Like you said the last two of the trilogy was a better piece of work to the first one (however i am not hating on your first part; it was actually very good) but I really liked the ending. I would rate this trilogy as an 8 or 9 out of ten. Actually a definite 9 because it was very well tied in. I really liked the storyline by the way and i liked the fact that Omina was rather ominous (the names was a play on words i expect).



It was very different. U didnt keep the writing extremely detailed nor did you write heaps of description and many would have to hate it for other people to love it but, like many others, u had the ability to keep the reader "reading" without effort. Does that make sense or am i confusing?



You did well,



Kabillionaire



Sorry if my critisism is not welcome :(



Source(s):



My Brain



</answer>



<answer from>



pointyea...
Member since: 24 February 2007
Total points: 2544 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Nice! It's very interesting and different. I'd give it an 8.



Source(s):



A fellow writer and aspiring author



</answer>



<answer from>



Book C
Member since: 30 October 2008
Total points: 100 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



The premise and much of the wording is good. A 7.5 out of 10



I would suggest that the start is too abrupt as the character development is too slow, to foster reader interest and familiarity with the main character. It takes all of part one for this to develop. Having the story in 3 parts, waiting for a dial up download, doesn't serve to sustain interest. I found part 2 riveting as it involved me with the character. I became disinterested and lost, with the added characters in part 3 and likely missed the intended climax.



For a short story it is imperative to limit characters, so that you can adequately develop those that you have and those that are important to the plot development, while maintaining an interest in the flow of the story.



</answer>

Darlene G
Member since: 18 February 2008

</question from>



<question>



SARAH PALIN AND THE POLAR BEARS?



If you research Palin and the Polar Bears, you will find that she is opposed to them being added to the Endangered Species List due to ice melting because of Global Warming. She doesn't want them added because it will inhibit drilling.  SO - why is she constantly seen on the campaign trail wearing a Polar Bear pin on her jackets? What is she trying to say? I don't want them protected but I like them?



</question>



<answer from>



Bibigirl
Member since: 13 August 2008
Total points: 4406 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



I'm thinking it's because the polar bears aren't endangered and to stop hunting them would allow their population to grow out of control causing even more man & polar bear clashes. They are coming into towns and villages and destroying property as it is, this is with their populations in check.



</answer>



<answer from>



Samwise
Member since: 01 November 2007
Total points: 9773 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Mathematics



</answer from>



<answer>



The person who focused on hunting has missed the point: the bears aren't clashing with humans because they aren't hunted enough; they are clashing with humans because they are spending time along shorelines, hunting for scarce food (and therefore attracted to garbage dumps and food stores) instead of out on the ice hunting seals.



I think the polar bear will continue be used as a symbol of Alaskans' northern attachments even if the bears are extinct, and I think Sarah Palin wears the pin because it's an Alaskan symbol.



</answer>



<answer from>



Atherfoo...
Member since: 12 April 2007
Total points: 593 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



That's not really Sarah Palin. It's actually Tina Fey.



</answer>

<answer>



I would definitely recommend Jonathan Stroud's Bartimeaus triology. The first book is the Amulet of Samarkand. It's all about a young boy who is apprenticed to a magician and decides that he hates his master and wants to prove he is really good so summons a djinn to steal a powerful artefact from a very powerful magician. As one might expect things don't seem to go his way and there are various plots to overthrow the magicians of a world not dissimilar to Victorian London by non-magicians etc etc. Its a little darker than Harry Potter but I couldn't put them down.



If you want a better synopsis of the first book visit
http://www.amazon.co.uk/exec/obidos/ASIN...



Source(s):



I've read the book



</answer>



<answer from>



OliveSor...
Member since: 10 August 2006
Total points: 116 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Irish writer Eoin Colfer books are just too good for kids. (His first name is pronounced "Owen").  His books are BETTER than Harry Potter.



If you love Harry Potter (and I do), then you'll love the Artemis Fowl series.  The audio book version is read by the same actor, Nathaniel Parker, who plays Detective Inspector Thomas Lynley on PBS.  Here they are in published order:



Artemis Fowl (2001)



Artemis Fowl: The Arctic Incident (2002)



Artemis Fowl: The Eternity Code (2003)



Artemis Fowl: The Opal Deception (2005)



Artemis Fowl: The Lost Colony (2006)



Artemis Fowl: The Time Paradox (2008)



Artemis Fowl is a billionaire teenage criminal mastermind who discovers the hidden fairy world.  I love the kid and his body guard, Butler.  I also read Colfer's Half Moon Investigations and loved it too.



You might also like the classic series by C.S. Lewis called the Chronicles of Narnia.  I don't recommend that you read them in published order but in order of action:



The Magician's Nephew



The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe



The Horse and His Boy



Prince Caspian



The Voyage of the Dawn Treader



The Silver Chair



The Last Battle



</answer>



<answer from>



Riflebun...
Member since: 21 July 2008
Total points: 565 (Level 2)



</answer from>

The Artemis Fowl series or try Arthur Ransome's Swallow and Amazon books, Of couse these aren't anything like Harry Potter but stretch your mind kiddo.



</answer>

<question>



This is one of the first poems i ever wrote. what do you think?



i dont want to know if its to long to read i just want to know what you think



Last night
Before I left you
I was in a hurry



Last night
Before I left you
I should have said goodbye



Last night
Before I left you
I didn’t even say goodnight



Last night
Before I left you
Did I tell you
How much I love you



Last night
In the darkness
I didn’t know
How much id miss you



Maybe id know
How much id miss you
I should have said goodbye



I didn’t know
What I was loosing



Last night
Before I left you
I was in a hurry
A hurry to learn
What you really meant to me



Last night
In the darkness
I left while u were still asleep



I didn’t tell you
I didn’t realise
How much I love you



Last night
Before I left you
I was in a hurry



Last night
Before I left you
I should have said goodbye



Last night
Before I left you
I didn’t even say goodnight



Last night
Before I left you
I didn’t tell you
How much I loved you



I know what I shouldve said
Im not gonna say goodbye



</question>

<original file>5428.html</original file>

<category>



Arts & Humanities



Books & Authors



</category>



<question from>



Shay
Member since: 23 September 2007
Total points: 134 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Representation from Picture of Dorian Gray?



i really need help and what i mean by representation is like when the lady killed herself a bottle of poison would represent that and when he killed Basil with a putty knife would represent that..



</question>



<answer from>



ck1
Member since: 13 August 2007
Total points: 48037 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Books & Authors



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



In  chapter 14, Alan Campbell gets rid of the body for Dorian and this is part of what is said: "a large mahogany chest of chemicals, with a long coil of steel and platinum wire and two rather curiously shaped iron clamps." You could have a steel coil and/or a piece of wire and/or a picture of a mahogany chest and/or a clamp to represent this deed.



You could have an easel or at least a paint brush to represent the portrait, itself.



You could have a picture of opium or an opium den to represent what happened to Dorian, a cigarette to represent the rather indolent Henry (or a cane), a picture of the statue of Adonis to represent Dorian and his beauty. You could also have a French novel to represent the book which influences Dorian in such a bad way (Wikipedia suggests it might have been something like Joris-Karl Huysmans's À rebours).



I'm sure there is much more, but I hope this helps a bit.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



THANK Y0U S00 MUCH THiS WAS A BiG H3LP!



</asker's comment>

<question>



I need your help with reading suggestions?



I want to read some good classics.  I am not just talking War and Peace or stuff like that.  But maybe some old books rich in vocabulary and are somewhat sophisticated.  Anyone have any good suggestions?  If you can, please provide name of book, author and a short description.  Thanks for your help!

<asker's comment>



there were really really good answers that are much appreciated!  but i like this one best because of the descriptions!  thanks for taking the time!



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



hellinor...
Member since: 11 January 2007
Total points: 22530 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



If you want a good "modern" classic, try "All the King's Men" by Robert Penn Warren. It won the Pulitzer prize. It's about a politician (Willie Stark) and his right hand man (Jack Burden) and how they run his campaign to run for Governor. It's full of lies, corruption and deceit.



The characters are fatally flawed, but still possess redeeming qualities.



I read it for the first time as a senior in high school and I have read it every year since then.



::EDIT:: I'd highly recommend "Crime and Punishment" by Dovstyesky. (sp) That's a good read as well. It is about a man who commits a crime and how he deals with his conscience afterward. Of course it has layers of symbolism, so that's fun to look out for too.



</answer>



<answer from>



Kells
Member since: 24 January 2008
Total points: 1628 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Les Miserable by Victor Hugo-
It's basically 3 stories that are connected. It's pretty much about love and redemption. It's a really good story, but rather long.
A Tree Grows in Brooklyn by Betty Smith
It's a coming of age story about a poor girl in Brooklyn.  Easy to read but still one of my favorites.
Joy Luck Club by Amy Tan
It's about 4 women and their lives and the lessons they learned.



Oh, and I really enjoyed Pride and Prejudice and Sense and Sensibility, both by Jane Austen and both good old fashioned love stories.



</answer>

<question>



Are there any good sites that offer help for fictional writing?



well I write all the time, but I've never actually had any guidance or advice on how to make my work better, so if anyone knows any sites that aren't boring that you think may help me please let me know



thanks



</question>



<answer from>



genura_u...
Member since: 07 February 2008
Total points: 630 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I read a book for my english class during the spring semester of '08 called "On Writing Well" by William Zinsser.  I had purchased the 30th Anniversary edition, and while the book is on writing non-fiction, there are many excellent rules of thumb to use for fiction as well.  You might also want to check out his other books over at Amazon.com...



</answer>

<question from>

<question>



What r the values,setting,style,character… P.O.V. of the story of my life by helen keller?

<answer from>



genura_u...
Member since: 07 February 2008
Total points: 630 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Well, it is the auto-biography of Helen Keller, who became both blind and deaf after a childhood illness.  However, I feel you need to read the book yourself to understand the rest.

the_laye...

<original file>6462.html</original file>

<category>



Arts & Humanities



Books & Authors



</category>



<question from>



Rizel B
Member since: 17 August 2008
Total points: 119 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Publishing a story online?



In class, we're looking for websites where we can post or publish the sci-fi and fantasy stories we wrote...do you have any websites or any idea of where we could?



And I think it has to be free--just saying cause I know that sum websites you might hav to pay money to publish a story and I dont think they would pay..



</question>



<answer from>



umbravul...
Member since: 24 May 2008
Total points: 821 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



If you're not being too picky about where the stories could be posted, there's always places like fictionpress.net, elfwood.com or deviantart. Since anything that is made publicly available (say, posted on a net-site that anyone can view) is counted as publishing (not professionally speaking, but from a legal standpoint), using a like that could work for this purpose.



All three are free, you just create an account and post your story according to their guidelines.



If however, you are looking for more professional sort of publishing, the only route I can think of would be to submit the stories webzines. This process however can take months and chances of being accepted are quite small.



Hope that helps



</answer>



<asker's comment>



thanks~



</asker's comment>
