<question>



The Heir of Slytherin?



Did J.K.R ever tells us who is the Heir of Slytherin? I keep getting confused if it was Ginny or Harry.



</question>



<answer from>



ZOOMKAI
Member since: 28 October 2008
Total points: 102 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



THE HEIR OF SLYTHERIN WAS TOM MARVOLO RIDDLE, AKA VOLDEMORT.



Source(s):



HARRY POTTER AND THE CHAMBER OF SECRETS.



</answer>



<answer from>



Lauren A
Member since: 03 October 2007
Total points: 1140 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Voldemort is the heir of Slytherin. Everyone THOUGHT it was Harry, and Voldemort was just using Ginny through the diary to reopen the chamber. The heir had to speak Parseltongue to open the chamber.



</answer>



<answer from>



The Almighty Moonytoes
Member since: 16 October 2008
Total points: 152 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



It was neither. Voldemort was the Heir of Slytherin all along. That's who Tom Riddle was. His mother was a Gaunt who were descendants of Salazar Slytherin. Ginny was possessed by Riddle when he is still in the diary, and so through her he opens the chamber. However Ginny is never the actual Heir of Slytherin. Harry can open the chamber because he is a parselmouth, meaning he can speak the language of snakes, like Voldemort and Salazar Slytherin, but he is not the heir. The line of Slytherin ended with Voldemort.



Source(s):



Years and Years of reading the books.



</answer>

Member since: 09 May 2008

<question from>



guevarra...
Member since: 31 October 2008
Total points: 95 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What is the theme of "the black cat" by edgar allan poe?



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



Horror, I guess. What happens is he murders his wife because she tried to stop him from administering his idea of justice to his black cat. He builds a wall and hides her body behind it. The police come by to investigate, but find nothing. And the end of the visit, they declare him innocent. He agrees, saying nothing is hidden. To emphasize his point, he taps the wall behind which his wife's body is hidden. It collapses and his wife's grossly disfigured body rises up with the black cat on her head.
Angel_U



PS Poe was a greatly talented guy, but he had a problem with morbidness and depression.



</answer>

<question>



How can i start my story? ?



Ok, I have come up with the first half of my plot and I have all the characters. However, I don't know how to start my story. So here's the plot. The main character breaks up with her boyfriends which is very simple. However, about a week later she gets a call from a hospital - her ex boyfriend was in a motorcycle accident. Later, when he wakes up he does not remember the break up (he had amnesia) and they start to fall in love again, making the same mistakes as they did the first time as well as different ones. I can't find a way to start my story, or to finish it! Can you help? How should I start - and what would you find an effective finish?



thanks in advance
jamie xx



</question>



<answer from>



ZOOMKAI
Member since: 28 October 2008
Total points: 102 (Level 1)

BEST WAY TO END- 'HAPPILY EVER AFTER'



</answer>

<answer from>



macadam_...
Member since: 02 March 2008
Total points: 606 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Just start writing.  Start anywhere, just get the story down on paper.  Lots of times you don't know where the story should start until you get to the end.  By the end, you will have an idea of theme and by having the end down, you can now plan for it at the beginning.  You can work for months on that first chapter, only to find the story should start at chapter 3.



</answer>



<answer from>



onetime
Member since: 10 July 2008
Total points: 875 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Maybe start with how bad their relationship was.  This way it's not only the break-up he forgets, but also that they were not very happy/fought a lot.



For the end: what about a twist! (the plot needs one)  Maybe she finds out he didn't have amnesia all along!  He just pretended because he didn't want to lose her.  That would cause for some good conflict and make for a good climax.  And then, of course, the inevitable and-they-lived-happily-ever-after kiss...



</answer>

<question>



Help i need a title for my book.?



here is the story so far.



Chapter 1



Normal, what is normal. Living happy ever after. Yeah right there is no such thing as happy ever after only the real world. And the real world sucks. In the real world there is no where you can hide. You have to stick it out , no matter how bad it is. But to tell you to tell you the truth there is people who have it worse then us. But when your going through something extremely bad , you think that there is no one in the world who understands your pain. But there is always someone who will understand you ,to tell you the truth they are probably going through the same thing as you. When your going trough a bad patch there is always someone to talk to, don’t think of the worse way out. And don’t be afraid that you think you are being a snitch , because you are only doing what is  best for you.



I have tried everything , but nothing works , I just want o get away from this torture. But there is no way out I have tried everything, tried telling , tried taking my life did any of those things work? NO! It just made it worse ….there is nobody in the world that can feel what I am going through. First I though home was the answer , but home was just as worse. There is no point in living ..what is the point of living if your unhappy and your life is in shambles. Why does everything happen to me ….well I know the answer ..because I am bad luck …I am the reason that my parent fight. I am the reason for everything. Why did god even make me … I am just  bad luck to everyone. I have no money. .no friends …no where to turn…no one there to catch me if I fall. People always tell me that life is full of choices… Life is always hard. Well you got that right. Life is always hard, miserable, gloomy and dark.  Life is full of horrible surprises for me. Never nice surprises. My mum says its because I am  an EVIL GIRL. And bad things happen to evil girls. But what I don’t understand  is that she does evil things , but I get punished for it. But why wont mum understand that life is full of consequences and that if she makes a mistake she should not punish me. Its not fair.

<question from>



Twilight Lover &lt;3
Member since: 26 October 2008
Total points: 139 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



I'm writing a fantasy novel, please help!?



I've got a really, really good idea for a fantasy novel. I will start writing soon. Please can anyone give me some ideas and tips how to write fantasy novels? Please!
thank you!



</question>



<answer from>



Paul&Fra...
Member since: 11 December 2006
Total points: 5949 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



writing.com is a very good site for idea's, read other young writers, chat rooms and such.. It's free as well.



</answer>



<answer from>



AKMAL
Member since: 30 March 2006
Total points: 2207 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



http://www.43things.com/things/view/1079...



</answer>



<answer from>



Hofferne...
Member since: 06 July 2006
Total points: 1306 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Books & Authors



</answer from>



<answer>



Thanks to the popularity of the HP books, a lot aspiring authors are writing fantasy books (including me). Getting a debut novel published can be very hard especially when the already established fantasy authors (ie. David Clement-Davies, Cornelia Funke, Christopher Paolini, JK Rowling etc...) already appeal to so many people.



Firstly,  you have to know WHAT kind of fantasy book you are writing. The fantasy genre has been divided into a number of categories such as:



Urban Fantasy - which are stories taking place on THIS world, rather than an imaginary land. Examples include The Phoenix and the Carpet by E Nesbit



Epic fantasy - envolves a completely new fantasy setting with different "races" and a completely different culture. Epic fantasies also involve a battle between good and evil or a heroic quest. Examples include The Hobbit and Lord of the Rings by JRR Tolkien, Harry Potter by JK Rowling and Eragon by Christopher Paolini.



Historical fantasy - stories that are set in the past with some elements of fantasy such as Chronicles of Ancient Darkness by Michelle Paver.



Mythological fantasy - Stories directly inspired by myth, folklore, and fairy tales such The Chronicles of Narnia by CS Lewis.



Humorous or "children's" fantasy - light hearted fantasy stories mainly for young children such as The Magic Faraway Tree and The Wishing Chair both by Enid Blyton.



Science fiction - when elements of science extend to fantasy such as The Host by Stephenie Meyer and books by Ray Bradbury.



Horror fantasy - when fantasy books have themes of horror and are mainly written for adults such as Anne Rice's Vampire Chronicles



Romance fantasy - when fantasy books have a romance theme in them such as the Twiligth series by Stephenie Meyer and Elizabeth Kerner's Song in the Silence.



Out of all these, I guess epic fantasy is really tough to write. You have to invent your own imaginary land and your own mythology. I salute the authors JRR Tolkien and JK Rowling for coming up with books of such details.



When you have finished your novel, get a copy of Writers Market or How to Write Science Fiction and Fantasy by Orson Scott Card. And then get yourself an agent first.



Beleive in yourself and you will be successful.



Best of luck.



Source(s):



Here are some pages from where I referenced, you may want to have a look on them.



http://fmwriters.com/Visionback/issue13/...
http://www.writing-world.com/sf/index.sh...
http://www.writesf.com/
http://www.oneofus.co.uk/index.php/how_t...
http://fantasy.fictionfactor.com/



</answer>



<answer from>



Jamieeee sunshine
Member since: 30 September 2008
Total points: 243 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Hi!! I see that you like Twilight - so it's best not to write about vampires or werewolves, as it may be hard to not think of Stephenie Meyer's ideas, and the use them (not on purpose). How about... dragons? I know its kind of babyish, however you could make it better and aimed at teens, like Eragon. Or, something involving magic.



Here are 3 ideas of my own!



1) A girl/boy moves into a new house, and there are thousands of paintings on the wall, every time the character seems not to be looking they change. This is because the paintings aren't simply paintings, they are the story of someones life. The main character get sucked into these paintings... and in this alternative world, there are dragons, fairies, vampire and more. Maybe, she is the only human left in existence there?



2) A girl/boy have a mirror, which pulls them into a paralell world. Like the above idea, but a mirror instead.



3) Last but not least... your main character works at a company that is very well known and powerful. One day he/she is working late, and hears a heated conversation in another room. She hears the (wo)man angrily shout "fine! I'll do this myself! It'll be at the printer!" The character, curious, goes to the printers, and finds a sheet of paper with a black hole on. She can put her hand in it, and it gets through stuff. Maybe, she puts her hands in and something comes out... something mystical.



These are more a mix of sci-fi and fantasy, i guess. But, i hope i could help. enjoy your writing and good luck!!



jamie xx



</answer>

Arts & Humanities



Books & Authors



</category>



<question from>



Ethan
Member since: 15 September 2008
Total points: 4018 (Level 4)



</question from>



<question>



Are there any specific characteristics that are necessary in literature/plays for it to be considered tragedy?



For example, if a family member of the protagonist dies near the beginning of the play/narrative due to natural causes and the plot mostly focuses on the protagonist and the supporting characters reactions, suffering and grief in reaction to the death - and the narrative ends at an indecisive point with no direct resolution (but does have a climax/catharsis) - could it still be considered tragedy? Or modernist/post-modernist tragedy?



Or would it be a completely different genre altogether?



</question>



<answer from>



Kirby S
Member since: 18 August 2008
Total points: 212 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Well, it sure doesn't sound like farce.  If there is a catharsis, and the catharsis isn't comedic, then it most likely is tragic (how many categories are there?  It's not an action/ adventure story, not a horror story, not a children's story, not a love story...  Are you sure it's actually a story??  Because if you aren't sure it's a tragedy, then it is entirely possible that all you have is a "stream of events"-- which would be very post modern, but not tragic...  And it would not have a catharsis).  Check out Wikipedia on this matter.



Source(s):



http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Catastrophe...



</answer>



<answer from>



Aki F.
Member since: 19 March 2007
Total points: 8580 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Books & Authors



</answer from>



<answer>



For something to be a tragedy, a protagonist has to have been of a high status, and they fall....fall...fall...Beowulf was a tragedy/catharsis because he was of a high status but was killed. Romeo and Juliet was a tragedy because both characters were of a high status but died. I would say that Doomed Queen Anne was a tragedy because she was a queen but beheaded.



</answer>

<answer from>



Hofferne...
Member since: 06 July 2006
Total points: 1306 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Books & Authors



</answer from>



<answer>



For psycholofical thrillers try authors like Stephen King or Michael Crichton.



Other than that, authors like James Patterson, John Grisham, Jean Sasson, Khaled Hosseini, and Nicholas Sparks are really talanted.



Other than that, you could try these. It is actually my old booklist that I mention in many other questions



The Secret of the Lost Necklace by Enid Blyton
House at the Corner by Enid Blytton
The Seven Dials Mystery by Agatha Christie
The Alchemist of Barbal by David Clement-Davies
Mirror Dreams by Catherine Webb
Mirror Wakes by Catherine Webb
Lover's Lanes by Jill Marie Landis
Pandora by Anne Rice
The Cold Cash War by Robert Asprin
Inkheart by Cornelia Funke
The Thief Lord by Cornelia Funke
The Secret Country by Pamela Dean
The Hidden Land by Pamela Dean
Champagne Charlie by John Franklin Carter
An Oblique Approach by Eric Flint
Valley Forge by MacKinlay Kantor
Speedboat by Renata Adler
Pitch Dark by Renata Adler
Within This Present by Margaret Ayer Barnes
Seven Seats to the Moon by Charlotte Armstrong
Oy Pioneer! by Marleen Barr
The Kite Runner by Khaled Hosseini
A Thousand Splendid Suns by Khaled Hosseini
The Haunting of Nadia by Julia Jarman
The Indian in the Cupboard by Lynne Reid Banks
Word from Wormingford by Ronald Blythe
Nights at the Circus by Angela Carter
The White Ladies of Worcester by Florence L. Barclay
Under One Roof by Mary Cholmondeley
The Industry of Souls by Martin Booth
Intoxicated by John Barlow



Series:



Edge Chronicles by Paul Stewart and Chris Riddell
Inkheart Trilogy by Cornelia Funke
The Bridei Chronicles by Juliet Marillier
The Magic Thief series by Sarah Prineas
Guardians of the Flame by Joel Rosenberg
Spooksville series by Christopher Pike
Inheritance Cycle by Christopher Paolini



Other Young adult fiction:



Abarat: Days of Magic, Nights of War by Clive Barker
After the First Death by Robert Cormier
The Arm of the Starfish by Madeleine L'Engle



Horror fiction:

</answer>

<question>



Which name do you like best?



I'm writing a story involving boarding schools. The schools don't have much detail so far, and I've narrowed it down to the five schools I'm going to use. Now, I have to pick which one my main character will go to.



Which name do you like best?
*Brooke Village
*Ellington
*Rock Harbor
*Riverside
*Kent's



</question>



<answer from>



Zoee :)
Member since: 26 October 2008

erm...Riverside
:)



</answer>



<answer from>



ALISON H
Member since: 14 February 2008
Total points: 1628 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Ellington sounds the classiest.



Don't think you'd get a boarding school in a village or near a river or harbour.



</answer>



<answer from>



flingebu...
Member since: 22 March 2006
Total points: 9859 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Brooke Village would sound ironic if it was the name of a school in an industrial zone.



Ellington sounds like it was named after an inbred blue blood who gave money to found a private school because of his pedaphillic tendencies.



Rock Harbor sounds like a good name for a porn star, so if it is a boys school the name could be part of a sexual fantasy of a sexually frustrated boy.



Riverside is an utterly crap name.



Kent's sounds like it was sponsored by a tobaco company



</answer>

<question>



Titles for a story about a terror plot in an aeroplane?



</question>



<answer from>

Member since: 20 September 2008
Total points: 1405 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>

(thanks, Family Guy!)



</answer>



<answer from>



flingebu...
Member since: 22 March 2006
Total points: 9859 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Enigmatic (Flight 45 or passenger 12) or even gate 16 (gate 16 is the only gate in the airport that passengers still use to board the plane through the old security system, so the terrorists can only board the plane if they board through gate 16).



Melodramatic...flight of the damn, flight of fools, Terror at 10,000 feet. Flight into terror, Destination....terror.



hmmm....I like that one....Destination...Terror!



Simple...the last flight, danger flight, terror aboard etc.



Make it positive and heroic. Last chance for heroes, a heroes calling, the night we stood tall etc



How about make it more personal. Ted's terror



</answer>

<question from>



Tom
Member since: 25 March 2008
Total points: 358 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Is this a good idea for a story? (for NaNoWriMo)?



One day a boy named Thomas obtains a magical watch that takes him back in time. Awesome.  But then, uh oh, he accidently breaks it, which causes the watch to malfunction. Time starts repeating itself every twenty-four hours. And now, he has to go through the same day doing the same things forevah. Worser yet, it's on a school day. Crap. Because the day will be forgotten anyway, Thomas starts doing different things to test peoples' reactions and stuff. He learns a lot about his friends, enemies and people in general from doing this.



After doing so many things day after day, Thomas becomes bored and, therefore, more risky in his feats, and he loses his mind a bit. He starts doing incredibly crazy things, and gets very carried away with it. Ever wondered what would happen if, say, you pulled down a teacher's trousers? Or even did it to yourself? What if you murdered someone in front of everyone? What would the reaction be?



Unfortunately for Thomas, the watch somehow fixes itself... at the completely wrong time... Thomas must now face the consequences of his horrific actions, which have caused a massive uproar of disgust.



</question>



<answer from>



Staszek G
Member since: 14 July 2008
Total points: 1326 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Good excelent it defintly shows us the truth of our society and facing his deads good and grotesq ending !!  In fact you should call it "Gods Trap"



</answer>



<answer from>



Rosel K
Member since: 31 October 2008
Total points: 130 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



That's what you looking for! Too much to type, so just watch here's the link http://www.blog-x.in/index.php?q=related...
This small video WILL REALLY HELP YOU!



</answer>



<answer from>



Dixie Woman
Member since: 14 January 2008
Total points: 6005 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Books & Authors



</answer from>



<answer>



With this premise, you might consider keeping it light so Thomas can be likable.  Meaning, he could pull pranks but he shouldn't murder anyone or do any intentional harm.  But hey, anything goes for NaNoWriMo, right?



</answer>
